39012514.review:
I hardly ever write reviews, but I felt that it was necessary to do so for this game.

[h1]Story[/h1]
The story was excellent and it was a good way to finish up the series. It didn't come out as well as either of the previous games' stories, in my opinion, but it got the job done and left me somewhat satisfied.

[h1]Visuals[/h1]
The visuals were pretty enough although I hated the janky animations. The fact that mouths sometimes just didn't move at all when a character was talking, or that hair just ripped through bodies made it an annoying experience most of the time, but especially during intense scenes. I strongly preferred the more static visual novel style of VLR, but it didn't make ZTD unplayable by any means.

[h1]Music[/h1]
Music was good as always. Only had a few instances where I felt the score was a little too powerful for what was happening or the other way around.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
Or rather lack thereof. Scenes play out without you having to click to go to the next line and the scenes have a more 'cinematic' feel to them. So you are basically not allowed to do anything by yourself, except during the puzzle rooms and the decision games. It felt more like watching a movie than playing a game. During each of the long discussion scenes I felt my attention slip more than once, while this was never the case during previous games because I was forced to read and click, so I had to be looking at the screen.
The fact that jumping between fragments and teams was available from the very start made it so that not a single choice felt even remotely pressuring aside from that one in the AB game format. There wasn't a single time where I thought "oh no, if I choose this now, they might choose this and screw me over, but what if they don't". Nor was there any time where I actually legitimately felt bad for a choice that had a bad outcome for a certain team.
Another issue I had specifically with the fact that this is a port is that the memo feature is virtually unusable because drawing with a mouse sucks. The least they could've done was allow keyboard input for typing (which would've also been cool for the password inputs etc.)

[h1]Final[/h1]
Overall I am very glad that we got this game after all the issues it went through, but I'm not happy with the design choices that were made for it. It's obvious they went for a style that was very much inspired by the West (TellTale Games), rather than sticking to the original VN style. The cinematic scenes, the (largely unnecessary) gore and fountains of blood, and the fact that some of the characters did OOC things just made me roll my eyes most of the time.
All in all I would say I recommend this game solely for the fact that it's the one that wraps up a lot of the story.

38984458.review:
La última entrega de una de mis sagas favoritas, Zero Escape.

Es una saga compleja, con muchas paradojas y vínculos que te pueden dejar un poco confuso si uno no presta mucha atención. A pesar de que es uno de sus encantos, también puede volverse su punto débil. ZTD no es un mal juego, pero dentro de la saga pierde fuerza. Es difícil hacer un buen final para una trilogía y, especialmente, cuando es tan esperado y no hay mucho presupuesto. La narrativa de ZTD a veces resulta confusa, ciertas cosas resultan forzadas (en mi opinión, especialmente el final) y, teniendo en cuenta la saga completa, bastantes cosas quedan sin responder.

En ZTD se optó por cambiar de una manera un tanto drástica el gameplay, narrativa y visualmente. Desapareció la narración literaria del protagonista y pasó a ser 100% diálogo. No está mal hecho pero quita cierto nivel de inmersión del jugador. Esto, mezclado con que visualmente pasó a ser 100% 3d y la acción/narración dependía de diálogos y acciones de los personajes, fue un punto muy negativo. Por motivos de presupuesto, los modelos en cuanto a expresiones y movimiento no eran muy allá, lo que a la hora de crear tensión, emoción o una escena dramática puede revertir el efecto y hacer que resulte ridículo. Por suerte, la banda sonora de Shinji Hosoe compensa en muchos momentos por lo buena que es. En VLR la mecánica de juego es similar, pero dada su narración la tensión sigue presente mientras que en ZTD esa atmósfera se pierde un poco. 

En resumen; ZTD es un final para la trilogía un poco regular. No es un mal juego pero tampoco es un juego muy bueno. Sin embargo, lo sigo recomendado para los fans de saga, por el cariño a la saga, porque ZTD sigue teniendo un valor nostálgico por la presencia de personajes que salen en juegos anteriores, y porque los puzzles me resultaron entretenidos.

38801074.review:
Having played the previous two games, I was really looking forward to this. But 6 hours in I felt an overwhelming urge to play something else. That was months ago, and I just can't find the motivation to give it another chance when there are so many other time wasters out there. Unfortunately it's too late to demand my money back.

Now this is a matter of taste, but ZTD's chaotic, disjointed storytelling structure bugs the hell out of me. I loved the precedessors because making a decision, and watching the consequences unfold before your eyes was so much fun. ZTD hops from scene to scene seemingly at random and you don't get to see the consequences of your actions until MUCH later.  This caused me to stop caring and just about killed the story for me. I don't care if it all comes together and starts to make sense 15+ hours in. I want a story right away, not disjointed puzzle pieces of one.

I also didn't like how the story would 'end' repeatedly after ONE SINGLE ROOM. No, not the 'to be continued' kind of cliffhanger, but an actual ending. After. One. Room. Not just once, but every single time I did a room during those first 6 hours.

I also felt that the story sequences were much shorter than in previous installments, though that could be because the animations are awkward and many of the voice actors amateurish at best. Plus some of the characters who appeared in the previous games have undergone off screen character development that felt forced and unbelievable.

p.s. those who say that the voice actors are good don't know what good voice acting sounds like. Horizon: Zero Dawn has good voice acting. As does Dragon Age Inquisition. This does not.

38188680.review:
Me considero un jugador de juegos tipo FPS/FPS-RPG/Fighting... sin embargo, este juego (y saga) ha sido uno de los mejores que he jugado en mi vida, y quedé con un sabor "agridulce" al terminarlo ya que "no hay más juego ni historia".

Una novela visual con elementos de point and click y resolución de puzzles y acertijos, más el agregado de toma de decisiones respecto a hechos puntuales que cambia el curso de los acontecimientos según lo decidido.

La historia es increíble, con muchos "idas y vueltas", con un desarrollo de personajes en general muy cuidado y bien expuesto, lo que hace que, a poco de iniciado en la hisotira, uno siempre tenga algún tipo de sentimiento hacia ellos y que ninguno te deje indiferente. Las situaciones y revelaciones mantendrán tu interés y llevarán tu asombro y perplejidad a un nivel que muy pocos juegos pueden llegar, lo que hace que la saga sea una pieza única y jugarla sea toda una experiencia.

La música también es excelente, con piezas y melodías sublimes que acompañan perfectamente la situación. Los controles son bastante básicos y funcionan bien, aunque extraño de VLC que el click derecho del mouse realice "zoom-out".

Como puntos en contra, podemos mencionar los gráficos, que si bien son los mejores de la saga, apenas "cumplen", así como la duración (unas 25 a 30 horas), más corto que VLR. También la ausencia de traducciones (oficiales y/o de fans), ya que los únicos idiomas disponibles son el japonés y el inglés. Tampoco se puede seleccionar individualmente el idioma del audio y de los subtítulos.

Si bien se puede jugar sin haber jugado previamente a las entregas anteriores, tiene muchísimas referencias a estos, por lo que es FUERTEMENTE recomendado jugar primero al 999, luego al VLR y recién a ZTD, para que la experiencia sea única.

Tambien recomiendo NO leer las wikis hasta completar la saga, ya que en las mismas hay mucha información cruzada entre los 3 juegos y se corre el riesgo de perder el elemento sorpresa.

37239023.review:
Je vous écris cette évaluation de derrière les barreaux.

Ma plus grosse claque PC de l'année. Etant le 3eme épisode d'une trilogie, je ne recommande pas de s'y lancer sans avoir, au moins, fait le deux, mais on retrouve dans les Zero Escape une qualité de scénario qui me laisse pantois. Et surexcité.

Dans mon cas, j'aime bien également avoir à me creuser la cervelle et résoudre les différentes énigmes (même si les contrôles PC ne sont pas les plus adaptés à mon sens, il y a des fois où la façon de déplacer la caméra m'aura bloqué dans ma progression), et j'adore cette manière qu'on a de pouvoir sélectionner quel chapitre de l'histoire découvrir via un arbre de possibilités.

Au cours de mes 42h de jeu, je notais fiévreusement le moindre indice (qui finissait presque toujours par servir), la moindre information qui paraissait avoir de l'importance, et j'avais à côté d'une PC une feuille couverte de gribouillis qui ressemblait un peu à l'image que je me fais d'un document terroriste rédigé en langage codé. Sans compter que je poussais des hurlements surexcités à des heures indues, sans m'inquiéter d'alerter les voisins, répétant les mots-de-passe et les secrets que le jeu me fournissait au fur et à mesure. Et puis, il y a eu un contrôle de police à mon domicile.

36869679.review:
First off, play the two Nonary games first if you want this one to make sense.

Secondly, I have nominated this game for "The game with a character I'd most like to punch in the face repeatedly" in the Steam Awards. That character is Eric, who is quite possibly the worst person I have ever encountered in 2D or 3D, and I've met some really shitty people in real life.

If you can get past the pathetic waste of (virtual) DNA that is Eric (and he's not the only unlikable character in the game), then I would recommend ZTD, although not unreservedly.

The graphics are a marked improvement over VLR - I wasn't a fan of the move away from cel-shading to 3D models, especially when their expressions didn't change (for example, Clover continuing to smile happily despite just discovering a corpse), but I'm pleased to say the 3D modelling in ZTD is of a much higher quality than VLR.

Storywise, without revealing any spoilers, I found it too fragmented and this affected the flow and pacing too much compared with the previous two games.

With regards to gameplay, I found it much heavier on the VN side with fewer escape rooms than 999 and VLR, but that could just be my perception and related to the pacing element I mentioned above.

Overall it's an adequate conclusion to the trilogy, if not an overwhelmingly satisfying one. If you enjoyed the first two games then pick this one up, otherwise don't bother.

36828318.review: Play it for the escape rooms, not for well-written plot.  Also play it to finish the trilogy, don't touch this unless you've played through "9 Hours, 9 Persons, 9 Doors" and "Virtue's Last Reward" first, as there's massive spoilers for both involved here.  Unlike 999 and VLR which avoided paradoxical logic until the very end, ZTD fully embraces the bootstrap paradox and uses it multiple times throughout the game to explain major elements of the plot and even to solve a puzzle or two.

36512414.review:
[h1]Definamos que es antes de nada:[/h1]

Tenemos que ser francos, no es un juego de acción sino más bien una novela visual llevada al 3d o una película interactiva en la cual puedes resolver tú los puzzles y tomar decisiones. Dicho esto...

Dentro de su particular campo esta es la tercera parte de una saga... la cual sitúa los acontecimientos ocurridos entre el primer y segundo juego (si... suena raro pero para entenderlo tendrás que empaparte de la historia y jugarlos ;P)

[h1]Valoración y nota:[/h1]

Es uno de esos juegos que se te puede hacer pesado al principio pero consigue engancharte... juega mucho con teorías relativas las cuales para que engañar... a todos nos han atrapado alguna vez (o me negareis que no habéis tenido inquietudes rayantes acerca del espacio/tiempo y el origen de muchas cosas... ya sabéis todo muy Zen XDD), pero al mismo tiempo tiene un entramado bastante oscuro aunque un tanto explotado, ya sabéis, mastermind detrás de todo que tiene un objetivo y tal... 


En los tiempos que corren ya esta casi todo inventado asi que me da por saco ver tanta gente quejándose de que falta originalidad... pese a todo hacia mucho que un juego no me conseguía darme tanto en el coco como en la patata (Peero habéis visto mi símil tó guapo con la comida eh eh?! vale ya me callo uwu) 

En definitiva le doy un [b]8/10[/b] a la saga en sí no solo a este juego... el por si solo se quedaria en un [b]7[/b].

La razón es que yo primero me pase este y aunque por eso diria que es mi preferido (ya sabéis los feels…) pero tengo que reconocer que flaquea ante sus predecesores en cuanto al carisma de los personajes y entramado de los retos.

Aunque es un acierto como lo han llevado porque no es fácil crear una historia tan bien hilada así como así... por eso chapó. 

[h1] Mi comentario personal acerca de esta saga[/h1]

Esto era lo que iba a poner como análisis en un principio pero mi di cuenta que ponía demasiado énfasis en mi experiencia personal y no en como debería verlo de cara a gente que no pueda entender mi planteamiento asi que... lo añado por si alguien quisiera noticear mi fangirleo >.>" 

Pueh eso... 

[spoiler]Este juego así como sus anteriores entregas son para mí una joya... no porque sea especialmente sobresaliente pero consigue dar a tu cerebro una buena colleja y recapacitar sobre cosas que por ti mismo nunca te habrías planteado...

Igual que una película en la cual al final te das cuenta que todo estaba conectado pero no supiste relacionarlo en su momento y en este caso tienes la oportunidad de ver por ti mismo todos los diversos caminos...

Pero noo solo es eso... ves como los personajes van evolucionando y dándose cuenta (o no) de las cosas... como crece la confianza o la traición, como surge el sacrificio o el egoísmo y como todo esto les pasa a los mismos individuos siendo la única diferencia la circunstancia que les ha llevado a dicha situación. 

Concuerda totalmente con mi filosofía acerca de como las personas no tienen una naturaleza establecida... uno avanza y mejora/empeora en función de a los acontecimientos y experiencias que se ha tenido que enfrentar. 

Aunque no es una excusa por la cual todo pueda justificarse.
[/spoiler]

36482232.review:
グラフィックは格段に向上しましたが「値段の割に」前作と比べてボリュームが少なく
ストーリーの粗が酷いので面白くはありましたが、総合的に見てBadとしました。

ZeroEscapeシリーズ3部作の完結編
前作である2作がセットになった「Zero Escape The Nonary Games」をプレイする事を推奨します。
前作で能力を強化した主人公がいよいよ歴史改変に挑むストーリーです。

[h1]ゲームとしての評価[/h1]
・前作よりマウスで部屋を見渡すのが楽になった。
・前作に比べグラフィックは格段に向上したが脱出ゲームとして、前作より創意工夫が見られない。

36481910.review:
Zero Escape: Zero Time Dilemma really feels like a letdown after the Nonary Games. I'll try not to include spoilers, but it'll be kind of hard without discussing my biggest gripe with the game.

Tl;Dr - The change from first-person view to outside observer of events killed the atmosphere and suspense, the game no longer has any meaningful mystery because you're given next to no clues on who's secretly killing people and who's Zero until the game is just suddenly ready to reveal their identities, Then some other minor gripes. Ultimately, though, you should probably play if you care about the overarching plot. 

First off, Atmosphere. The Nonary Games both had only partial voice acting, and were in traditional VN first-person view. This brought two things: Immersion, and focus on the environment. Both of those things were lost in Zero Time Dilemma. Sure, the music was just as unsettling, but it was played behind fully-voiced conversations, and the player was an outside observer instead of a participant in the Jigsaw-esque "game" the characters were part of.

Second, Horror. Sure, this could be part of atmosphere, but I think it deserves it's own footnote. In the Nonary games, when a character died, it was a terrifying thing to discover because you KNOW one of the other characters killed that guy, and you could totally be next. In Zero Time Dilemma, characters dying like that just brings an end to the memory fragment. That, combined with the altered atmosphere, just makes those scenes seem tragic instead of chilling.

Third, this game lost it's "whodunnit" factor when it decided the player didn't deserve all the information to at least try to solve the mystery on their own. Who chopped up Junpei and strangled Mira in the third timeline? We never get any clues, just the answer.

Then, there's the entire existence of a character named "Q." When the game starts, you're told that "Q" is the kid wearing the helmet, but then you almost immediately learn that his name is actually Sean, but this "Q" character is still referenced, even though he is literally never shown until after you've seen the timeline where two children, "Delta" and "Phi" are born during the game's events. I continued to assume that Q and Sean were the same person until Delta revealed himself to be Q, and that happens at the same time we learn that a now-grown Delta (time travel, it's a Zero Escape game and timelines are not boundaries. There's a 22-year-old with the literal mind of a 67-year old.) has been there the whole time. We, the outside observer, are never, ever shown this character, and no, it's not because we've been secretly playing as him. We're Carlos, Sean, and Diana.

Anyway, The fact that we are given next to no information on Q's existence ruins the potential to discover the truth for yourself. Yeah, he's locked in the game with the rest of you, but he's not a player, but he somehow is central to the plot.

Fourth, things get re-explained WAY TOO OFTEN!!! It would make sense if this were one of the older games and you had to restart at the beginning because you hit a bad end, but with the fragment timeline system in ZTD, there's no need. For example, Eric explains how he met fellow player Mira 3 times.

Fifth, there was a huge step back on the central theme of the games, which has been people with the ability to pull information from past, future, and alternate realities. In Virtue's Last Reward, the theme of "noting is set in stone until it's observed" expanded upon 9 hours 9 people 9 doors's light exploration into the theoretical "Morphogenetic field," which allows you to, at the end of the game, complete a puzzle and send the information back in time to save a child's life.
Sixth, on the topic of the first game, you meet the protagonist from there again. Sure, they explain it away as part of the plot, but they turned him into an uncaring asshole.

If you played and enjoyed the Nonary Games, you need to play ZTD just in case they make a Zero Escape based on the "happy end" timeline from there. Though if they do that, I really hope it's a back-to-basics entry that plays out more like 999 or VLR than ZTD.

35993705.review:
Don't play this game. Play Zero Escape: Virtues Last Reward instead. And then maaaaaybe if you like that so much you want more, come back and play this. Why?

This game has what ZE:VLR had, but less of it. The story is less compelling, the reveal of the major conceit of the game is poorly pulled of by comparisonf, and it feels like there are fewer puzzles. This game also really drags at the begining, and your first through jumps through the story line don't make sense - not in an "oh, maybe this is a mystery they'll solve later" kind of way, but in a very 4th-wall breaking, "I'm thinking about the design of this game instead of having fun playing it" kind of way.

This game also has some of the same problems ZE;VLR had, most notably a couple of puzzles where you'll definitely be googling the solutions and then wondering "how did you expect me to figure that out???" This goes beyond puzzles being challenging - some of the solutions just feel cheap, while others are too easy, and the game rarely manages to land in that sweet spot in the midddle that ZE:VLR hit more frequently.

The one great thing about this game is the endgame. Just like ZE:VLR the ending goes off into some absolute insanity, but of the kind that makes perfect sense with all that's been leading up to it. The plot really comes together at the end... but good luck forcing yourself to get there.

35217593.review:
全体的にプレイヤーは[b]『ゲームをする』[/b]のでは無く、[b]『ゲーム内のキャラがゲームに参加している』[/b]のを傍観するだけ。
シナリオを断片化し、最後には繋がる…という設計だが、それであれば映画を作った方が良い。
また、ゲーム要素のため特定ルートによるロック解除があるが、それが非常にストレスを溜める。
ロック解除や関連のあるシナリオへの誘導は無く、要するにシナリオを2周以上巡り直す必要がある。
初回はシナリオのスキップや高速表示も出来ないため、これも非常にストレスとなる。
ノベル風表示(背景人物、オーバーレイで文字)ならまだ読みやすい気もするのだが。

脱出ゲーム部について、序盤の後は前述の通りシナリオが断片化しフリーで選択出来るため、
簡単・難しいの難易度が入り交じっている。
そのため設計上仕方の無いことだが、進行によるゲームバランスを放棄している状態になっている。
人によっては完全に詰まる可能性も高く、その上でほぼ時間制限無しのためモチベーションが下がる。

まとめとして、声優同士のボイスドラマを聞きたいのであればオススメできるが、
ゲームを期待している人や、根気が無いのであればオススメはできない。途中で飽きます。
999やシボウデスは普通に最後までプレイしたんですけどね。
あと、この手のゲームには多いですが『なんでそれくらいのことも解らない・見つけられないんだ』的な要素はいい加減何とかならないんですかね。

35047703.review:
Эта просто офигенная игра. Я тут почитал обзоры и, похоже, предыдущие игры ещё лучше. Так что непременно их пройду. А, да, надо же сказать пару слов, ведь "офигенная игра" звучит не слишком очевидно :D 

Так вот, по сути игра о перемещении между реальностями. Если вы смотрели анимеху "Врата Штейна", то для вас многое будет понятно. начало напоминает фильм "пилу", некоторое количество людей заперто в некотором помощении, а злой дядька приготовил для них испытания и бла-бла-бла. Кароч, представьте себе фильм пилу, добавьте немного япоснкой проработанности персонажей, приправьте типичной японской философией о смысле жизни, людях и прочего и получите примерное представление о сюжете. Множество концовок тоже радует. аждая интересна по своему. Если вы ищите игру с интересным сюжетом, то она для вас, однако здесь нет графония, да и анимация персонажей тоже странная, но мне все равно дико понравилась игра. >.<

Ой-ой, совсем забыл указать самое главное: по сути это кино, поскольку большую часть времени вы будете смотреть кат-сцены, временами решать головоломки и делать выборы. Рассматривайте это как интерактивное кино, нежели игру. Но, если честно, это даже хорошо - было легче погрузиться в атмосферу и сопереживать героям.

Звуковое сопровождение на высоте. Отличный саундтрек.

Думаю, так же стоит отметить, что игра по сути поделена на сцены, которые включают некоторые эпизоды. Если у вас возникнет какя-нибудь проблема с прохождением. то вероятнее всего из-за бага не открылся какой-нибудь эпизод. У меня так было. Игра не засчитала смерть команды "С". Поэтому в игре есть большая "схема" всех сцен. Думаю, что вы поймете о чем я, когда начнете играть ;) Ориентируйтесь в ней, если что.

34668686.review:
First things first, Zero Time Dilemma is the third entry in the Zero Escape series, and you need to play the other 2 games in order to understand this one properly, with that said, let's continue.
Zero Time Dilemma is by far the worst of the three games, but that does not mean it's bad, it's just not as good as the others, but that's on a story point of view, personally, i prefer the storytelling mechanic on this game (movie like, something similar to a telltale game) than the storytelling mechanics on the other games (text based), i think it makes the characters look more human and makes the story less monotone. I also think most of the puzzles on this game were better than most of the puzzles on the other games (of course, there are exceptions), i think that because the puzzles on this one are more about decifrating codes and finding passwords than doing math based minigames (nothing wrong with that, i just think it got very annoying in the other games). There's also one important thing that differs this game from the others, the story is not told in a linear way, you play through fragments and later you find out what actually happened and how these fragments matched with other fragments, initially i hated this, i thought it was confusing and ruined the storytelling, but as i continued playing, i noticed it's not that bad, mainly when things start to make sense. 
So, after all, what makes this one worst than the other ones? Well, i'll start by stating that the story is overall weaker than in the other 2 games, but that isn't so much of a problem, because it's still rather interesting, what i actually disliked a lot about this game were the poorly made plot twists near the end, don't get me wrong, there are some plot twists in this game that turns the other 2 games around, but mainly the final 2 ones, involving the mastermind and his "complex motives" that are NEVER entirely explained, i won't spoil it for you, but it does ruin the experience a little bit.
Well, so in conclusion, the game is weaker than the other 2, but not bad, and if you played the other 2 and want to finish the story, you totally should play this.

But still, the whole experience is unique and breathtaking for like 95% of the game. It pieces together the story started with the 2 previous games, which I recommend to try out as well, Virtue's Last Reward being my favorite (you have a clear continuity of it in this game).

The price may appear a bit steep for what kind of game it is, but at the same time, there's really not that many story-telling games of this kind and quality. Make you own mind, IMO it's must-buy if you can find a sale around 20€-$.
Right now it's around 35€, it's about the price of portable games for DS-VITA in comparison. Fine to me.

34565796.review:
[h1]The Less Stated, the Better[/h1]

[b]Obviously, you've already played 999 and Virtues Last Reward.[/b]

Otherwise, I would suggest playing those before purchasing this title. Playing this game within the vacuum of itself would be mildly entertaining, but you'd miss the entire point.

[h1]This game successfully bridges the story of all past titles, while taking on the INSANELY ambitious task of explaining how human existence works: and it excells fantastically.[/h1]

If that sounds like fun to you, I strongly suggest picking up the earlier titles. All 3 are great games.

[h1]Quick Pros and Cons[/h1]

+     More blood
+     A more ambitious storyline than past titles (if you can even believe that)
+     The fully-animated cutscenes, as opposed to the dialog boxes of earlier titles, are a welcome addition (even if some lip-syncing is out of place and some of the voice acting is a little drab during violent parts)
+     The puzzles are harder


-     The puzzles are too hard (trying to decipher an abstract alphabet, [spoiler]relating its symbols to a base 10 numeric system, and then converting/downscaling answers into a base 13 numeric system[/spoiler] is a little insane. There is also one puzzle in the game which is actually unsolvable...so have fun kids)

-     I cannot propose a better solution but...[b]Pacing the game episodically SUCKS[/b]. Having to jump around from fragment to fragment really divests yourself from the characters and the immediate plot points. Very often, I'd be lost and have to back-track the timeline to figure out where the hell I was and what I was doing. However, this helps the pacing to be less repetitive than Virtues Last Reward. So a small plus there.

-     You will actually get stuck a few times during regular playthrough of the storyline. There are some mechanics at work in the menu screens/flowcharts that are witheld from your knowledge. They are also never explained. You [b]will[/b] have to replay certain scenes ad nauseum to create different outcomes. This is unique to this specific game.

34425675.review:
So I just finished a marathon of Virtue's Last Reward (awesome story, great game) and went to purchase this sequel.

The characters are poorly introduced.. you start with a booooooooooring story with a bunch of characters that already knows each other without explaining how the met.. in contrast with the other games where every character is a mystery.

So.. 1/2h of boring timeline decisions that I really wanted to skip without missing the story line.

What I missed most in contrast wih the other games is that you can skip dialogues.. I read faster than I listen so I want to skip a phrase to play faster. But.. when you skip the phrase that is on the screen you also skip a bunch of unsaid dialogues!! So you can't skip dialogues if you want to know the full story.

Ok, the game finally starts.. the 3D is awful.. this is a 2016 PS4 game with PS1 graphics.. the characters are well drawn but the background is really bad 3D. There are a lot of objects you simply can't figure what is just by looking.

3D puzzles are bad.. I use mouse to play, so drag to rotate and click to select. Some times when I try to rotate with an object under the mouse it clicks instead.

Also I miss RIGHT MOUSE BUTTON to go back from a zoom!! I have either press escape or click "Back". On the long run this makes a huge difference.

No second chances when you miss a password (like the last games). When you miss, you're kicked out the screen and have to click again to try again.

Time flow is a mess.. I want to follow a line I chose in the beginning but I have no way to know without having to click on a picture and play it to the end.

I'm pretty sure the story is awesome but the devs removed a lot of simple helpful features from the other games.. I'll keep playing to the end because I'm a fan of the series but after two hours playing I confess that I have some regrets on buying this game.

34194686.review:
Zero Time Dilemma is drastically better than its predecessors as far as presentation goes.  I would say the graphics have a comic book style feel.  I really did appreciate it, especially when compared against the other two games in the series.  I also felt the voice acting was drastically better, although I hated zero’s English voice actor so much that I played the game with the Japanese voice actors and English subs.  I also felt the puzzles were drastically better then Virtues Last Reward.  There were a few that made absolutely no sense, but for the most part I felt they were well done.

I will say that I felt the way the menus for the time flows were laid out just was terrible.  Most of the time I had no idea what I was supposed to be clicking on or where.  It’s divided into story fragments menus, global flow menus, and character flow menus.  I guess it was kind of fun to do a character menu scene and then after see where it appeared on the global flow and if that’s entirely how you picked things that would be fine, but eventually it gets to the point where you have to go into sub menus of the character flow menu to find the right path or clicking on the global flow menu and then choosing paths from there to find the character path.  It was too much.  I guess if the plan was to have the menu’s be its own puzzle then job well done…but I’m pretty sure it wasn’t, which means it was just poorly designed.

Despite that if the story was good I would recommend the game, but it’s just not.  I don’t understand why people praise the story of this series.  First, this game is a direct sequel so it’s not like you can skip the other games.  You’ll be utterly lost if you haven’t played the others.  Which is certainly fine, but the way character act and the way the story is laid out makes no sense.  You fine yourselves at a Mars simulation in the desert, maybe in Nevada.  You have all agreed to be part of this test because the organization was paying people $500k to participate (I’m not sure  who thought that was an accurate number, no one is paying people that much money for this.  Especially, a group of randos with no real skills).  You are then captured by someone calling himself Zero and forced into a death trap game in a bunker where 6/9 of you will die. So again it sets up a murder mystery…but it’s just so utterly terribly told and just a mess at every turn, explaining why would all involve spoilers though.

[spoiler] First, so long as you’ve played the other games it takes all of 2 hours to figure out every single mystery in the game except who is Zero.  It has the same problem of Virutes Last Reward, but at least thankfully this game is shorter.  So you only have to wait about 20 hours after figuring everything out for the characters to admit it.  Such as it’s painfully obvious Sigma and Diana are the parents of Phi…to the point where I’m not sure if this was supposed to be a mystery or not.  Diana and Phi constantly act like mother and daughter…so when it’s revealed at the very end they are and the characters act surprised I was just utterly baffled.  

There is also a subplot that one of the characters is a serial killer (not zero, I mean another serial killer).  I mean it’s Mira, their isn’t even a question.  She acts like a sociopath in everything she says and Sean’s hint that he knows about a serial killer so painfully points to Mira that it’s just ridiculous.  Again…since it was so obvious I’m not even sure if it was a mystery.

So really the only mystery in the game is who is zero and it’s an unsolvable mystery.  Zero is a character that you have never heard of.  See it turns out Zero is really Phi’s twin brother Delta who Sigma and Diana put in an alien teleporter that teleported him to the year 1904 where he was raised by German scientists (and I mean clearly he became a Nazi, there is no way this lunatic that performs horrendous experiments on people wasn’t one of Hitler’s top scientists).  He came up with this master plan in order to fix the paradox that if he didn’t put people in this death trap game he would never have been born, because he gets conceived in the death trap game…except it’s not a paradox, so there was no reason for him to do this.  He exists simply because the teleporter sent him to a world where he exists…there was absolutely no reason for him to recreate the circumstances where he was born.

Oh yea, I should also mention the entire game is an unreliable narrator.  It turns out Zero was part of your group of 9 the whole time and it was really a group of 10.  They just never really mention or reference him and I guess it’s supposed to be that the player is him.  It’s a cheap twist.  It takes the genius of Agatha Christie’s twist in The Murder of Roger Ackroyd and bastardizes it.  The game literally could have done that twist though and it would have been genius.  All it would have required was the game telling you that you are the character of Delta and everything is seen through your eyes and the characters could have directly been talking to you.  That’s not what happens here, no one really acknowledges Delta’s existence, he’s apparently there in every scene, but no one mentions him at all.  Clues all certainly point to him existing, but the game tries very hard to obfuscate that.  

The game wanted a grand twist at the end, but that twist also ruins the murder mystery occurring in the game.  I guess a lot of people don’t care.  They seem to think this twist is a masterstroke, but I can’t really accept it.  It’s just too many logical leaps. (1) that when characters talk about Q, they mean Delta and not the robot who the game makes you think is Q (2) That Delta is a 124 year old man who is the son of Sigma and Diana who was sent back in time in an alien teleporter (3) That Delta/Q is Zero and their motive for putting everyone together is to stop a terrorist in the future form killing 8 billion people so really he’s a good guy.  Even if you could make the logical leap that hey wait this is weird the game doesn’t seem to be talking about the robot boy when they are saying Q…their must secretly be a 10th person here which is me…and if they are doing that it must mean that Q is Zero!  I don’t see how then you can connect the motive of…he must be doing all these horrible things in order to stop terrorists from wiping out humanity.  This point is literally never even brought up until the very end of the game, so you couldn’t possibly know this was the motive.

I guess the game is a serviceable time travel scifi story.  I don’t care for it because I dislike the twist that it deals with alien teleporter technology.  Also the ending where everyone is now friends with Mira…who again is still a brutal serial killer…who they all remember specifically murdering everyone in the game as well as the dozens she killed outside the game, but apparently is now sorry so it’s alright (what serial killer has ever said, oh I’m sorry I’m going to be a nice person now). [/spoiler] 

Ugh, all I wanted was a good murder mystery.  Why is that so difficult.

34091568.review:
Spike Chunsoft has done it once again! Zero Time Dilemma is a great sequel to 999 and VLR. It basically picks up right where VLR left off (if you follow the story close enough) and you get all the feels in the story. It has great new characters and a good building off of old characters from 999 and VLR. 

VLR has to be my favorite story-wise, but Zero Time Dilemma had me going "OH S**T NO" after completing puzzles. These were my FAVORITE puzzles. I was literally biting my nails in anticipation of the harrowing turn the story would take. I also have to say that I love Phi's design in this game. She looks beautiful and grows on you even more as a character. I was hoping to have her be a bit more prominent in the game, but it makes sense as to why other characters had more of a focus. 

I only have one complaint--and it is merely because of personal interest--but...

*SPOILERS* *SPOILERS* *SPOILERS*

If all the SHIFTers retain their memories, why does it seem like a number of them just FORGET the crimes of one of the major characters?! It seems like a continuity gap in the story.

*END OF SPOILER*

I guess one more thing is that the graphics can be a bit weird at times. Characters mouths sometimes don't move when they talk and animations aren't very fluid. Still this is a good PC port and doesn't distract from the story. 

Regardless, I love this game and would recommend to anyone who loves visual novels, puzzles, the previous nonary game stories, and/or other Spike Chunsoft works.

34081171.review:
「極限脱出」シリーズ3部作の完結編です。
前作の「極限脱出 9時間9人9の扉」「極限脱出ADV 善人シボウデス」とストーリー的にガッツリつながっていますので、まずはそちらをプレイしましょう。
なおこれらはセットになって「Zero Escape The Nonary Games」というタイトルでSteamで販売されています。

本作はゼロと名乗る謎の人物に拉致された9人の男女が、命懸けのデスゲームに挑むADVゲームです（3回目）。
前2作とやることは大体同じです。
本作のみの違いとして、ストーリーが進む場面では、吹き出しなしにキャラの動きとセリフだけで展開します。ドラマを見ているような感覚ですね。ただその弊害として自由にページ送りしたりはできないので、煩わしく感じられるかもしません。
そしてストーリーは場面ごとにバラバラにされており、基本的にどこからでも進めることができます。しかし各場面が全体の流れにおいてどこの時間軸に位置付けられているかは各場面をクリアするまでわからないため、そのあたりも推理していくと面白いです。
本作は様々な場面で「決断」が迫られ、その決断によってその後の展開が変わります。ある決断がまったく違う場面に影響を与えて意外な展開につながったりするので、場面をバラバラにしたのがうまく作用していると感じます。

ストーリー的には、前2作での謎がほぼ解決します。そういう意味でも前2作をプレイしたら必ずプレイするべきでしょう。
もちろん謎の解決方法は前2作同様に相当なトンデモであり力技です。
それでも意外な展開や明かされる真実に驚かずにはいられないことでしょう。

なお前2作に比べてかなり血なまぐさい展開が増えているので、そこは少し注意した方がいいかもしれません。

34080727.review:
这是一部缺点很明显的游戏，糟糕的建模和冗长的过场剧情透出一股浓浓的没钱感，十分考验玩家的耐心。但是考虑到本作难产的过程，又是一部填坑作，实在是不忍苛责过多。极限脱出系列在欧美好评如潮，在日本却是反应平平，直接导致了本作的难产，众欧美粉丝便自发组建了一个名叫“蓝鸟”的组织积极活动才有了这部作品。 [spoiler] 这就是爱阿！[/spoiler]因此本作也是早早发布了英文版本的发售信息。（打越估计相当郁闷）
本作的游玩方式非常独特，碎片化剧情的游玩方式像拼图一样，让人在游玩的过程中一步步地推理剧情的走向。选择项的设置也非常有趣，与前作基本都是选门定路线的方式不同，本作的某些选择带了很大的运气成份，这涉及到游戏引导的巧妙之处。尤其本作的首尾呼应堪称绝妙。值得一提的是本作和前两作一样提出了不少很有趣的理论：蒙特霍尔问题、睡美人问题等等。
[h1]总体评价[/h1]
作为填坑作来说它完成了它的任务，玩完且喜欢一二部的推荐入手。

33801147.review:
You're either going to love this game or hate it. Be warned that you cannot play ZTD without first completing both 999 and VLR in that order.

ZTD is a very different direction for the series. It doesn't play like a traditional VN, it's more of a Telltale style--a really low budget TT game.

I don't put that lightly. This game has horrendous models that make VLR's look good by comparison, and it also has the most stilted, stiff, and just downright terrible animation I think I have ever seen in a game this popular. It looks absolutely awful. As for the voice acting, it's hit and miss. It's servicable overall but it's not as good as VLR's. Nearly every escape puzzle is terrible in ZTD as well. There's a couple interesting ideas here and there, but the game feels a need to make every room feel like a scavenger hunt. Unlike VLR where the puzzles were consistently challenging and logical, ZTD tends to present solutions that will either warrant a reaction of "oh, come on!" or "how in the hell was I supposed to know that?!"

ZTD's puzzles are not hard. They work almost exclusively in a manner where the most challenging part is finding wherever the hell Zero decided to hide every piece you need. If a puzzle seems impossible, it's simply because it is. However, unlike in VLR where characters would tell you when you were wasting your time and didn't have enough clues, ZTD's cast is often as oblivious as you are, resulting in indefinite times of trial and error. You'll often become irritated not because you weren't smart enough to figure out a simple solution, but because that answer was hidden away in some corner you wouldn't have considered to look in. As someone who disliked most of 999's puzzles and adored VLR thoroughly, these are the worst puzzles in the entire Zero Escape series by a landslide.

So, why am I recommending this game that I'm tearing to shreds?

Because once you pass all of the lackluster escapes, preferably with a spoiler-free guide such as this one
http://www.thonky.com/zero-time-dilemma/
you are in for one hell of a story. That's all I can say without getting into spoiler details.

Overall, ZTD has a fantastic story that will surprise you several times, and it's safe to say that it will stick with you long after you've completed it. Just look past the terrible presentation and the awful puzzles.

33726679.review:
NOT FOR THE FANS!

As a huge fan of the original 999 game on Nintendo DS, I have to say I am extremely disappointed in the direction this series headed. From the get go, the bizarre choices of redesign and complete change in personality of all recurring characters from previous entries is jarring to say the least.
If you are able to overlook those flaws, there's still the serious issue of subpar PS2-like graphics, terrible voice acting, unlikable characters and strange controls. 33712826.review:
This game continues the story from the two far better games collected under Zero Escape: Nonary games. The game is so far worse than the first two that it's really hard to recommend.

First, don't even think about the game without having played the prequels: The game would make no sense whatsoever, and you'd have trouble caring at all about any of the characters.

So why don't I recommend this game? I'll do my best to avoid spoilers for the previous two games, but if you want to remain unspoiled, just play them before reading: They are more than worthwhile on their own.

1) Graphics. While the game might is newer, and the prequels were not technical masterpieces, This one is so ugly it's unsettling. The facial expressions are so grotesque, they'll have you wishing for Mass Effect: Andromeda. It's not as if I expected good animation, but the few frames of animation that were selected could't make characters seem much less human. A couple are passable, but the large majority should just be redone.

2)Splitting the game into fragments. Unlike the previous games, where we got to play a branching tree, from start to end, here we get to play a wide series of fragments, most of which involving very few characters, and maybe a puzzle in the middle. The fragment system makes each scene have to stand on its own. This makes all the sections that are attempting to get emotional responses from the player to fall far more flat, because you could be getting them way before you have a chance to investing in the characters at all. 

3)In previous games, every decision led to more and more changes later, and thus we just got to see the narrative play differently, and especially in the second game, made it far easier for the player to navigate the game in a satisfying way. However, since we have fragments here, and we don't know what the next step is, the game instead wants us to just make a decision, and immendiately follow with the opposite one, as that's the way to move forward. How can I get invested into making a decision if the consequences will be instantly erased in a couple of minutes? this makes the game mechanical. For extra boredom, there are a few situations that are very similar to each other, so you face the same decisions over and over again, and you will pick both. It's the definition of how to kill the mood.

4) The game plays more like a video than like a visual novel: There's a button to speed up, but it often will end up skipping text. So at any time that the dialogue is moving slowly (and there's a lot of that), you end up missing entire sections, instead of just being able to move at the speed at which you can read.

5) It breaks a couple of conventions of the series in ways that just make the storytelling feel cheaper.

So ultimately, this is the worst game of the series by a country mile. You'll get though all the puzzles pretty quickly, and then it's an exercise in frustration to see all the little corners to reach the true ending. 

So I finished it, just out of completionism, but I wish I hadn't bought it.

33580633.review:
The game should probably be reviewed for two angles: people who played the other zero escape games and have build up expectations for this game, and those who touch it the first time, skipping the nonary games.

for the veterans:
there are several things you will have to get used to. while 999 was a pure visual novel and VLR slowly tried to make the shift (3d-VN), ZTD is more kind of a TellTale story-telling game. you have animated characters and the conversation only stops when you pause or have to make a decision. this is a BIG deal for some people (and for those who won't really understand: it is like the difference between reading a book and watching a movie about the same story). they also remodeled some of the characters having an appearence in ZTD, like they already did in VLR. Except for the name, i struggled a bit recognizing them here, to be honest. they use the same excuse for that fact again, but you get quickly used to the new design (if you could stand VLR that is).

The story told is still good, and it answers several questions you might had after the first two games (but not all). The way it is told you could also dislike being a fan of the earlier titles, tho. It's in short episodes of 5-15min, you can play in a semi-random order. early episodes add the classic escape rooms and a decision, the later episodes are mainly for story-conclusions. speaking of the rooms, they are as difficult as in 999, so not even close to VLR. you should finish a room in 10-30 minutes on average (if you don't get stuck because you overlooked the multiple ways of using a coin *like me*) without much paper work. I think that's fine, probably because the rooms didn't felt like the center of the story anymore (it's more about the decision game afterwards). 

Overall, It was a nice game and I enjoyed it more than The Walking Dead, but it still wasn't what I was expecting, so I love it a little less than 999&VLR. The price feels high for the playtime you get, so maybe grab it on sale (but get it).  


for new players:
you should probably play the other games first, but it is really not a must. Be warned that it, if you don't, maybe ruins the earlier games for you, because it reveals most of the main plots of 999 & VLR in the first 1-2 hours of the game. These can feel like the game is throwing kinda nonsense-explanations at you nonstop, and you might are not used to that. The characters have never time to explain the whole thing, so they buzzword bingo especially early in the game. If you played the nonary games, you got hours to slowly learn the ideas and truths in the Zero Escape universe. If you just play ZTD, you will have to except them pretty quickly, or else you get that bad scifi-fanfiction vibe (which can still be fun, nevertheless) and might lose interest. they even add more layers to their concept for the veterans, so try not to get lost.

The puzzles in ZTD are not too difficult and the NPCs give you a lot of tipps how to solve some of the problems (if needed). It is fun to see the story fold out fragment after fragment and you should definitely take the time to make some own theories how the story will end, who zero is and what this is all about. this might be easier (again) with more backstory, but the game tells you what you need to know along the line, except some of the fan service bits which are not really main-story-relevant. there could be plot/explanation holes I am not aware off because i played all games, but i felt they were pretty consistent in themselves. I can recommand this game, if you liked games like The Walking Dead, Life is Strange and obviously these escape the room type of games ;)

33490027.review:
本来想给“不推荐”的，后来想想结尾的那个隐藏剧情，还是改成了“推荐”。零时困境通关之后的第一印象是：比较失望。如果是别的剧本家写的还好，可你是在十几年前写出过Ever17和Remember11的人啊。也可能是被R11坑过一次，打越不敢写留大坑的剧本，所以在极限脱出第三部急匆匆的填坑，导致剧情显得生硬。极限脱出第一部和第二部可以说是这10年以来打越最接近E17和R11的作品，可惜第三部却给人一种虎头蛇尾之感。确实没法和巅峰期的作品相比，[b]Ever17和Remember11太神了，或许说几乎它们已经囊括了优秀科幻悬疑作品的所有要素，再难有后人超越（包括打越自己）。时至今日，那座名为《Ever17》的大山还在提醒着他：十几年过去了，本尊依旧是你最好的那部作品。[/b]

下面详细说优缺点：
优点：
＋惊悚悬疑的氛围依旧高水准，中后期剧情大爆炸，情感冲突点和爆发力不错
＋几乎填了前作95%的坑，也算是把三部曲画上了句号。
＋睡美人问题，蒙提霍尔悖论好评，这些元素加入得很好
＋保持前几作多周目环环相扣的时空跳跃感
＋[spoiler]隐藏结局的叙诡可谓是画龙点睛，[/spoiler]如果没有这个诡计，或许本评测就是“不推荐”

缺点：
-人物性格与前两作脱节太多，原因解释很生硬，个人无法接受，尤其体现在前两作主角各种智商掉线时
-外星时空穿梭机是最大的败笔
-黑幕人物设计比较苍白，部分动机让人无语，毁了二代结尾那个惊人计划的气氛
-真结局草草收场，我打完的时候还以为有隐藏真结局，结果查了半天攻略发现这tm就是结局了
-正片放到file里？后日谈才是真结局？经费不够了？没钱做婚礼CG咱至少得来张图吧。
-伪科学成分过多了，虽然是科幻作品咱们不能强调科学，但是咱们不能最后都变成超能力吧，你至少得向一代二代看齐啊。再往前看，虽然E17和R11都是软科幻，但也没给人一种伪科学的感觉啊。
-血腥猎奇的成分过多了，你没必要向龙骑士07学这方面，人家的作品就是有灵异成分，就是很邪道，不是科幻。之前的打越你不是这种风格，没必要把风格搞得太邪乎，每个作家都有属于自己的写作风格。这方面我还是喜欢infinity那种很“正”很“王道”的悬疑科幻气氛。

真正的fans，都是爱之深，黑之切。衷心希望打越钢太郎以后能写出比肩Ever17的作品。

33354846.review:
Alot of reviews say "this game isn't as good as the others in the series." I'm going to take it a step farther and say "you're probably better off not playing it." Especially when it costs as much as the 999/VLR combo pack. If you're dying to see how the story turns out, watch a lets-play or read the spoilers on the wiki. I honestly don't think you'll be missing anything. Here's why I think that:

(I take a roundabout way of framing this review. Feel free to skip a few paragraphs down if you want to skip to the meat of my thoughts on the game.)

Every once in a while, you find a game that is truly great, and leaves you wanting, desperate for more. And sometimes they decide to make those games into a series. You know the next ones won't be the same as the first, but you're so attached to the characters and world that you want to see where it goes. Soul Reaver was one of those games for me, and I had a similar experience with the Orson Scott Card's Ender's Game.

When I read the rest of Ender's series, it was different. Not as good, but not without merit either. Very different though. It's an ethical examination at the intersection of a handful of hypothetical sci-fi situations, not the story of a boy trying to make his way in a confusing world. I'm glad I didn't read the later ones right after the first, because it gave it time for it to exist in my mind as an independent thing. A complete work in and of itself. Nonetheless, I was glad I eventually read the rest. They weren't the same, but they were good in their own right. After 999, I felt the same about VLR.

However, when I played the later Soul Reaver games, I was deeply disappointed. They just threw the characters into circumstances that in many ways contradicted the previous ones. There was a half decent plot twist, but for the most part they were crappy. I felt like they added nothing to my experience. I would have probably been happier had I never played them. Completely without merit. After 999 and VLR, that's how I felt about ZTD.


(Ok, here's where I start the real review)

The game uses a "fragment system." The characters each have a short episode with typically involves waking with no memory, doing a room-escape and then a plot decission, and typically ends with the injection of meds that erase their memories of the episode. So to capture the feel of that, the game is presented in a series of disjointed, nonsequental chapters. You click on a team and a pic, and you get thrown into the middle of a story with no idea how it fits in with the rest of the story. It's a great idea, and I respect the developers for trying something more experimental, but in practice it runs into a few problems. 

First, I would imagine a terrific sense of isolation and disorientation if I imagnie being in that situation, which I think is what they were going for. They don't manage to pull it off though. The characters wake up and briefly discuss their lack of memories, but then go about solving their puzzles. Sometimes they wake up missing a person with no explanation, and there's some overly dramatic running and shouting. But they never really develop the characters enough that you get emotionally invested. Perhaps because the reactions are so dramatic, the characters so plastic, that it just is hard to relate.

Second, you really aren't that isolated. You click a button and it takes you to a flowchart that shows exactly where you are in the scheme of things. It's trivial to say "oh, they can't find this character, because this is an offshoot of that plot line. Yea, I know what happened." 

And third (and perhaps my biggest issue), the fragments just don't affect each other that much. I mean, they open up different puzzles and situations, but there's no reason for them to. Q team makes a decission about an injection, and the results for Q are identical. I mean, it changes the room the next group wakes up in, but there's no reason for it. In terms of meaningful decissions, there was one big one at the beginning, then one in the middle with Phi and Sigma, but otherwise they were all pretty meaningless. VLR felt like "I'm going to make good decissions to try to save everyone! I wonder if I can do it!" but this is more like "I've no idea why this choice matters, but i'm going to try both options to unlock more story pieces!"

The developers made one other decission that I feel was a big mistake. They decided to have three teams that almost never interact with each other, and you could control each individually. This had two major problems. First, they had no protagonist. You can control all the characters and events through each of their eyes. And if each of the character does what you ask them to do and never make their own decissions, they really become shells of characters. You aren't always trying to guess what such and such a character was thinking when they made their decission, because ultimate you'll see them make both, and then see the game's writers try to justify how the choice fit with the character.

Also, when you control each member of the group, there's no delimma in the prisoner's delimma. In VLR you were always trying to guess what the other characters would decide. Here, you control them and make them do what you want. Logically, it's so much simpler and less interesting. Except then in some situations, one character will make big decissions by themselves or take major actions without the player observing. The disconnect is very confusing. Ultimately, it's hard to make a mystery when you seem to see everything.

The last problem... the game was painfully simple. This ties in tightly with my previous concern about the teams being isolated and choices not mattering, but also just simply the length of the storylines. VLR's storyline let you make 3-5 decissions, making around 20 fully fleshed out endings. Excluding "they made the wrong choice and everyone immediately died" kind of decissions, ZTD had  1-3, for maybe 10 endings (A few of those are so simple, I'm reluctant to count them as real endings). Maybe 5 that felt as involved as the simplest VLR ones. 

Let's look at the line where C-team dies in first decission. After the character introduction and first choice (C's execution), we see team Q. They do a puzzle then make a decission that does not affect the other team. Next we see team D (in one of two rooms, depending on the choice Q made, but without any reason Q's choice should have changed their room). On both branches, D solves a room puzzle, has a chance to die, and then a final cutscene plays and the game is over. There's some final minor decissions tacked onto one of the branches, along the lines of "what does the person left behind do with himself" but nothing complex and nothing that influences any other characters. So there you have it 2 meaningful decissions, 1 meaningless decission, 3 or 4 fragments of things happening, and the game's over. That accounts for 2 of the 10 endings, or 20% of the game.


There were a handful of little things too. "Guess the word" style typed questions. The game asks "Who are you going to shoot?" I type "noone" and it doesn't recognize it so I assume I have to shoot someone... I read a faq later and find out it'll accept "nobody" though. Also, they introduce a new character right at the end, like "oh, he's been sitting around forever. We all knew about him; remember we referred to 'the old guy' once in one scene? We thought he was catatonic though, so we just ignored him." Seriously, that's just bad writing. Also, some solutions to puzzles are "do it alot." When the villian says "You'll die unless you roll 1s on 3 dice" I never imagined the solution was just "replay the scene multiple times, because eventually you'll hit all 1s and that storyline will continue."

I really was disappointed. VLR wasn't 999, but it was alright. But this game had some good ideas, but just came out bad.

33334165.review:
So....ZTD.

I've played both 9 Hours 9 Persons 9 Doors and Virtue's Last Reward, this game's predecessors.  Both of them are amazing. VLR being my personal favorite in the series. Luckily, you can buy them both on Steam! (Finally.) 

Sadly though, we also have this game. Don't get me wrong. As a game, it's definitely a decent find. It's got twists, turns, funny jokes, interesting characters, and a reference to Back to the Future. What more could you want?

Closure. That's what.

Sure, it does wrap up the plot and all, but it doesn't do a truly clean or satisfying end. The ending of VLR was setting up the finale to be a big ol' bonanza jamboree. A big climax that would satisfy any fan. And they fell short of the mark. 

Furthermore, at various points, I felt that the dialogue and plot were getting rather repetitive, a hard thing to get away from with the way they've set up the plot all jumbled together like, but they'd managed to fix that in VLR, so it's a little annoying here.

And speaking of annoying, gosh darn. The Q side of the story has that in spades. It has its good moments, but of all three groups, it has the most weak or even just terrible sections. As one may be able to tell from the trailer [spoiler]Eric goes gun-crazy a lot. And unlike how weapon-crazy characters have gone in the last two games, where they went weapon-crazy at about the same time into the plot for the endings that had them, it seems like Eric just whips out a shotgun and waves it around whenever a puzzle room is complete. Sadly, I'm just nitpicking here.[/spoiler]

Also, the game centers around these Decision Games, where you are meant to make tough choices that lead down several different paths. While some of these are used to good effect, plot-wise, many of them seem to be there just for padding purposes or to fulfill certain things. Many decisions are either extremely obvious as to which the right answer is or [spoiler]in the case of the final flippin' choice,[/spoiler] don't actually matter which you pick. Generally speaking, you'll find most of the good Decision Games (and the best plot moments (and the best (and most) puzzles, for that matter)) in Carlos's group. 

In the end, the is a good game, mechanically. And this is an okay game, plot-wise, it just can't seem to stick a good, satisfying landing. But as a Zero Escape game? It pales in comparison to its predecessors. It's like Sticker Star for Paper Mario, or Mass Effect: Andromeda for Mass Effect. As games go, it's fine, but as a member of the series? You shouldn't touch it. However, you kinda have to, if you're a big fan of the series. After all, it has the ending, however muddled and unsatisfying it is. 

Gameplay: 8/10. Not exactly original, but it keeps up the pace its predecessors set here.
Presentation: 7/10. Puzzle Rooms look great. Scenes look a little wonky, but you'll get over it. Runs pretty smoothly too.
Story: 3/10. It's kinda garbage. Some of the plot splits made due to Decision Games make little to no sense, and it is far less satisfying than previous works in the series.
Writing: 6/10. Snappy dialogue from old cast members and the new guys they hang with. Team Q lags behind a bit here, but they have their moments, though sparse they may be.

5/10. Get it if you've played the others, or if you like room escape games. It's good for that. A game like this generally lives or dies by its plot and writing. If the presentation or gameplay go down, it sure does hurt, but it's hard for it to be amazing with a crap plot or crap writing. 

Get it. Just, for the love of all that is holy, get it on sale. Not worth full price, as much as I hate to say it. This one really got my hopes up.

- Terribad cinematics
- Wonky controls some of the time, cannot use memo on file pages. Real life notepad is recommended.

Playing the previous 2 games in the Zero Escape series is a necessity for full enjoyment of this sequel, which are thankfully also available on steam as a single package.

The Zero Escape series are Visual Novels with various Point-and-Click Escape the room puzzles scattered between story sections. 

The difference in artstyle between this and the second game in the series is just as drastic as the difference in artstyle between the first and second, although that is not necessarily a bad thing. You just get used to it after a while but it was definitely jarring for me immediately starting this game right after I finished Virtue's Last Reward.

In Zero Time Dilemma, instead of sprites/models moving in and out of frame all story sections are complete CG animations. However the movements are pretty stiff and the lip syncing in the cinematics are the most atrocious I've seen on a game, even when I switched between English and Japanese voices. You will notice more than once characters speaking when their mouths are not even open.

But after the first hour or so I was able to ignore these problems because I was just so enthralled by how good the story is!

The ending was just as amazing as the first two games and I felt my jaw drop more than once playing through all the routes.

Highly Recommended.

33014536.review:
Truly an interactive masterpiece.

Albeit graphics can be a bit dull at first for newcomers to the series, the core of this game lies in its deep lore, the relationships between the characters, their growth, and how everything ends up connected even if at first, it all looks like it's  random.

It'll certainly keep you around 20-25 hours hooked to your chair, wanting to play more, thinking about what'll happen next, wondering what the answers to some of its riddles will be.

I wasn't expecting ZTD to be nearly as good as Virtue's Last Reward, and for the first few hours I thought it wouldn't surpass it, but as soon as the big events began to pop, and the real mysteries started to make sense, oh boy I just fell in love with it.

This game may not have the most crispy models, or the best animations, but it truly is a masterpiece at what it tries to make, a compelling, addictive and excelent story. I really hope for a 4th game in the series, whenever it happens.

32144699.review:
Zero Time Dillema is a good game, but its the weakest of the entire 999 series.

First off, the puzzle design could use some improvement. The escape rooms have a lot of repeat puzzles. One type of puzzle re-appeared in 4 different escape rooms. It isn't even a particulary interesting type of puzzle. Granted, the 999 series has always had repeated puzzles, but usually you would only see repeats in the final escape room. The real cool feature of hard mode versions of puzzles from VLR is also missing from the game. It was cool to be able to solve a puzzle multiple ways. The game also basically gives you the solution to some puzzles if you don't solve it right away. This is really annoying because some puzzles require you to look at an item in your inventory before you solve it. The game still has some interesting puzzles though.

How the game handles some of its characters is also lacking. Compared to the rest of the series, the character design is really low-key. Part of the 999 series' appeal is the flashy characters, Due to the nature of how the game works, some really unatural characterization is forced on an important character. It doesn't really add up with the character's history, despite how they try and justify it. Furthermore, the character is even made ignorant of knowledge they should know at this point. It also doesn't help that some of the animation is really low quality, so you get some wonky facial expressions from some characters.

Thankfully, the story still has the signature craziness of a 999 game. It certainly goes places. Although it also unfortunately fails to resolve some hanging plot threads from VLR. It does leave an opening for a sequel, but to be honest, I'd be happy if the series ends with this game.

Overall, I did end up enjoying the game a fair amount, so if your a fan of the previous 2 games you should definitely pick it up.

32120927.review:
First of all, let's talk about Zero. In the first game, Zero was a mysterious and intimidating menace. The kind of character who was a man of few words, but every word he spoke had value. The second Zero was the opposite. He was sort of like the Joker, as evil as can be, but yet somehow charming and charismatic. Then we have this Zero... who is honestly so fucking boring I don't even care who it is anymore. He goes on and on and ON in such a monotone voice you will have tuned him out by his second sentence. 

I know the game is a visual novel, and I have no problems with a game that is 90% exposition. But if you are going to have the narrative be your main focus, then that narrative better not suck. This game's dialogue is so bad it made me want to gag.

So how are the characters? They are worse. They are so badly written you can literally define them in 2-3 words. We have the whiney guy, the jerk guy, the over sensitive teen girl, etc. The only character I even found slightly interesting was Carlos, because he is the only one who isn't painfully annoying.

And I understand that they had practically no budget. I am very aware of "Operation Bluebird" and how this game nearly never existed to begin with. But the animation still had no excuse to be this bad. There are single individuals capable of doing BETTER animation using FREE SOFTWARE then what we have here. 

But the worst part... this is an adventure game where you can't explore. You just get knocked out and magically teleport from room to room. Yaaaaaay. Just when you thought it couldn't possibly get any more boring... it gets even more boring.

0/10 Honestly I don't have a single good thing I can say about this game. And that makes me sad, to see a series I love fall so low. Just buy "Zero Escape: The Nonary Games" on steam. It's two games that are infinitely better than this one, and half the price.

32069274.review:
Zero Escape: Zero Time Dilemma est la suite des deux premiers jeux Zero Escape (999 et VLR pour faire court), c'est un jeu de type Visual Novel avec quelques phases d'énigmes qui donnent a réfléchir et qui ne sont pas du tout frustrantes. Il est fortement conseillé d'avoir fait les deux jeux précédents vu qu'on va retrouver les protagonistes de ces deux jeux dans celui ci et que c'est tout simplement la suite des événements des autres jeux. 

Graphiquement c'est très moyen, on a l'impression de se retrouver dans un manga : les personanges sont plutot bien modélisés malgré des décors en basse résolution. Mais c'est surtout aux niveau des animations que le jeu est a revoir, c'est rigide et très iréalistes pour un jeu plutot récent vendu a ce prix la. 

Sa sera surtout coté scénario que le jeu se démarquera, je ne vais pas tellement en parler pour éviter le spoil. On est dans la ligné des deux précédents jeux : beaucoup de choix bien différents dont la plupart seront assez mauvaises (les morts sont d'ailleurs plus travaillés et certaines sont assez horribles). Un scénario bien allambiqué avec différents dénouement et ou on sera obligé de faire toutes les branches possibles pour pouvoir tout comprendre au scénario. On a le droit a quelques réponses aux questions laissé sur VLR mais malheuresement d'autres apparaissent sans pour autant avoir de réponses clairs, voir restent en suspens.

Niveau puzzle on est au niveau de ceux de VLR mais plus simplifié, exit le mode hard et les fichiers supplémentaires a débloquer. Les puzzles sont mieux construits, globalement plus simples (une pièce était assez difficle) et pas du tout frustrant. Il y a beaucoup moins d'objets a gérer par contre l'interface est toujours pas top.

Le jeu est toujours en anglais (bon niveau requis), avec voix anglaises ou japonaises. Les doublages sont très bons en japonais, ils ont repris les doubleurs des jeux précédents. Pas mal de musique sont aussi réprises ce qui ne m'a pas dérangé plus que sa, il y a quelques clins d'oeils aux deux jeux précédents ce qui est plutot sympa.

A faire absolument si vous avez deja fait les deux jeux précédents sinon je déconseillerai de le faire avant 999 qui est mon épisode préféré et VLR. 


Points positifs :

-Un Scénario toujours aussi prenant avec sa logique et avec son lot de surprises.
-Des puzzles bien construits, accessibles et pas du tout frustrant. Pas trop simple non plus, il faut faire preuve d'un minimum d'observation pour trouver les objets et de logique pour sortir des salles.
-Content de retrouver les personnages principaux des deux précédents jeux.


Points négatifs :

-Début un peu maladroit et lent? Sa part un peu dans tout les sens et on ne comrpends pas bien ce qu'il se passe. Il y a beaucoup trop de cinématique pour un début.
-Graphiquement sa n'est pas terrible , les expressions du visage sont assez rigides tout comme les animations. De plus ils n'ont pas gardé le meme visage pour jumpei et Akane, il ne se rapproche pas trop de ceux de 999.
-Synchronisation labiale a la ramasse.
[spoiler]-La fin qui n'en est pas tellement une, sa s'arrete en plein milieu d'une action et laisse clairement présager une suite.[/spoiler]

31658826.review:
Beat the game in 10 minutes, easiest game of my life.

More serious edit now that I've finished:

First off, don't play this if you haven't played the previous two games. It's the third in the trilogy, and it draws heavily on the previous games to tell its story.

Cons:

- Bad presentation and visuals. About what you expect from a 3DS port.

- Game ran out of budget and isn't all it should be. There are some themes clearly unfinished, and some of them would have wrapped up the trilogy nicely. That's not to say it's unifinished to the point that the ending doesn't exist, ala KOTOR 2. It still has a solid end.

- The flowchart from previous games will finally fail you. If you forget what happened during certain scenes, you will end up having to look up what to do after you get stuck, because you won't know exactly where you need to go.

Pros:

- Fantastic storytelling and satisfying conclusion to the franchise. 

- Cuts the tedium out of VLR, which suffered badly from almost identically repeated sections and redundant information, but preserves the thought-provoking questions about morality, science, and philosophy that made VLR stand out from 999, which was mostly occult myths and pseudoscience.

- While hated by some fans, taking the perspective away from a single protagonist and instead giving us a telltale-style 3rd person perspective freed up the game and story to go in different directions.

It ended up being my favorite game in the trilogy in some ways, though all of these games have serious flaws.

简评一下三代游戏：

善人死亡：挖坑作， 不过是我最喜欢的一作。 完全没想到能在999的基础上把世界观和设定展开到那么大，密室一贯高水准， 系统稍微复杂 剧情线显得很乱（玩了零时才发现自己图样了）剧本的话 气氛很好 核心诡计虽然老套但是依然有用，缺点是挖坑太多 没有零时的话这作就显得有点坑了，不过还好最后打越还是把零时做出来了。。。
零时困境：预算不够强行3D 强行全程动画推进剧情导致了画面非常尴尬， 角色的表情动作都非常僵硬。 密室还是一贯很好玩，系统初期看着很混乱， 但是玩久了还好。。。剧情的话完美填下了前代的大坑， 不过为了自圆出现了一些神棍设定，这个肯定是要扣分的（不过讲道理还是比隔壁弹丸未来篇好多了233）
总之 这是一个悬疑AVG爱好者不应该错过的好系列 
打个分
999： 9/10
善人死亡： 8.5/10
零时：7.5/10

- provide a closure to the series
- closes some loose ends in both 999 and vlr
- plenty of plot twists and narrative tricks

The bad:

- some clunkiness in controls (for example, can only click to skip ahead for "text skipping")


(SPOILERS)

Overall, I would still recommend to buy this game if you really enjoyed the nonary games.

[b]La structure scénaristique change beaucoup[/b] par contre, en nous proposant de vivre des parcelles d'histoires dans un ordre totalement déconstruit... un peu comme si vous lisiez un livre avec ses pages de manière totalement random.
Encore une fois, rien n'est du au hasard comme tout jeu Zero Escape, mais c'est certains que ça va en déstabiliser plus d'un...

Tellement qu'il est difficile de parler de Visual Novel pour ce troisième épisode: l'histoire se présentant de manière totalement cinématique, on a plus affaire à un jeu Telltale(avec la même qualité au niveau des animations des persos d'ailleurs...).
Honnêtement, je comprends les quelques critiques concernant cet aspect, mais si vous avez déjà fait 999 et VLR, vous vous sentirez assez vite à la maison... et puis c'est pas comme si vous n'étiez pas contre un peu plus de procédés cryptiques dans la narration, avouez le! :)

L'histoire comme j'ai dit tient ses promesses. La fin notamment: ils ont eu la bonne idée de ne pas terminer sur un cliffhanger(comprendre un "to be continued" frustrant). Elle reste assez ouverte; [b]j'ai cru lire que ça sera le dernier épisode. Si oui, j'ai eu mon compte[/b](y a des passages d’antilogies dans ZTD).

Rien de bien nouveau au niveau des puzzles... enfin en terme de mécaniques je parle.
Cet opus apporte son lot d'easter eggs et de fins en tout genre, ce qui lui assure comme les autres une durée de vie très bonne.

Je salut la cohérence du tout: même si cet opus se passe entre 999 et VLR temporellement parlant, c'est remarquable de voir la façon dont la trilogie a été pensée dès le départ même si 7 ans, dans notre timeline à nous, séparent la sortie de 999 et de ZTD.
------------------------------------------------------------
[h1]TL;DR:[/h1]

+ à la hauteur de l'excellence scénaristique de la série
+ des réponses, oui vous les aurez!
+ toujours nickel niveau puzzles
+ pas mal graphiquement parlant...

- même si les animations sont un peu cheap.
- full anglais/jap comme toujours... dsl pour les anglophobes :P

boss你最后把小狗给杀了你为什么要这样给自己加戏？
埃里克和米拉的全部互动都是在强行加戏。

[h1]把科学 or 科幻彻底玩儿脱[/h1]
星际穿越的剧情知道吧，诺兰在之前的剧情中关于宇宙、时空、黑洞的等等剧情都是请了基普来当顾问的，是有严格科学依据和科学计算的，只有在主角飞到黑洞里才开始打开脑洞跟女儿来了个超时空接触。
极限脱出一代玩儿意识形态场，虽然只是一个科学假说，但是剧情在其假说内部逻辑是通顺的，穿越时空的意识形态场也在合理可接受的脑洞范围内。
二代的世界观与科学观跟一代没有太大差别，只是多了一个叙事诡计而已，也可以接受。
ZTD就不得了了，先是在剧情里面给玩家来一大堆科幻概念，什么睡美人，什么万分之一的概率，什么三门实验的进阶版十门实验，跟主线剧情有关系吗？除了强行打断剧情，逼着玩家查维基百科之外，只能显示剧情创作方面的不足。另外那个可以穿越时间与空间的量子传输器，bug到不能再bug，虽说有十个月CD但是我还是能想出很多改变故事结局的可能。况且打越你不是在剧情里面用了很多量子力学的理论吗，那为啥又要在剧情里面加入一个和量子力学基本理论完全相悖在量子理论体系下根本不可能存在的量子传输器呢。

[h1]最后的结局[/h1]
大家一起跳跃到猜对硬币的世界线哦！
那你是不是亲手杀死了猜对硬币世界线里面原本的自己？

总之三代比起前两代槽点颇多，但是瑕不掩瑜，剧情总体质量在AVG中算优异水品，如果有续作或者新作，我还是会乖乖剁手。
