25262369.review:
Overall: 3/10.
I played the game to 100% completion, attaining all achievments.

TLDR: Horrible animations, terrible dialog, and mediocre puzzle rooms makes this the worst of the three Zero Escape games. I cannot recommend this game to anyone. It's painful to watch, It's painful to listen to the bad voice acting, and the "payoff" at the end of the game felt contrived and flat.

I have loved the prior two Zero Escape games, completing them both 100%. This, however, is not the same quality as the prior two on the 3DS.

Graphics - 3/10 Horrible character 3D animations. There is no motion capture movement here, it's all via stiff animation techniques. It felt like a game from the early 1990's before motion capture was implemented. If a scene is too difficult to animate? Show a picture of the ceiling, or the wall and play a sound effect. Then show the animatronic characters again. The artists did a decent job with most of the models themselves, except with the dead fish-eyes everyone has. The one really bad character model is Mira. She's supposed to look sexy, with her oversized chest. Unfortunately she looks like a teenage boy's drawing of a hooker. Because all of the characters are more cartoon than real, it just looks sad. This cartoon isn't sexy, just comically bad to the point of being unintentionally funny. Overall, I think the game may look better on the low-resolution 3DS vs the PC. The PC just exacerbates the low quality graphics and empty environments.

Sound - 3/10 English voice-overs are beyond cringe-worthy. They don't fit the characters at all. And the dialog doesn't match the emotion, or lack of emotion. Junpei sounds awful, and Zero's English voice is too low to hear. I ended up changing the voice overs to Japanese, who did a great job providing much needed drama, with English subtitles. Sound effects were often amateurish, sounding out of place and just wrong.

Dialog: This has always been a problem with the Zero Escape series. Most of the time the dialog is okay with the occasionally painful banter. This game is mostly cringe-worthy. There are several times when a conversation is hijacked by a character so the science-fiction explanations are presented to the player. It's also common for characters to repeat confirmations to ensure the play knows what to do next. (Yes, you can skip any dialog IF you enable the feature in the options menu.) Eric, one of the most irrational and irritating characters in the game, inspired me to find this solution. Another problem is unnecessary cursing when it didn't make sense. Again, it's an attempt by the developer to sound more mature--only to end up sounding like a 13-year old who's angry with the world.

Gameplay is divided into two styles - story and room escape. Considering how badly the animations were, and how slowly the dialog was going, I often skipped people's dialog. I would then click the Dialog Review button and read it instead. This was much faster, as the pacing sometimes ground to a halt. I really wanted to enjoy the experience and kept looking for a silver lining--I didn't find one. Instead, I simply got bored with it.

The room escapes kept me going. None of the rooms were terribly difficult, though I was hoping for a bigger challenge.

The biggest change for the series is how fragmented the storyline is. It makes sense near the end of the game why it was done this way, but it makes for a very disjointed experience. I didn't care for it. Especially 3/4 of the way through the game--you'll get stuck. The flowchart provided typically shows exclamation marks (!), but there won't be any. Because I don't play "Find the Pixel" to prod a game to continue the gameplay, I checked online. It turned out to be a choice I had not considered.

I feel very let down by this game. I had such a great time with the prior games on the 3DS. The 2D graphics, while basic, were charming and required more of my imagination. The 3D models and environment felt like it was too much for the studio. A feeling that carried into the end of the game.

Speaking of the end of the game... No spoilers here -- The story scene at the end of the game simply stops when you don't expect it. The game then starts rolling the credits that you CANNOT skip. Bad move. Unless you look for them, you'd miss the epilogue notes for the various characters.

As I said at the start of this review: I cannot recommend this game to anyone. It's painful to watch, It's painful to listen to the bad voice acting, and the "payoff" at the end of the game felt contrived and flat. Don't waste your time.

25160618.review:
[b]Short Version:[/b] Answers questions raised by VLR and does nothing more. ZTD is okay, but considering the rest of the series, that's probably the worst thing a Zero Escape title can be.

[b]Long Version:[/b] Unlike the other games in the series, ZTD is not a visual novel. It's a series of long cutscenes, interspersed with the usual puzzle rooms and choices. This method of narrative presentation baffles me, as it essentially removes the charming internal monologue of the POV characters while accentuating just how much standing around and talking there is in these games.

Cutscenes are unskippable when you first view them. Unfortunately, this goes by a fragment-by-fragment basis, so if three fragments have the exact same tutorial cutscene... then you're gonna have to sit through it every single time.

The modular method of storytelling is a huge missed opportunity and only serves to drag down the pacing of the story. The very basics of the scenario have to be repeated in unskippable cutscenes at the beginning of each fragment. Presumably, the meta reason for this was so players wouldn't get confused or feel compelled to play the fragments in a certain order, but after the third time you hear somebody explain the memory wipe drug, you start to see the problem.

There's no incentive to try and make sense of how the timeline fits together, because characters have their memories wiped at the end of nearly every fragment so it ultimately doesn't mean jack shit. It's also blatantly displayed on a flowchart. What could have been a fascinating storytelling lense is instead one of the game's biggest flaws.

I'm not gonna touch on the story's actual content much because I'm trying to keep this spoiler free, but the new characters are nothing interesting, and if you're familiar with the director's work you probably already know what their Character Twists are just by looking at them. Also Junpei's bizarre personality change is so cheesy, it wouldn't be out of place in the film noir episode of Sam & Max.

I am bitter.

Life is simply unfair.

My first 100% completed game, with all the achievements. (I also solved all the puzzles on my own. feel so proud of myself.:)

Conclusion: The ONE BEST puzzle game I've so far played. One of the BEST games I've ever tried.(Haven't played a lot of games anyway.)

I didn't buy the previous two games of this trilogy, nor played them or read about them before, but I DONT really think that this affects the playing expereience. 

Full of blood, betrayals, puzzles, and time travels. This is the largest timeflow chart I've ever seen, with so many decisions and corresponding consequences. really had a great time going through all these pieces of "clips" to find clues of the truth.

The story is fantastic, with all those vivid characters and thrilling plots. As a sci-fi fan, I enjoyed going from a timeline to another, experiencing the "butterfly effect".  I actually solved all the room escapes when my game time reached 18 hours, but end up spending another 10 hours watching those clips, so that I can get the full view of the story. The Biggest Puzzle in this story is not one of those room escapes, but the STORY ITSELF.

The room escapes are challenging yet interesting. Get ready for a hard fight, since a few brain teasers are involved. I enjoyed the sense of satisfactory after each success. 

One thing that makes me feel disappointed is, that I realized that I've spent 20+ hours on this game these days. God I wish I were able to Transport to the past... 12/10.

25011410.review:
It's not often that a game makes me stay awake until I've completed it. This game did just that.

This game most certainly has it's flaws. And were it any other stlye of game I'd probably give it a much lower rating, but this game is a Visual Novel at heart, and we need to remember that it didn't get a huge amount of funding.

Let's talk about the good points first:

STORY:
The story for Zero Excape: Zero Time Dilemma is a continuation of the first two games: 9 Hours 9 Persons 9 Doors (Nintendo DS), and Virtue's Last Reward (Nintendo 3DS and Playstation Vita). 9 people who had initally signed up for a government experiment testing whether people could live on mars or not, are captured by the mysterious "Zero" and forced to Decide whether the result of a coinflip would land on Red or Blue. IF they choose correctly: They free. If they choose incorrectly, though, they have to take part in Zero's Decision game until at least 6 of them are dead.

The story is basically what got me hooked on the game, it's extremely story-driven; as were the previous two games. It does get a little confusing at times though. 9/10

GAMEPLAY/CONTROLS:
The game is more of a Visual Novel with Room Escape sequences every now and again. The controls are what you'd expect from a Room Escape game really, though it seems like it would be much easier to control with a controller. With a mouse I found myself accidentally clicking things when screen transitions happened, or being unable to drag the camera the way I wanted. With a controller those things would be nullified. Also the in game buttons have controller buttons shown on them, but no Keyboard Hotkeys.

There are also times where the game doesn't tell you if you're missing something you need, so you have to either manually search for the part you're missing, or google it.

Overall, it gave me some frustrations every now and then, but nothing major. 8/10

SOUND:
The music in this game is very, very good. It uses the same music from the previous two games, which brings back memories and can make you feel what you felt at those times. They music is also very good at evoking emotions, it's constructed in such a way that when the game wants you to feel tense, happy, sad, etc. You will.

Personally I didn't try out the English voice acting, as usually it's fairly bad. English speaking people never seem to get inflections correct, and things that should sound one way end up sounding really cartoony, or just completely different. I may try out a few scenes with the english language on just to update this review, but it's not certain. As for the Japanese voice acting, I can't fault it really. A lot of the words that are said are in English though, and Japanese pronunciation of English words can be pretty lackluster. The subtitles also don't help, as they're subtitling the English dialogue, not the Japanese dialogue. This means that some translations are incorrect, and the way you read something might be said and toned completely differently.

Overall, the music is amazing, as is the japanese dialogue, held back only by English words and the subtitling. 9/10

GRAPHICS:
The graphics in this game are fairly basic. The character models have obviously been worked on harder, or longer that the rest of the game models, they feel somewhat out of place at times when compared with their surroundings, or other 3D aspects/items. A lot of the textures look (and are) flat in a lot of cases, which leads to some things looking slightly weird and low rez.

The animation in the game is.. pretty bad. The characters move stiffly, or not at all, and the lip synching is terrible in both Japanese and English languages. it never quite matches what the characters are saying. The animations basically just feel very rushed.

Overall, I'd say the game lookes fine visually. The animations are sometimes painful to watch and the textures look flat and drab. 5/10

In conclusion, despite it's flaws I think it's a great game, especially so if you've played the two previous.

In total I'd score this game 85/100

24980786.review:
Well, it's the third Zero Escape game.  In case you haven't played the past games, it's still the same basic premise as the first two games of the series: You and 8 other people find yourself locked in a building, playing a game being run by someone calling themselves "Zero".  Much like Saw, (with Zero mimicking the role of Jigsaw, obviously) this game has many deadly "traps" in it, which you must avoid while solving puzzles.  However, the Zero Escape series turns this into a sort of visual novel/choose your own adventure game, with cryptic riddles and puzzles in the style of escape-the-room games.  Combine this with a story containing time-travel, moral dilemmas, and stange science and psycology tidbits, and you get this...  But is it good?

The first two games?  Absolutely.  The third game, Zero Time Dilemma?  Not so much.

I don't know where this whole "you can play this game without playing the first two" mentality is coming from.  Having played all three in order, I can tell you that's absolutely false.  I mean yeah, you can [i] technically [/i] play them out of order, but you can also [i] technically [/i] watch the seasons of Breaking Bad out of order too.  That doesn't make it better, though.  The other two games will be coming to Steam though (although nobody knows when), and I HIGHLY recommend them, regardless of whether you play this one or not.  I'd wait to purchase this until playing both of those.

However, if you've already played those, or if you really just don't care about order, then I'd still wait until purchasing this.  Why?  Well, here's the pros and cons...

Pros:
-Voice acting is good, for the most part.  There are some parts where it doesn't quite work, but overall it's okay.
-Puzzle design is, again, good for the most part.  Yes, just like the voice acting, the puzzles have some good and bad elements.  They aren't as hard as "Virtue's Last Reward"s puzzles, but definitely more difficult than 999's.  Some of them are just downright confusing, though.  Hopefully you like converting between base-10 and base-13...  If you don't know what that means, you're gonna have trouble.
-References to past games.  Maybe there's too much of it, but it's nice to check up on characters and see what they've been up to.

Not too many pros, but now it's time for now..

Cons:
-Plot.  It's all over the place.  I get what they were going for, but it feels less like the past games and more like The Matrix.  And not in a good way.
-Music.  I think almost all of it was reused.  If there were any new tracks, I barely noticed them, which I think speaks for itself.  I'm not saying the music in here was bad, but it's not used well.
-Animation.  This is a big one.  If you don't like how the trailers look, you'll like it even less when you get in the game.  Animations are stiff and clunky, and at times they're outright laughable.  Not exactly what you want to go for when you're trying to portray a deep story.  I have no idea why they went with this style over what they had in the past.
-Characters.  Two of them are inherently unlikeable [spoiler] (Eric and Mira) [/spoiler] and the rest are either one-dimensional, or returning characters from past games.  They don't get along well, either.  Plus, you don't get to really ever see them interact with each other, since for 95% of the game, they're stuck in groups of 3.

And now the big one:
-Structure.

It's rare a game has such trouble structurally.  Normally, a game just tells you its story, and then everyone happily moves on.  But noooooo...  not ZTD.  ZTD uses the "fragment" system, and WOW it's a mess.  (Again, why couldn't they just use what they already had!?)  Instead, the 9 characters are split into 3 groups of 3, and each group has their own screen of seperate "fragments", in which you play through the story somewhat anachronistically. In a fragment, you see the teammates of your choice go through a puzzle, make a choice in a "decision game", and then have their memories wiped and you get booted out back to the fragment selection screen.  Oh, what's that?  You're confused as to why their memories get wiped?  Yep, me too.  I understand why after beating the game, but only slightly.  Plus, the game introduces and explains this concept about as well as I just did here in this review.  In fact, I probably did it better.

However, the BIGGEST problem?  It's the decision game.  Most of them take the form of a moral dilemma or probablity theory question.  For example, one decision game asks you if you want to shoot a gun with a 50% chance of firing at one character, in order to save another.  Another game requires you to know how the monty hall problem works.  However, tell me this...  How can your choices mean anything if you can simply reset and try again, until you get the result you want?  The game tries its best to make you feel bad for certain choices, but ultimately it can't, because it never locks you into anything.  Plus, you pretty much have to see all the results of all the choices anyways, so at the end of it all it basically becomes meaningless.  "Oh, sure, this character died and now I'm being framed as a murderer, but it doesn't matter because I had to make this choice anyways to move the story along."

Speaking of moving the story along...  There was one point I got stuck because I didn't do some specific thing in the beginning of the game.  Actually, I HAD done it, but it didn't count because I didn't do it the specific way it wanted.  And there was no clue I needed to do this either, no mention that it would change anything.  If anything, I had been given evidence that it [i] wouldn't [/i] change anything.  I ended up using a walkthrough to figure this out, but I didn't use it for any other part of the game.  For those curious, the part was [spoiler] voting each team off in the decontamination rooms [/spoiler]

Overall, the story just doesn't come together in a good way.  It resembles something more of an action movie, like The Matrix, or X-Men or something.  It doesn't feel satisfying, and just leaves you with a sour feeling at the end of all of it.

Sorry, but I wouldn't recommend this.  It just doesn't feel right.  I WOULD however recommend:
-The first game, "9 Hours, 9 Persons, 9 Doors".  Currently on the Nintendo DS, but it should hopefully come to Steam in not too long.  Pick it up then.
-The second game, "Zero Escape: Virtue's Last Reward".  Currently on Nintendo 3ds, and PS Vita, but should also come to Steam sometime.  I can't recommend this one higher.  It's fantastic.

"It's time for the Decision Game.  Will you purchase Zero Time Dilemma, or will you not?"
Whichever you choose, I hope the outcome is favorable to you.

24914397.review:
强烈推荐！！！！（本条评论不会涉及这一作的剧透，但是会涉及到前两作，剧透处会用黑条打码。）


[h1]关于游戏[/h1]
这是一个非常值得一玩的解密游戏，游戏性强，这里不多说，推荐看官方的简介，多说一句都是剧透。顺带一说，本人没有玩过前两作，是通过好友才知道这个游戏的，并且第一次接触这个游戏也是在Steam平台上，玩了十几个小时后斟酌之下我决定慎重地写评论+安利这个游戏。


[h1]适合人群[/h1]
解密爱好者 硬/软科幻爱好者 科幻迷 推理迷 （初上手也没关系，可以看攻略慢慢来，相信这个游戏会让你爱上的）


[h1]一些科普[/h1]（非打码处不涉及剧透）
-[b]量子力学-纠缠态[/b]（这个定理游戏没有明确提出来，但是我还是想把它放在第一个，认为理解这个对于理解游戏剧情/世界线有帮助）
定义（摘自百度百科，有改动）：量子纠缠是粒子在由两个或两个以上粒子组成系统中相互影响的现象。这种现象是关于量子力学理论最著名的预测。它描述了两个粒子互相纠缠，即使相距遥远距离，一个粒子的行为将会影响另一个的状态。当其中一颗被操作（例如量子测量）而状态发生变化，另一颗也会即刻发生相应的状态变化。
一下子在这篇评论里解释这一个量子力学的理论似乎有点解释不过来，有兴趣的旁友想知道详情可以自行搜索一下各大网站，我这里就说一些和游戏相关的和自己的理解好了，这条不剧透，只是讲理论，就不打码了。
量子纠缠是一种量子力学现象，一对同种条件下产生的粒子，其中一个受到影响对另一个也有跨越时间、跨越空间的影响。虽然游戏中没有提到，但我觉得量子纠缠可以解释游戏中的很多现象，比如形态形成场。
-[b]量子力学-叠加态[/b]
既然谈到量子纠缠，就不免想多说一下量子叠加。就通过一个例子解释得简单明了一点吧：
Perh（一种少量放射性物质）和Baosas（一只喵）关在一个盒子里，有50%的概率放射性物质将会衰变并释放出毒气杀死Baosas，同时有50%的概率放射性物质Perh不会衰变而Baosas将活下来。在你把盒子关上后你是不知道Perh有没有衰变把Baosas弄死掉，那么Baosas的下场有两种可能，一种是被Perh*掉，一种是没被Perh*掉，要知道结果，就必须打开箱子，在你打开箱子前，这两种可能的状态是叠加的，就是说Baosas的状态是“被Perh*”和“没被Perh*”的叠加，但当你打开箱子，只会看到Baosas“被Perh*”或“没被Perh*”，但不可能看到这两种状态的叠加。因此只要观测，叠加态就不复存在。
游戏中有涉及这个理论相关的地方，但没有明确提及这个理论，玩过游戏后推荐自行仔细科普一下“量子叠加”，还是很有趣的。
-[b]形态形成场[/b]
[u]“形态形成场”理论重点[/u]：
一旦形成“形态形成场"，其传播就可以跨越空间与时间的界限。换句话说，只要有“形态形成场”存在，就可能在瞬间影响到其他地方，这也可以算做是世界瞬息万变的一种。
通俗易懂地说，就是只要同样的事情发生过几次之后，就会形成事件的"形象之场"，而只要和这个"形象之场"产生共鸣，同样的事情就能再度发生。这里所谓的"形象之场"，并非一种能量所传达的信息之类的东西，而是与家装的室内设计图有点儿类似。
这一个理论是现实有的，而游戏将这一理论稍微篡改了一下[spoiler]，并且在这一理论的基础上才衍生了一代的剧情，茜和淳平通过形态形成场跨越时空交流，茜在一代里因9年后的淳平帮助而得救。[/spoiler]
[u]形态形成场的特征总结[/u]:
1.无论生物和物质，都可以不经介质或传媒改变形态或行为思维
2.相同情景或是相似度极高，具有一定共性的二者会相互影响。
-[b]抽象画理解实验/老鼠寻路实验[/b]
这两项实验也确有其事，只不过游戏中稍有修改，修改不大，这里便以游戏设定为事例
1.抽象画实验：有贵妇形象和小型犬形象的抽象画，猜中贵妇形象大概是7%左右，猜中小型犬形象的仅有3%。一周后，电视台便在本国范围内播放答案和讲解；后来又找到了完全没看过节目的外国人，猜中小型犬形象的几率提升了一半。
2.老鼠实验：有两条路的简单迷宫，一个暗无光亮、一个有光但通电。一开始老鼠先通往有光的出口，被电后才折返。第二只老鼠一开始也是通往有光的出口，被电后折返。随着实验的进行，一开始选择阴暗出口的老鼠越来越多。
这里表现了形态形成场的第三个特点：“不仅仅是物质形态，生物的行为也会受到影响”。游戏中给出了一个可怕的推测，由此来“影响并控制全世界人的行为”。
-[b]SHIFT[/b]
个人理解就是意识穿越。
-[b]Redical-6[/b]（本条为自己依据剧情总结的）
游戏虚构的一种病毒，致死率75%，它名字的由来是因为它的第一个症状是让被感染者失去对时间的知觉，让被感染者的思维的一秒变成根号六（Redical-6）秒。而它的第二个症状，同时也是真正的致命症状是使被感染者有一个极为强烈的想自杀的愿望。（这个病毒的致死的重要原因个人理解是因为它拖累了大脑处理信息的速度。由于大脑处理信息的速度受此病毒影响而减慢，但同时又在接受外界的信息，大脑处理速度跟不上外界信息的接受速度，导致感染者有强烈自杀的愿望）
传播性很强，能通过体液、水等介质传播[spoiler]，由Free the Soul组织研发（我推测），传闻第一次出现在2028年12月，在二代的时间线上导致了世界60亿人口的死亡，但组织创始人的理由却是……（在本作中会有解释）[/spoiler]
-[b]FBR[/b]
好像说了就剧透了……开头承诺就算黑码也不剧透本作剧情www
-[b]Axelavir[/b]
第二作善人必死中出现的Redical-6的解毒剂。[spoiler]Axelavir是在2038年由一名R6病毒感染者体内提取的抗体制成的解药，其生产主要是利用IG复制机。[/spoiler]然而，即使在被治疗后，一些症状还会将持续一段时间。

24866443.review:
This game is great. It is, but please, PLEASE do not play it without having played the second one, or at least watched a let's play of it. All 3 are connected, and while you can play each one separately, you miss out a lot, especially on this one. A LOT.
The first one, 999, is great as well, but for me virtue's last reward is the best game I've ever played and is a must if you're going to play this one. I'm sure the emotions you'll go through once you see or realise some of the plot twists cannot be compared to what you'll feel if you've played the last game.(that goes for all of the series. Fingers crossed they're already working on making the other 2 available on steam at some point)

About the game itself now, it has a few small flaws but was generally great. Compared to the previous one, which I consider a masterpiece, the puzzles are not as challenging(I have to say, there are too many hints, I'd rather have the option to choose easy/hard and be able to figure more stuff alone), yet some were still pretty interesting, the plot was weird, but it was again pretty well written. One thing that felt bad was the duration of the game, it was quite shorter than the previous one. The animation also felt strange.

The series' main characteristics, though, are there. An amazing story, with many plot twists, well written(although with one... strange, questionable part. Just one though), cool puzzle rooms and really interesting characters. The (unique) flow of the game was REALLY interesting and I loved it. I also love how the story blends in with the previous games. 
A bit overpriced, but I did not regret buying it at all.

Generally, I enjoyed the game a lot and I am definitely waiting for the next one.

24817520.review:
Eh, it's just another anime-styled "visual novel".

The way it's presented, you might think has some element of "room escape puzzle" to it, but not really.
You make choices at key intersections of the story, which may or may not lead you to some clues that you can make use of in another branch. That's it for the "puzzle factor".
It also leads to the entire game unfolding in a disjointed and uncompelling manner, since it becomes more about unlocking each branch of the story on a flowchart instead of an investment in what's actually happening.
This is by design though, as the story itself makes it a point to show you how nothing really matters since the characters can just jump between timelines until they get their desired outcome, just like the player is doing when going back to an intersection to pick the other choice.
The entire thing feels gimmicky and comes off more as a way to "break the meta".

That's also as much as I can say about the actual game.
Your appreciation of this as a "visual novel" is gonna depend entirely on how much you enjoy anime tropes.
I, personally, don't - and I was bored with it quite fast as a result.
It's teenage pulp along the lines of what you'd expect from a comic book, which is certainly perfectly within the bounds of target demographic. A lot of people obviously like it, but it's just not for me.

24801671.review:
Please play 999 and Virtue's Last Reward before this one, things will make more sense that way, and you'll meet some familiar characters. I hope they'll get worthy ports somewhere down the line! If you liked the previous games, play this one, definitely.

The game, as a whole, was for me a satisfying continuation of the Zero Escape series (and presumably the last one). The graphics were beautiful, but the animation left something to be desired. The puzzles felt a bit easy and repetitive compared to earlier instalments (you didn't have to think too much, most of the time you found the answers lying around somewhere). Familiar music was applied well at key points in the game, but sadly it seemed there wasn't much new music.

There's some mind blowing things in the story, and then others you'll have a difficult time wrapping your head around. I liked the characters and their personal surprises. I just wish that more references would have been made to 999 and VLR, there were some key concepts in those that weren't even mentioned. I really miss the old characters, I'd love to know what happened to them. uchikoshi pls

tl;dr: The game has some weak spots, but overall it's an interesting play for a Zero Escape fan.

24799950.review:
Zu allererst: Ich habe die ersten beiden Teile von Zero Escape (999 & Virtue's Last Reward) nicht gespielt. Dieses Spiel hat mich allerdings dazu gebracht, das auf jeden Fall nachholen zu wollen, sobald diese auf dem PC erscheinen.


Zur Story:
Die Handlung beginnt damit, dass neun Charaktere in einer Zelle aufwachen und vom "großen Bösen" mit einer Vorliebe für Latein zu einem Spiel herausgefordert werden. Bereits hier wird die Wichtigkeit getroffener Entscheidungen klar.
Schließlich beginnt ein grausames Spiel. Die Charaktere werden in drei Gruppen a drei Personen aufgeteilt und in getrennten Bunkern untergebracht. Die einzige Möglichkeit, zu entkommen: Es müssen sechs Leute sterben. So werden die Charaktere durch unterschiedliche, teils sehr gefährliche Situationen gejagt, bis wieder ein Fragment abgeschlossen ist.
Ein Fragment? Richtig gelesen. Die Story wird nicht linear erzählt, sondern in einzelnen Schnipseln, bei denen man zuerst nicht weiß, was vorher geschehen ist. Da den Charakteren regelmäßig die letzten Ereignisse aus dem Gedächtnis gelöscht werden, sind auch sie erst einmal ratlos. Wenn allerdings ein Fragment mal nur mit zwei statt drei Charakteren startet, beginnt man schon mit einem gewissen Kloß im Hals.
Dabei wären wir auch schon bei der Stimmung und egal welche Stimmung das Spiel vermitteln will, es schafft es recht gut. Der Soundtrack ist gut, die Charaktere vielleicht optisch nicht für jeden was, aber die Gespräche und Gedanken führen einen gut in die Psyche der einzelnen Charaktere, sei es nun der zynische Junpei, der labile Eric oder das seltsame Kind mit Amnesie.
Noch etwas abschließendes zur Story: Für den Verlauf der sehr verzweigten Story ist es wichtig, dass dem Spieler am Anfang Informationen vorenthalten werden oder er sogar zu falschen Schlüssen verleitet wird. Gerade im letzten Drittel häufen sich Enthüllungen und Twists und es wird ein tieferer Sinn hinter dem grausamen Spiel klar.


Zum Gameplay:
Streng genommen gibt es drei Arten von Spielsituationen.

1. Filmsequenzen:
Hierbei handelt es sich um animierte Sequenzen, die die Story und oder/Situation erläutern. Da das Spiel für den 3DS gemacht wurde, sind sie grafisch natürlich nicht der Knüller, aber wer sich nicht an staksigen Anime-Charakteren in Cell Shading Optik stört, der wird mit zum Teil sehr spannenden und emotionalen Momenten konfrontiert.

2. Escape Room:
Jepp, genau das, wonach es klingt. Häufig steckt die gerade gesteuerte Gruppe irgendwo fest und muss versuchen, sich aus ihrer Lage zu befreien und beispielsweise den Raum zu verlassen oder neue Interaktionsmöglichkeiten zu finden. Dabei sind die Rätsel manchmal etwas verwirrend, aber mit genügend logischem Denken recht gut lösbar.

3. Entscheidungen:
Der wohl essentielle Bestandteil der Story. Meist durch eine Sequenz eingeleitet, wird vom Spieler häufig eine Entscheidung verlangt. Oft sind diese sehr binär, wie die Frage, ob man einen Knopf drücken soll oder nicht. Allerdings gibt es auch Punkte, an denen drei oder mehr Entscheidungen möglich sind. Außerdem sind viele Entscheidungen sehr emotional aufgeladen. Riskiere ich, meinen eigentlich sicheren Gefährten umzubringen, um meine sonst sicher tote Freundin zu retten? Wen greife ich in einer Gefahrensituation an oder versuche ich sogar, eine friedliche Lösung zu finden?
Allerdings lässt sich nicht jede Entscheidung ohne Vorwissen treffen. An einigen Stellen werden Codes verlangt, die erst an anderen Stellen der Story auftauchen oder Namen, die man normalerweise noch nicht kennen kann. Es sei dabei auch gesagt, dass die Story dennoch halbwegs logisch erklärt, warum die Charaktere auf einmal die nötige Info haben.


Wem würde ich das Spiel nicht empfehlen:
-Leute, die keine langwierigen Rätsel im Stil klassischer Adventures mögen
-Grafikfanatiker
-Menschen, die zu zart besaitet sind, und mit psychisch belastenden Situationen nicht gut klarkommen
-Leute, die immer Knöpfe drücken müssen und lange Sequenzen nicht abkönnen

Wem würde ich das Spiel empfehlen:
-Liebhaber von Adventures und vertrakten Handlungen
-Leute, die kein Problem mit etwas unbeholfener Animation haben, solange die Story gut ist
-Jedem, der Szenen mag, die wirklich an die Nieren gehen
-Filmliebhaber, denn häufig arten Zwischensequenzen in eine Art Kurzfilm aus

24773564.review:
TL:DR = If you like the Saw movies, you'll enjoy this game as well
Now for the long version.  I never played the previous two games in this series and so it was harder to get into the story then I assume it would have been otherwise.  [b]MORPHOGENETIC FIELD!!![/b]  I did not understand why the designers would have the story jump around like it does; eg from one "history" where people may be dead that your choices should not have caused to jumping forwards and backwards in the timeline.  All I can say is; trust that this is NOT the game "not saving your decisions" and there is purpose to it all.  I do believe they could have improved the experience; maybe by showing exactly where each fragment lay on the timeline BEFORE playing through it, but irregardless I greatly enjoyed this title and fully recommend it to anyone who liked the Saw movies.
I do have three additional warnings however.
1) The price tag is a bit steep for what you get at $40, I'd suggest waiting for it to go on sale first
2) The first section of the game is a bit slow and repetitive - stick with it, and do not be afraid to make bad choices - you'll be able to change them later
3) DO NOT cheat and look at the passwords guide until the very end or you saw the password in your playthrough but forgot it - those road blocks are there to make you experience the other sections before coming back with the correct answers

24771729.review:
Chances are, if you're looking at buying this game, then you have already been part of this cult following since the first or second game. If however, you are new to the series, I strongly suggest playing through the seond title, Virtues Last Reward before playing this game. (The first game in the series really doesnt have much bearing, except for two characters, but even then it doesnt mean much). 
     Coming from my own personal experience with the previous two titles in the series, I would say that the puzzles are a little less difficult than Virtues Last Reward, and though certain story beats really had me invested while i tried to piece together the narrative, the ending was very lackluster considering this game is supposed to wrap up the series. Animations and voice acting are as cringy as the trailer shows, but it makes up for it with thoughtful dialogue.
     I have been eagerly anticipating this game for over three years and even supported Project Bluebird (petition to make publishers fund Zero Time Dilemma), so despite minor gripes about the game, I'm so glad I found this series and stuck with it to the end. It will probably never get the recogniton it derserves, but it's a gem for sure.

24765307.review:
Zero Time Dilemma isn't quite as good as 999, but it still is a great game. The puzzles are generally a bit easier than the ones in VLR, but they feel more robust and none of them really stands out as bad. (I'm looking at you, VLR pantry's ice cube puzzle...)

The music is absolutely stunning, and the game looks good on the graphical side of things. However, the character animations were really poor. Voice acting is good, though.

If I had to rate it, I'd say the game gets an 8/10 from me. Please note, though, that my standards are very high!

24758051.review:
A very unique and fullfilling game, Zero Escape: Zero Time Dilemma puzzles' are well-designed and extremely fullfilling to solve. In addition to the puzzles, as a bonus the game has unique way of story-telling: where you can pick and choose which fragment of the various timelines to play and they need not be played in order.

Despite this game being chronologically a prequel to Virtual's Last Reward, you should defintely play the first two games first to better understand the storyline. This is of course granted if you are playing mostly for the story since this game will fill in plot holes from the previous two games.

Overall, a really great 20-hour game with excellent story-telling and puzzles, easily worth the $39 (which i defintely did not regret paying full price for LUL)

24745627.review:
Zero Escape is an outstanding series comprised of themes and ideas beyond that of the average video game. 

Zero Time Dilemma is no exception, as the game is cleverly structured with various mysteries that leave the player wondering the reasons behind it all. 


While advancing through the story, the player can switch between 3 groups of characters as they are forced to play a perilous game of life or death.

- The characters all have unique personalities and I didn't find myself avoiding  a specific team.


This time around, the player can pick which "fragment" of the story they want to complete for each of the teams.

- Although the very nature of the game can create confusion, the in game flowchart keeps things organized as you progress throughout the story.


Additionally there are puzzles within the game that encourage the player to search around and think about, but luckily there is a built in notepad to jot important information down. 

- The puzzles are well designed and fun, however there are some difficult puzzles that the player will encounter.


If you have not already experienced the first two games in the series, I highly recommend doing so before diving into Zero Time Dilemma. It is best enjoyed as a sequel and not as an entry to the series.

24742838.review:
爆机之后就来评价啦！

非常棒的游戏！
剧情真心没话说！基本上收了上一部的所有线索，然而感觉还是私心留了个小尾巴。
虽然据说这一部非常可能是该系列的终结作，然而还是希望会有下一部啦╰(*°▽°*)╯

接下来说说正经评论(我已经尽量说的不涉及剧透了，但是！可能会涉及剧透！还是要提醒一下大家）
1、 叙事方式（SHIFT及主角人数）
    在上一部极限脱出中，SHIFT可以说是相当出彩的设定。由于SHIFT这一设定的存在使原本单调唯一路线的解密变得灵活多变。这种多变使得剧情虽然会有各种结局，但是你仍然感受到所有事情的发展有个大方向，可以说是多而不乱的同时可以了解整个事件始末。另外SHIFT的存在也省去了一般视觉小说中必须重头来过以获得新结局的重复劳动的无力感，对于我这种比较没有耐心的人来说是简直就是救命啊！
    上述一切都基于唯一主角这一关键设定！！！！
    然而在最新一部里，沿用SHIFT的主角变成了三位，这对不了解过往剧情的新人来说，就不太友好了。例如，某些习惯以一个个主角视角玩的人，在某些decision game里是被卡住，无法继续玩下去的，这个时候你必须每个角色做出一次选择，才能解开新的剧情；以及某些习惯在遇到decision game的时候把所有选项都选一遍，再继续下一个剧情的，接下来的剧情发展就会显得混乱不堪。显然编剧也考虑到了上述问题，引进了fragment的操作方式，然而我在玩的时候仍然觉得很混乱。这种操作方式只能说从某一程度上减轻了混乱，然而效果个人感觉不是特别理想。想要讲清楚三位主角SHIFT的故事，对于目前的表现手法上还是显得比较吃力的。我得说，这是个很勇敢的尝试，而然结果只能just so so。 ┑(￣Д ￣)┍

2、 密室逃脱
    本作的密室逃脱比上一部来说简单了一些，整体来说还是属于中上的难度吧。不会说卡在某一点上死活过不去，各个房间的解密方式逻辑性很强（这点让我赞到爆！），角色们的提醒有的时候会非常明显。同时，本作中有一间房间（pod room）的解密相当新颖，非常好评！我建议：不是经常玩解密游戏的朋友完全可以尝试不要看攻略玩。

3、 剧情
    因为是科幻类剧情，可能会觉得有点扯，然而蕴含在其中的道德dilema还是挺值得深思的。 [spoiler]这是一部看似有多个时间线，然而事实上回到过去仍然无法改变结局的故事。 [/spoiler]虽然编剧说会对玩家的三观造成相当的冲击，然而我在爆机之后觉得，基本上所有的黑暗都是情理之中，不会特别惊讶。结局可以说，让人恨得牙痒痒啊……但是还是充满光明和希望的。
    [spoiler]玩完极限脱出2就站Phi和Sigma的cp的人！SUCK THAT BABY!!!![/spoiler]

This game... Where to begin.
It is important to note that this is the third game in the Zero Escape series!

24686711.review:
I just started this game today and I have to say, right now, these are the worst character animations I've seen in my life. Stiff, awkward, so bad it ruins the tone of every scene, and the camera frequently cuts to the ceiling to avoid having to animate the characters doing stuff like falling, picking up objects, etc. Basically the characters can only stand ramrod straight, move their limbs back and forth stiffly, and flap their lips in a way that vaguely looks like talking. No idea why anyone thought this would be better than the visual novel style of 999 and vlr.

Honestly I don't care how great the story turns out to be, and yeah, so far it's super fun and has interesting puzzles, but I can't let anyone pay forty bucks for this mess. I don't regret buying the game, just the price tag for a game with such a glaring flaw; if you can stand to wait, buy this on sale.

24680190.review:
Einfach nur Wow! Eines der schönsten Entscheidungs- und Puzzlespiele!
Die Spieleentwickler haben hier eine wirklich gute Arbeit geleistet!

Die geschichtliche Umsetzung ist einfach der Wahnsinn.  Nach fast jedem Fragment wird der Spieler neu überrascht.
Durch das Aufstellen von Vermutungen über den weiteren Ablauf des Spiels bleibt die Spannung sehr hoch.
Das Spielmenü ist anfangs etwas seltsam, jedoch gewöhnt man sich daran. 
Bei einigen Rätseln kann es nicht schaden einen Zettel und Stift zur Hand zu haben.

Grafisch könnte das Spiel noch etwas verbessert werden. Vorallem die Bewegungen der Figuren wirken in manchen Szenen ziemlich unrealistisch. 
Zero Escape bindet durch die Handlung so sehr, dass auch auf niedrigsten Grafikeinstellungen der Spaß nicht verloren geht.

Für das Spiel müssen gute Englisch Kenntnisse vorhanden sein, damit auch jedes Detail verstanden werden kann und der Spieler problemlos durch die Rätsel kommt. 

Leider hat auch dieses Spiel irgendwann ein Ende.

24672693.review:
Bu yapım için olumlu bir değerlendirme bırakmamam mümkün değil. Bu inceleme de tamamen bunun için ama size hikaye ile ilgili gerçekten bir şeyler anlatmadan bu serinin nasıl tanıtımı yapabilirim diye de düşünmeden edemiyorum. Bu konuda elimden geleni yapacağım, yani spoiler endişesi içermedem okuyabilirsiniz burda yazanları. Ancak aynı zamanda bu yazının size çok fazla şey anlatmama ihtimali de var, bu yüzden bir alttaki notumu okuyup geri kalan metinlere hiç bulaşmayabilirsiniz.

ÖNEMLİ NOT: Öncelikle bu oyunun tek bir oyun olduğu yanılgısına düşüp, bunu alıp doğrudan oynama hatasını yapmayın. Bu bir üçlemenin son oyunu ve önceki oyunları bitirmeden bunu oynamanın hiçbir anlamı olmaz. (Çünkü aynı evrende geçen farklı hikayeler tarzını işleyen bazı oyunların aksine bu oyun, ilk iki oyundan gelen soru işaretlerini sonlandırıp hikayeyi belli bir noktaya ulaştırıyor. Diğer bir deyişle bu üç yapım tam bir uyum içinde, biri olmadan geri kalan ikisini anlamak çok zor.)

Seriye yabancı olanlar için bundan önce oynamaları gereken oyunlar sırasıyla:
1- 9 Hours, 9 persons, 9 doors
2- Virtue's Last Reward
3- Zero Escape: Zero Time Dilemma

Spesifik olarak bu oyuna değinmeden önce genel olarak serinin nasıl bir yapıda olduğundan bahsedeyim. Visual novel tabirine aşina olanlar bilir, japonların görsel ve işitsel verilerden de faydalanarak, bazen sizin seçimlerinize göre şekil alan bazen sadece baştan sona okuduğunuz hikayeleridir bunlar, diğer bir deyişle görsel roman. Bu seride de ağır olarak bir görsel roman havası bulunduğunu söyleyebilirim. Her oyunda birçok seçimle karşı karşıya kalıyorsunuz, her seçim sizi belli bir noktaya ulaştırıyor, ANCAK tüm hikayeyi anlamak ve gerçek sona ulaşmak için tüm bu sonları almanız gerekiyor. Diğer bir deyişle bu "ah, bu endingi açtım oyun bitti" dediğiniz türden bir yapım değil, "ah bu endingi açtım geriye x kadar ending kaldı" dediğiniz bir oyun.

Bu özelliğine ek olarak bu yapım çeşitli bulmacalar da içeriyor; tamamı odadan kaçış teması üzerine kurulu olan bulmacalar. Bu bulmacaların oranını düşünürsek sanırım azdan çoğa Zero Escape: Zero time dilemma, 9 hours, 9 persons, 9 doors ve virtue's last reward olarak sıralayabilirim. (Bundan emin değilim ama gerçekten vlr'de çok fazla bulmaca bulunduğunu, bundaysa fazla az bulmaca olduğunu hissettim oynarken. Belki de bu oyun çok akıcı olduğundan bana öyle gelmiştir?)

Az çok ne tür bir oyun serisiyle karşı karşıya olduğunuzu anlattım, bu oyunu bu kadar güzel kılan şey ise mükemmel hikayesi ve bu hikayeyi sunuş şekli. Her bir oyunu bolca plot twist içeren bu yapım sürekli sizi şaşırtmaya, anladığınızı sandırıp aslında hiçbir şey anlamamış olduğunuzu yüzünüze vurmaya bayılıyor. Her yapımda gerçek sona ulaşana kadar sürekli olarak bir gizem içinde kalıyorsunuz ve bu sunum beni etkilemeyi gerçekten başardı. Bu oyunun öyle bir yapısı var ki; bu hikayeyi bir anime serisi veya film şeklinde anlatmak isteseniz emin olun bu kadar güzel sunmanız mümkün değil.

Ve genel olarak bu son oyuna dönersek, ilk iki oyunda başlayan kurguyu gerçekten çok güzel tamamlıyor. Bir önceki oyunla bağlantısı olan ve burda göreceğimi umduğum tek bir olayı bana göstermemiş olsa da, geri kalan her şeyi önceki oyunlarla çok güzel bağlayıp, anlaşılmayan noktaları aydınlattı. Önceki oyunlar dediğim gibi daha çok visual novel havasındayken bu oyun baştan sona animasyon içeriyor, yani sizin seçiminizle ilerleyen metinlerden ziyade karşınızda cinematicler var.

Benim kesinlikle sorun etmediğim ama bazı kişilerin kötü görebileceğini düşündüğüm yanıysa, dediğim gibi bana çok fazla puzzle varmış gibi gelmedi bu yapımda, bunu da şu yüzden diyorum, bu oyunda geçirdiğiniz sürenin çoğunda sadece bazı sahneleri seçip o sahnelerin size anlattıklarını izlemekle yetiniyorsunuz. Bazı noktalarda size seçim veriliyor, o seçimin sonucunu görüyor sonra seçim anına geri dönüp diğer seçimlerin sonuçlarını kontrol ediyorsunuz. Bu izlediğiniz sahnelere göre de bazı noktalarda kilitli olan bölümler açılmaya devam ediyor, ve oyun size bu şekilde içerikleri belli bir sistemle sunmaya devam ediyor.

Peki tüm bunları anlattıktan sonra genel olarak ne düşündüğüme gelirsek: yukardan da anladığınıza eminim aslında; hikayesi, bu hikayeyi sunma şekli, karakterleri ve dünyasıyla çok keyif alarak takip ettiğim; kesinlikle bu serinin arkasındaki ismin gelecekteki diğer çalışmalarını da aynı heyecanla takip edeceğim bir seriydi bu. Yavaş yavaş açılan gizem hikayelerini, odadan kaçış bulmacalarını ve plot twistleri seviyorsanız ve bolca metin okumayı sorun etmiyorsanız kesinlikle bu seriye bir şans vermeniz gerek, pişman olmazsınız. Aynı zamanda bunlar size pek bir şey hitap etmiyorsa fazla yaklaşmanızı önermem, çünkü bu yapım başka bir şey sunmuyor.

24665420.review:
首先，接受作品本身设定是欣赏一切科幻作品的前提，但是这部作品里面不说平行宇宙和时间旅行的概念，“在不同世界线/平行宇宙之间跳跃(shift)”这个概念仔细想想其实逻辑上是站不住脚的。不过话说回来如果不考虑这个逻辑缺陷的话，整部作品的架构还是很严谨的，尤其是这么多世界线的前提之下还能做到基本逻辑自洽，很多意料之外的展开都有合理的伏笔铺垫，已经是相当不易了，只是美中不足之处在于结局略显仓促[strike]讲道理5分钟确实太短了[/strike]。
游戏性上来说，密室的难度设置比较合理而且（我个人感觉）是随着游戏进度逐渐上升的，虽然有的地方可能会卡个几分钟...相比之下shift这个机制的存在类似于剧情锁，有些地方需要其他世界线的信息才能解开谜题，这也是整个游戏里最棘手的部分。一个亮点是玩家可以自由选择各个记忆片段的设置，不仅贴心而且也贴合游戏的设定。
人设上，Junpei不仅思想上黑了不少而且整体戏份也不多，消防员Carlos，高大上，真正的救火英雄。一家三口组剧情真的很暖，嗯..对我说的是D组 [strike]可能是因为在Sigma和Phi身边Diana就像小孩子一样[/strike]
游戏中后期需要手边准备纸和笔。

TL;DR: This game is really REALLY good. Pick it up when you can, but wait until the first two games in the trilogy finish getting ported to pc.

Non-TL;DR: This game is a port, and a great one at that. I suggest using a controller if you've got one; but it's not necessary. Using the beta patch (enabled in Steam) fixes an audio cut-out glitch that affects the game. And.... that's it for glitches.
The characters are nicely written and the english voice acting (japanese VA is original) is done suprizingly well. The story is well written, although trying to figure out how to get the true ending is a little tough.
The puzzles are well made but some required me to look up a guide. :/ Decision moments are sometimes luck based. Monty Hall, I'm looking at you.
I really recommend this game who likes to get a good story, albeit a graphic one.

24632907.review:
Holy freaking crap. This game is just amazing in all points.
But Should I write a really long, extensive review or leave it at that?

Let me flip a coun. If I win that toss, I'll leave it at that. If I lose - more review.

Damn. Okay, here we go. Let us embark into a 20 hour [strike]review[/strike] Decision Game!

First of all: I have no prior knowledge or Experience with the Zero Escape Series. Say: 999 and VLR.

This gamme is a Puzzle Game / Visual Novel, but unlike your average visual Novel all dialoge is voiced and acted by character models in the respective rooms. So, in Game Cutscenes pretty much.
The Story is pretty simple (and might be known from a certain other Spike Chunsoft game involving a killing game)
9 people are trapped in an underground shelter. They are split in groups of 3 and awake for 90 minutes at a time. After that their memories of those 90 minutes are erased. To get out of the shelter they need six Passwords. A Password is revealed once a person dies. If you did the math, then six of the nine people (at least) have to die so the rest could escape. 
And here is where the game starts to shine: You dont play the stories of the 3 teams in a linear fashion. Rather than this, you have a global flowchart, based on a decision made by the 3 teams which splits the timeline into 4 different ones. You pick those 90 minute, amnesia ending snippets (called Fragments in game) and play through it. Some require you to make a Decision which might end up causing deaths or other bad (or good) things to happen. You are able to jump in and out of completed Fragments to see different outcomes or to just check what the devs came up with for text entering possibilities.

For example - I keep this part as vague as possible but still, Spoiler tags

[spoiler] One character from a team ends up dead at the beginning of a fragment. Another character aquires a weapon and believes you (the player controlled character) did it and threatens you to spit out the name. I have tried a lot of names that come up in the game, including end game very spoilery ones and I got different responses such as "You say it was ME? Stop prouting Bullshit!" upon entering the gun wielders name, "I can see that, but you are probably acting for him" upon entering Zero, the name the game master calls himself and "Interesting, But I dont know where that is" with the super duper spoilery name[/spoiler]

This also happened with another whudunnit text entry, but in textbox form. 

The VN Action is Broken by Escape the Room-Style Puzzle games. Those arent too hard or require you to have extensive knowledge about a lot of things (since usually upon checking a puzzle long enough, they will give you hints that become less subtile). I stopped the time on one I thought was going rather fast, and it took me about 20 minutes.

If there is one thing I have to complain, its that the voices, especially the voice of Zero, was very quiet and with a fan running next to me, I could barely understand what he said. This might have been due to my Laptops crappy sound output, but still, even with headphones it was hard to make out what he was saying.

Music is wonderful and fitting to the situation, the Puzzles are very well crafted and the Story is just [i] Woah [/i]

Overall, a good solid recomendation

24528346.review:
I enjoyed this a lot more than I expected to. The story is really interesting, and the puzzles were varied enough to remain interesting throughout.

The puzzle part is really the only "game" aspect of it. Aside from that, it's largely an interactive movie with many possible endings. The story branches at the many decision points you encounter, resulting in 2 different outcomes. You are able -- and in fact, required -- to go back and make the alternate choice to completely unlock all of the outcomes. I found it to be a really clever dynamic.

24522037.review:
先提醒下，有可能涉及剧透的部分都隐藏了。

从结论说起，这是非常棒非常值得推荐的游戏，完全值得我112元原价入手。
这里主要是指的极限脱出三部曲，9小时9人9房间（NDS）+善人死亡（3DS）+零时困境（也就是本作）。
最理想的游玩体验是，在完全无剧透的情况下，按照以上的顺序依次游戏，最好在每一作玩完后，都停几天用来回味下剧情，自己进行一下猜测和联想，然后再玩下一作。
然后你就会发现——这体验太愉悦了，并且发现不少剧情逻辑BUG……或者说，作者做的模棱两可的描述，你只能自己想象。

再回头来说下本作，本作的优点是讲清楚了之前埋下的坑，只看剧情的话，也算是给系列做了个完整的结局。然而本作的缺点也不少，我的感受是，相比之下，本作是三部曲里最糟糕的一作。

首先游戏进程选择的方式不好，过于碎片化的选择体验很差，而且由于每一个剧情的顺序和关联性很差，很难让人有连续游戏期待下一慕的心情，相反会被[spoiler]一片一片雷同的情节[/spoiler]拖的很累，感觉游戏过程中不是在融入剧情，而是在被动的完成任务。如果作者在叙事方式上放弃[spoiler]地点相同时间错位的小惊喜，和第一人称观察者的小惊喜[/spoiler]，反而换成另一种更有代入感的叙事方式，可能会更好。

其次，本作的谜题相当糟糕，这当然也是涉及一个代入感的问题。过于模式化的解谜，用各种拼图游戏来强行增加解谜时间，简直就让本来就支离破碎的故事情节变本加厉，解谜后的疲劳感超过了解谜本身的兴奋感，终究还是因为谜题设计上过于简单缺乏成就感，而过程却因为繁琐的拼图游戏累得够呛。反观前2作，这方面就适度的多。

再次，本作在[spoiler]血腥程度上算是回归第一作了，但是憋足的3D过程动画，缺乏独白的心里描述，反而不及过去那么震撼，甚至很多地方让人有种为了血腥而血腥的做作感[/spoiler]，在我看来这并不能给游戏有所加分，反而显得肤浅了。

此外是一些零碎的吐槽：
[spoiler]作者似乎是刻意的违反推理小说的十戒（在第二座善人死亡的时候，还有专门的文档描述过。）如果是系列的老玩家，可以翻回去一一对应下，我刚刚才通关，回忆中至少违反的一半以上。比如不能有超能力啦，不能使用超科学的机器啦，不能使用不知道的线索或者灵光一闪解谜啦之类的[/spoiler]

[spoiler]作者自己在第二作提到了机器人的3个定律，结果本作就这么不管了，红眼机器人他也是机器人啊，机器人的第0定律总觉得不能算适用吧，这也不能算为了人类的大义，有点牵强[/spoiler]

[spoiler]本作游戏参与者中居然没有背锅侠，米拉居然能得善终……不能因为她全程卖福利就有优待啊[/spoiler]

[spoiler]所以说直到最后作者都不打算解释ICE9这个坑了[/spoiler]

[spoiler]同样的，前一作爱丽丝和四叶穿越时间线的方式也没填坑，如果和薛定谔的猫有关的方式，那么在本作的外星科技面前是显得多么无力……[/spoiler]

[spoiler]从最本质上讲，前作的穿越是建立在闭环的时间线上，跨度45年。而本作直接跨度了124年，并且需要穿越才能确定循环条件，这跨度太大几乎已经算暴走了啊（虽然并没有什么特别不好的）[/spoiler]

[spoiler]其实这个游戏，换个标题也一样成立，比如《穿越时空的少女》，比如《我们都是超能力者》[/spoiler]

[spoiler]我觉得我对这个游戏一切的负面评价，源头都是，作者黑淳平黑的太过分了。虽然可以理解成傲娇，但是人确实是变的厉害，才1年啊哥哥，1年就这么大性格变化，这也算一种超能力了吧[/spoiler]

[spoiler]在三部作品中，提到的共鸣，解释上貌似都不太一样。第一作是指的血缘关系或者情感关系会加强共鸣，第二作是说，强能力者会同化吸收弱能力者的能力，使得能力共鸣增幅，到了本作，又变成了只要大家是超能力者，站在一起不光可以相互增强，还可以吧不是超能力者的人也带一脚一起穿越，这设定的细微变更其实挺维和的[/spoiler]

[spoiler]茜其实也表现出了和零类似的世界线观察者的能力，至少第二作是这样。可惜本作却败给了消防侠[/spoiler]

[spoiler]我忍不住第二次吐槽了，第一作ICE9爱丽丝那么好的一个伏笔，被莫名其妙的一个路过就搪塞过去了[/spoiler]

还有个来自游戏外的吐槽，就是我们伟大的机(3)翻(DM)汉化组，这翻译质量还有很大的优化余地啊（4.1补丁）。虽然第一时间能玩到很感谢，但是解谜部分的对话翻译还是机翻，剧情对话的一些翻译，因为我能听懂不少日文，所以明显发现好多翻译不对啊。希望汉化组能继续完善，让以后玩的玩家能有更好的体验。这游戏能打汉化补丁太棒了！三大妈太棒了！

听说这游戏前作要重制了……那么[spoiler]第一作绝妙的上下屏视角该怎么办？[/spoiler]。虽然我是蛮支持这个系列上PC的，因为做笔记各种方便啊，有啥线索什么的，直接截图甩QQ上就可以了，在3DS上做笔记一点一点写太苦逼了位置到最后有点不够，像PSV这种单屏幕机器要做个笔记也是蛮醉的。
也正因为做笔记太方便，加上游戏树形图跳跃系统的方便，每一作我通关的时间也在不停缩短。第一作记得花了40小时以上吧，选择上的差异是自己做笔记弄出来的，最后才选到了正确的路线。第二作30多个小时，主要跳跃太节约时间了，笔记对解谜帮助很大。本作时间最短，20来个小时就通关了，还得算上我一边吃饭一边玩玩完还跑去洗碗的时间……主要归公于，QQ截图做笔记太方便了

总之，期待这个系列三座能完全上STEAM，我完全不介意完整的再重温一遍，嗯

24521503.review:
Great game, a well written story with lots of mystery and a great atmosphere. This series have one of the best story and a nice atmosphere I ever played, especially in the first game, the feeling of satisfaction to discover what's behind each numbered door is the best. To absolutely NOT miss.

Compared to the two previous game, Zero Time Dilemma seems a bit odd as we actually follow the story by pieces and with the point of view of multiple persons which actually make the game slightly different from 999 or VLR. So the notion of doubt between the players would be mostly gone, right? Well, not really, the author still found a way to spice it up, and make the players still doubt each other’s. 

One of the change that I like is the animation of the story (not the animation itself, it's actually not that good). Before in 999 and VLR, we had to read the story with a plain background. Now in ZTD, we just have to follow the story by watching the animation, just like a movie.

Yet, I still find some decisions made by the characters a bit weird or exagerate which sometime make me question their logic, but why not, they experienced things I didn't.

To fully enjoy ZTD, it is more than recommended to play 999 and VLR, otherwise it would be quite confusing and you would just spoil some parts of the two previous amazing games, which would be not wise.

Overall, I enjoyed this last installation of the Zero Escape trilogy, well, not as much as VLR but It still deserve its place as a Zero escape game in my opinion.

24488289.review: Just finished this game a couple of days ago and I needed to let it digest because I could have given this game a negative review due to the back half of the game but overall I still think this is a winner but potential players need to know what to expect before jumping in. This game largely is non-linear, which is awesome, but can be potentially random and confusing due to the story jumping all over the place. In saying that the game works well by doing just that because you are trying to piece together all the threads of a story that takes many twists and turns throughout. I was impressed by how everything came together and take my hat off to the developers for creating quite a complex tree of decisions and plot branches to get to the end. Next point of warning relates to the story being told: there is a HUGE number of cutscenes which cannot be skipped or fast forwarded. I love a good cutscene but I do believe this game could have snipped a fair few of them out of the game. I found myself not having touched mouse/keyboard in upwards of an hour at some points. They do serve character development, of course, but when the ratio of interactive gameplay and cutscenes is out of whack and is noticeable then there may be a problem. Perhaps a few more puzzles scattered through the ending may have broken up the long videos. Hence why by the end of the game I was quite relieved that the story was done. But, why the thumbs up? This game does have a very addictive knack of creating mystery, having some challenging puzzles and having some of the solutions to those puzzles requiring a lot of pen and paper notes plus scattering answers throughout other scenes that pushes this beyond a hidden object game. If you don't like a challenge, don't like puzzles, or like to use a hint function within a game then don't play this. The mood of this game does replicate any 'escape room' scenarios ala 'Saw' and is 110% not suitable for children. There is a lot of death in the game, some very strong adult themes, and terminology that is going to fly straight over most  younger people's heads but for the adult audience this is very much a Japanese style game that is very familiar to anyone who's watched most Japanese extreme cinema or watched a bit of Anime. Overall, I did enjoy the game, not without flaws, but I was impressed by how addictive it was and will be interested to see what they do next :)

After waiting anxiously for what seemed like an eternity, Zero Time Dilemma lives up to all the expectations I had from a game like this. Perfect for fans of science, psuedo-science, philosophy, puzzle-solving and the mystery-thriller genre in general, with returns from old, lovable characters (and some new ones that'll be quite a treat to see develop!) as well as challenging puzzles (that sometimes, admittedly, were a little far-fetched, but did not detract from the storyline, which was the game's main focus anyway - consider it closure) and the new animation style takes the best from the game's predecessors and combines them into a style I liked much more than VLR's.

24467895.review:
De primeras, para resumir: Juego NECESARIO de trilogía a la que jugar OBLIGATORIAMENTE. 

Simplemente increíble, si las entregas anteriores se caracterizan por dejar cabos sueltos y por la tremenda y complicada trama, Zero Time Dilemma consigue (aunque durante el juego parezca que no) despejar todas las incógnitas y aportarle un sentido a la saga que demuestra que no solo es un juego macabro de puzles. 

Respecto al sistema de juego, aunque al principio parece que se pase de innovador (al menos yo no creía que me terminara de convencer), conforme avanza te das cuenta de que los saltos espaciotemporales (a los que los creadores de Zero Escape quieren acostumbrarnos) aportan mucho dinamismo a la historia, y quizá sea parte del encanto propio de la saga, ¿no? Que cada detalle sorprenda, y que de repente "algo" de sentido a todo. Lo que sí he notado es que, a la hora de resolver las habitaciones, han apostado por un sistema más mecánico, muchos de los tipos de puzles se repiten y, al menos desde mi punto de vista, los de las anteriores entregas eran más complicados. 

Los personajes están muy bien escogidos, con sus secretos y motivos personales para aparecer. Lástima que alguno no aparezca anteriormente, porque o los quieres o los odias y es fantástico que ninguno deje indiferente. 

Respecto al aspecto gráfico, estoy absolutamente enamorada de cómo han evolucionado a la hora de plantear tanto escenarios como personajes, y creo que para lo que ofrece el juego ha sido idea de 10 cambiar la perspectiva en primera persona de los anteriores. 
 
En fin, sigo alucinada y cualquier cosa que salga de mis manos es alta alerta de spoiler hypeado. Jugad, jugad y echadle horas, que lo merece.

Pues todo eso, que 5000/10, señores.

24467409.review:
I loved this game, just like it's predecessors. I'm not a fan of visual novels overall but this game really stands out a lot. 

[h1]Pro's[/h1]
[list]
[*][b]Amazing story. Really.[/b] This alone is reason enough to buy this game already. It's [i]that[/i] good. It wrapped up the series in a really satisfying manner.
[*]A good change of pace between gameplay elements (escape rooms) and story elements.
[*]Just when you think you know some things, the game throws you a curveball to get you off-balance. But in a good way; it's not like suddenly crazy weird stuff happens (and no "I woke up and it was all just a dream" here), it's actually incredibly well thought out and seems to always be two steps ahead.
[*]You really need to use your brains and think on some puzzles or story fragments, for example if you need to give an answer to an open-ended question. It brings about great discussions and theories as to why and how things are happening that you don't know (yet).
[*][b]You can actually play this game without having played the other games.[/b] Don't get me wrong: there are definitely nudges and winks towards the other games, but if there's significant information, they'll actually explain it in this game aswell. Note that you do sort of spoil some things that happen in the other games, but I wouldn't say it's massive plot twists that would make playing the other games unnessecary. I played this with my partner that didn't play the other games and yet we both knew about the same at the same moments. In fact, we look forward to the PC ports of the other games! :)
[*]The game features violence and blood, but you never see actual extreme gore. I thought it was a good balance between being scary but not frighteningly much to divert your attention from the story.
[/list]

[h1]Cons[/h1]
[list]
[*]A big story element is that there are 3 teams. That's not really an issue by itself, but the story is further divided into fragments that you can watch individually. I didn't really know where to start and most things made no sense at all. All in all it gave a rough start. Later on when you've played some more fragments, things start to make more sense though. 
[*]Sometimes you can get stuck in the various timelines and you simply don't know what to do. The main timeline isn't always clear enough to show you what options you have left. 
[/list]

I can't mention enough how good the story of this game was. It reminded me of the "Saw" movies, with less gore and a lot better story. I'm really glad I've played this series and I think it's one of the best games I've ever played story-wise. I couldn't recommend it any more than that. If you have the patience to appreciate a good story, definitely consider picking this up!

24440865.review:
[h1]Who is this game for?[/h1]
This game is for everyone who played the previous games (Zero Escape: Virtue's Last Reward and 999). It is a visual novel with multiple "Escape Room Puzzles". If you are into solving puzzles and living a rich story but haven't played 999/VLR then I recommend you to get them before getting this game. As of the time writing this, the previous games are on Nintendo 3DS and iPad. They will be ported to STEAM soon.


[h1]The Good Things[/h1]
+ Rich thrilling story sequences that is able to maintain your interest to the end.
+ The game is mostly voiced and animated in 3D. (During Escape Rooms, it is not voiced. However, little dialoug happen during these sequences).
+ Where in 999 we had the Nonary Game, VLR had the Ambidex Game, ZTD version is called The Decision Game which gives new twists on what VLR has established.
+ Awesome soundtracks and awesome returning picks from past games.

[h1]The Bad[/h1]
- Production of this game was hurt because of limited resources. You will notice that the 3d animations (during the narrative mode) are very limited and sometimes weird. It is such a shame that we have games like "Telltale's Game of Thrones" or "Beyond: Two Souls" with expensive production values and average story work. 

- Camera control in the PC could have been done better.


[h1]tl;dr[/h1]
Love Zero Escape games? Buy it.
Love puzzle/visual novels and didnt play Zero Escape before? Buy them all and play them in order.

24424017.review:
At last we finally have the conclusion to the Zero Escape series after it appeared for a couple years that this game wouldn't get funding due to relative poor sales of the previous two games in the series. Although I'd have to admit all games in the series are pretty flawed in one way or another, I'd still recommend giving these a look if you're down for a pretty well written mystery/thriller with an unmistakably Japanese flavor. So before we go any further, know that THIS REVIEW WILL CONTAIN LIGHT SPOILERS FOR 999 AND VIRTUE'S LAST REWARD because I have no idea how to discuss this series' convoluted plot otherwise

Zero Time Dilemma begins in December of 2028 at the Dcom facility in Nevada and takes place after the events of 999, but before the events of Virtue's Last Reward. Sigma and Phi have traveled back in time and joined what is known as "The Dcom experiment" in order to prevent the outbreak of the Radical-6 virus which has killed most of Earth's population in the future. They are joined by Junpei and Akane from 999 who have been tracking the movements of a terrorist organization known as "Free the Soul" whose objectives also include destroying humanity. They are joined by heroic firefighter Carlos, sad sack Eric, seductive Mira, a somehow familiar looking girl named Diana, and a young boy boy has no memory and wears a strange capsule on his head. As part of the Dcom experiment, the group of them are (of course) locked in a facility and forced to play a deadly "decision game". The group is forced to split into 3 teams and told that at any point if 6 people are dead, the remaining survivors will be allowed to escape. Additionally, every 90 minutes a drug from the participants bracelets is injected which puts them to sleep and wipes their short term memories. Pretty crazy stuff

The story of Zero Time Dilemma is told in 90 minute "fragments" where you choose what team you'd like to follow and watch what events play out over the next 90 minutes. Only you initially have no idea where those 90 minutes fit into the grand timeline of the game. Sometimes you'll start a fragment and half of the group will be already dead and you'll have no idea why. I actually found this approach to storytelling a little annoying and hard to follow as I never knew where in the timeline I was and near the end I couldn't keep track of all the reveals of who was dead and who was alive and why.

After 999's static images and fixed camera, Virtue's Last Reward introduced voice acting and full 3d models with moderately successful results. Zero Time Dilemma takes it even farther with a much more distinctly cinematic approach to portraying its story. Zero Time Dilemma uses much more camera panning and animations during cutscenes. This is a slightly less successful transition unfortunately. It was pretty clear that the animation team was either rushed or not very experienced. Animations are jerky and forced and the lip sync is pretty questionable. It personally didn't bother me too much, but it was certainly notable and I know a lot of people will find the stiff animations a distracting drawback

I thought the puzzles in Zero Time Dilemma were some of the best of the series. They were varied, interesting and had me pulling out actual pen and paper to work through problems. Depending on the order of the fragments you play, the pacing of the puzzle rooms can be a little weird though. In my experience, I had tons of puzzle rooms in the beginning and middle of the game, but almost none near the end which made playing through the end of the game more like watching a movie. Speaking of the end... it was kind of a let down. Without discussing any spoilers, the ending was sort of plain and disappointing which was a surprise in of itself since 999 and Virtue's Last Reward had such huge reveals and shocking twists. Ahh well, it was still nice to finally have some sort of closure for this series.

Regardless of what the marketing of this game wants you to believe, you can't play it without playing the first two games first. Or at least you shouldn't. Start there first or else you'll likely be massively confused. For veterans of the series, this game will offer some closure for the story, albeit a slightly disappointing one. I still must admit I enjoyed this game a lot as it features some of the strongest puzzle rooms in the series. The Zero Time Dilemma journey is much more enjoyable than the destination, and the journey is worth it.

24420235.review:
TL;DR - Generally solid but lackluster, without much fun, challenge, or cheeky dialogue to rescue it. Wait for it to go on sale, even if you're a fan of the series. 

6/10

More below.


---



A valid and passionate attempt to finish out the Zero Escape series that falls flat in puzzle challenge and curve, character development, and an enormous amount of unsolved questions. 

It had a lot of potential - the voice acting is decent, the musical remixes and new tracks are on par with the rest of the series, and while most of the story's twists were predictable after a point, some DID leave me impressed at the amount of hidden foreshadowing and Uchikoshi's general ability to blow the player away. Given a few more months minimum of polishing the story and gameplay, this could have been an outstanding game to end the series with a bang. As it is, it sends the series out with a thousand more question marks and a wet, sad fizzle. 

Returning characters' consistency is all over the place, while new characters are flat and dull. Puzzle rooms are surprisingly empty in challenge for an M-label audience - outside two INCREDIBLY hard ones, most puzzles presented are either boring, extremely repetitive, or both, requiring less of the logic that other ZE titles favor and more just a pair of working eyes and an ability to see that "X goes into Y". When I become less excited for puzzles in favor of frustration over a third "fit all the items in the box" minigame with no change in difficulty, it speaks for how much fun I as a player am having and how much I want to continue the game for the sake of finding new things. And while the story had its moments, most of it felt like the writers were dragging their feet. Dialogue was stale, character chemistry was awkward, various points unresolved from 999 and VLR were not addressed even in passing, and (my biggest complaint) one particular twist anchoring much of the end of the game felt completely out of genre - a deus ex machina that tried to explain a lot but felt thrown in as an afterthought, not even touching the ideas of Quantum Theory and the possibilities of the human mind and body that existed in other games. It made the rushed ending even less enjoyable. Even the addition of epilogue files to try and wrap things up after the cinematics end falls short, several characters not even making an appearance for a "happy ending".

THAT ALL SAID, THOUGH: I'm still a fan of the series, and I still do have a fondness for the purpose of this title, even if this game is on the bottom of the trilogy by a long shot for me. If you have played the other two Zero Escape titles (and you should - much of this game won't strike as hard if you're playing it blind), then I'd recommend getting this for the sake of completion and some manner of story resolution... but NOT full price. Lack of engaging puzzles, a 20-hour-max play time and no major replayability afterwards really makes it hard to defend the $40 USD price tag.

Wait until a good Steam Sale if you're that desperate to pick it up.

24414829.review:
Great ending to a great series.
WARNING: If you haven't played 999 or virtue's last reward, I strongly urge you play both of those games before playing this one.  You will not enjoy this game nearly as much if you have no idea what's going on, and this game is competly story reliant.  There will apparently be a pc release for both prequels at some point, so fear not.

Zero time dilemma took what may be called a risk; they departed from the visual novel style that the first 2 game utilized, and instead adopted a more cinematic style when presenting the story.  At first I was skeptical of this decision, and feared that it would tarnish the 2 previous games I had come to love, but I find the decision really had no ill effects on the game at all, and doing away with all the clicking may even be considered a positive.  One negative, may be that important information could potentially slip by you if you aren't giving the game your complete attention, but there is a log you can check in that case for any miseed dialogue, but really if you aren't giving a story focused game your complete attention then why are you even playing it.

The puzzles in this game I consider to be easier than the first 2 games, though not by a massive amount; perhaps I am just so used to the way puzzles are done in this series after playing the first 2.  There were only a couple of moments that I found myself not knowing what to do, and it was usually just because I hadn't clicked a specific place below some floating symbols or something similar.  

The second game (virtue's last reward) had you navigate a flowchart to move between different storylines, and this game does the same while adding a few new complexities to the equation, such as 3 point of view characters and the story fragment system. These new features aren't just gimmicks either and play an important role in the way the narrative is told.

I won't speak much on the story, because spoilers for a game this story focused, and a game with so many twists and turns would be a disservice to anyone reading this.  All I will say is that everything is wrapped up nicely, I am satisfyed with this conclusion to the series, and this is probably my favourite of the 3 games in the series, though time will tell if I will change my mind, since I only just finished this game.  

tl;dr: IF YOU ENJOY STORIES IN YOUR GAMES, LIKE ADVENTURE GAMES, LIKE VISUAL NOVELS, LIKE SFI-FI OR HORROR, THEN I SUGGEST YOU TRY THE ZERO ESCAPE SERIES.

Наконец-то владельцы ПК получили нормальную "Пилу" на свои устройства.
Это игра о выборе, каждый ваш выбор влияет на финальный итог этой истории, о ребятах, попавших в неприятности. Всего их 9, и каждый выделяется своим характером и своими мотивами, временами случаются "Вотэтоповороты", которые почти всегда удивляют. Как таковая - это визуальная новелла, но с примесью детектива, хоррора и головоломки. Весь геймплей разделяется между 3 командами и за каждую из них вам придётся пройти несколько комнат с испытаниями, и в конце сделать выбор, от которого зависит жизни не только "ваших" напарников, но и жизни других комманд.
Так как это детектив, то разговоров тут много, и так как, русский не завезли, приходётся как-то выкручиваться.

Let me first state that I'm really mainly recommending this game to those who have played 999 and Virtue's Last Reward. Now onto the game, I really did enjoy Zero Time Dilemma a lot, but sadly not as much as the other two. Overall, Zero Time Dilemma is a great and fitting ending to the trilogy, and while I have a few of my own gripes with it, it was a really enjoyable experience overall

Pros:
[list]
[*]Great story
[*]Soundtrack is amazing as always

[*]Fully-animated cutscenes were actually really cool. I know the animation may not click with some, but I enjoyed it

[/list]

Cons:
[list]
[*]A few issues with the story, but I won't list them because spoilers
[*]It may have been just me, but there were times where the story felt way more linear that what I'm used to with Zero Escape games, which I guess worked out well for this particalar game, but it just felt kind of weird to me
[*]As with most Zero Escape games, it takes a little while for the story to pick up, but this may not be that big of an issue for some
[/list]

If you played and enjoyed 999 and Virtue's Last Reward, then you'll definitely enjoy Zero Time Dilemma. If you haven't played the previous games, then I highly recommend playing them first before playing this one

24376803.review:
Zero, my old friend. I've missed you.

Well, sort of. You've never been the same person twice, have you?

Yet here you are, with two previous Zeroes under your thumb, and a rogue's gallery of nine people, some familiar-- some not. What vile scheme have you cooked up this time?

Three teams of three, plus Gab. He carries notes and stuff. Incredibly old, and adores his cheese. 

There are a couple of changes that were made from the other games, but only a small handful of them bear mentioning: 

First, the visual novel sections have been cut out, and replaced with fully voiced and animated cutscenes. There are some upsides to this, as the need for tedious button presses every few seconds goes away, which does wonders for the pacing. You can turn the skip off and on in the configuration tool (which also has the video and audio settings). 

Next, the Nonary game has been replaced by the Decision Game. Unlike previous games, the teams are set from the word go, and don't change. At least not until things start going sideways in Act III. People live, people die, and what happens in every ending is important to the final resolution. Good or bad, every one. This is one of the few games where ti counts to see everything the game has to offer. 

If you've played the first two games all the way through, you'll know what's coming. If not, you're in for a wild ride. You won't get some of the more obscure plot points until late in the game, but it'll be worth it when you do. My suggestion, if you have the hardware-- buy the previous two games, and play them. 9 Persons, 9 hours, 9 Doors is the very basics, and while it explains the events within the game, it leaves far more questions. 

Virtue's Last Reward, on the other hand, ends on a sort of cliffhanger, which is answered in this last game, and you finally get the answers to all the other questions that have been hanging around since the opening of the series...

Including some you may not have thought to ask. 

You see, it's all about a snail... A single snail that changes everything. Like the previous two games, there are a pile of escape-the-room puzzles to solve and decisions to make, but ultimately it's a huge mystery spanning three games over the course of nearly half a century. 

Definitely worth the price of admission, and the devs are quick to deal with bug reports. I more than got my money out of it, which these days is rare at best. On my list for Game of the Year, for sure.
