24148294.review:
This comes from playing the first two games in the franchise and thouroughly enjoying them.  

  To begin, this isn't a horrible game in and of itself.  But it suffers, struggling in almost every area.

  1. New people are going to have an impossible time getting in to it.  It starts slow out of the gate  just trying to catch up newbies with a massive information dump, and it's going to create a lot of head scratching.  There is some dense dialogue about premises from the previous games that is hard to swallow.  Its still possible to approach for new players, but I can't possibly see it being as enjoyable for the first hour.

  2.  For fans of the series, there are some red flags for you as well.  The presentation completely restricts the narrative and makes no sense.  Unlike the previous two games, this isn't strictly a choose your own adeventure story.  By adopting what the game calls "fragments", you basically play only snippets of a story, before jumping to another line of the story.  Your choices don't result in a feeling of accomplishment or weight.  Instead of encouraging choices about how to progress through the story, its really just an inane system where you put check marks in a box as you move along.

  3.  And the story.  

  Don't get these games wrong.  There are always puzzles, but the puzzles always play fiddle to the story.  There aren't very many and they aren't hard enough to challenge someone who likes puzzle games.  In the past, this has been okay because the story was so good.  But the story is lacking in this installment.

     The first half is addled by the presentation like I've already said.  The elements are all present to be interesting, but its a slog; however, the third quarter is where this game shines.  For a brief moment, it gains some direction and feels like its headed somewhere big, and the excitement is there.

   But then.  Without spoiling anything.  The home stretch of the story is the most ridiculous series of deus-ex-machinas that I have ever seen.  There are huge concepts that are introduced at the very end with basically zero set up, and, somehow, even less explanation.  

  Its borderline offensive how stupid it becomes.


  In summary.  There are moments of greatness, but most of it is a slog.  The puzzles are fine and the story is a slow build that nose dives just as it becomes satisfying.  Players of the first two will inevitably play this, but it won't live up to the previous installments.

  New players?  Just go play the first two games (999 and VLR) if you can get your hands on them.  They are fantastic.

  I was excited to play this game. I loved the first two.  But I am extremely conflicted about this one.  It's not a bad game, but its not good.

24148137.review:
Ahhhh, the Zero Escape saga.  What can I say about it that people haven't already?  Between intriguing mystery, exploring the hidden depths and quirks to the colorful characters, and genuinely challenging puzzles I legitimately fell in love with this series from my first play through 9 Hours 9 Persons 9 Doors.

All that being said, while this game is a very nice capstone to the series, it feels just a bit lacking.

Perhaps it has something to do with the shift from visual-novel style to a more Tell Tale Games-esque interactive movie.  Only problem is, unlike TTG there's no quick-time events and (whether you love or hate QTE's) that removes a level of immersion from the game.  When you're reading the events visual novel style in the first two you can't help but be drawn in, and with TTG knowing that a dialogue choice or QTE waits around every corner means you're constantly on the edge of your seat.

ZTD, however, lacks both of those.  You still make choices and explore the consequences that unfold, but it's always after watching a scripted sequence that, admittedly, can run a bit long.  The puzzles also feel just a bit less challenging than I'm used to from this series, and the fact that the gameplay is broken up into multiple "Fragments" means that the story has a disjointed feel to it while trying to play since after each big decision you're getting booted back to the menu to pick a new memory to play out.

Of course, those complaints are middling compared to the fact that this is a worthy conclusion for the Zero Escape Trilogy.  Any complaints I may have are pointless since if you're already a fan you've probably already got it and if you aren't you're doing yourself a disservice trying to skip the first two and jump into this.

My overall opinion?  A good game, nice way to end the series, but it unfortunately feels like this all really peaked back in Virtue's Last Reward.

24147504.review:
[h1] Внимание! Это третья часть трилогии! [/h1]
   Изумительная игра. И, о боже, такая японская. Но прежде скажу, что Zero Escape - серия, и если вы не играли в [b]Nine Hours, Nine Persons, Nine Doors[/b] и [b]Zero Escape: Virtue's Last Reward[/b], то сориентироваться будет безумно тяжело. И речь не о милых пасхалках, отсылающих к событиям предыдущих игр, а о критически значимых сюжетных элементах. Половина героев здесь должны быть вашими старыми знакомыми к моменту начала! 
   Что ж, скоро первые части будут портированы на ПК, что существенно облегчит жизнь всем нам, а пока можно воспользоваться видео-прохождениями или блогами в lparchive.
   О, и кстати, изначально серия сидит корнями в портативных консолях, так что к некоторой графической... аскетичности лучше привыкнуть сразу. Честно слово, оно того стоит. Только звук переключите на японский.

[h1] А теперь о самой игре [/h1]
   Итак, девять человек по разным причинам соглашаются участвовать в эксперименте, который скоро превращается в битву за выживание. Они уже примерно знакомы друг с другом, но свой багаж тайн все равно есть у каждого. А где-то в этом исследовательском комплексе находится и маньяк-организатор, который старательно избегает показываться на глаза. И комнаты, много комнат с загадками и ловушками. За одно прохождение их даже увидеть все невозможно... но кто сказал, что прохождение будет только одно?
   У нас тут 20+ часов специфического экспириенса. Во-первых, это упомянутые комнаты, из которых необходимо найти выход: комната управления и наблюдения, биолаборатория, лазарет, лаунж-зона, душевая, склад и прочие. В них надо разбираться с мини-паззлами, искать коды, а также применять и комбинировать предметы. 
   Во-вторых, между комнатами будут скриптованные сценки с сюжетными выборами, которые посылают нас на разные ветки сценария. Этот сюжет, который проходит через жизни девяти человек в разнящихся вариантах прошлого и будущего, есть отличительная особенность серии Zero Escape, потому что в нем важная каждая сцена. Каждый маленький эпизод на этом монструозном дереве развилок, выборов и последствий. 
   Иногда вы, игрок, принимаете решение перепрыгнуть на конкретную сюжетную линию, и герои подчиняются. Иногда решение принимают они, и тогда вам ничего не остается, кроме как последовать за ними. Придется работать сообща, если хотите сохранить жизнь всем участникам.
   

[h1] Размышления и небольшие спойлеры [/h1]
   Zero Time Dilemma в принципе отвечает на многие вопросы, которые остались открытыми в первых двух частях. На многие - но не на все, да еще и парочку собственных добавляет, и вводит целую новую сущность в свою мифологию (тут речь о "3D-принтере", который [spoiler]работает сквозь время и реальность[/spoiler]). В общем, задел на продолжение есть, но и сама по себе история выглядит завершенной. Чего точно не скажешь о концовке второй части, ха.
   Неловко обвинять эту игру в использовании жанровых клише, когда она сама жанр и определяет. Ожидаемые неожиданные повороты, неожиданные неожиданные повороты, "все не то, чем кажется", хитрое положение камеры, аккуратное введение в заблуждение при помощи недомолвок и натуральная санта-барбара взаимоотношений персонажей - это таки внутренний канон. Зато если игрок внимателен к деталям и не спешит ничего слепо принимать на веру, он будет вознагражден парой ранних подсказок. Это отлично.
   Zero Escape также интересна в том плане, что искусно примешивает к собственному художественному вымыслу многие существующие явления и научные гипотезы, пускай бы спорные и недоказуемые. Таким образом, если вы принимаете предлагаемые допущения (существование вируса Radical-6, к примеру, или явление SHIFT), то вам будет весьма комфортно. Если не принимаете - увы, сюжет превратится в кровавое приключение группки людей с супер-силами.
   Дальше все-таки спойлеры по ощущениям. 
   [spoiler]Наверное, это немного смущает меня. Персонажи знают, что могут сSHIFTиться в нужный момент, если их жизни угрожает опасность; а это значит, что острота чувств игрока притупляется. Какая тут драма, если жертвы и испытания так и остаются в побочных линиях. Игра вроде и пытается сказать, что опыт не пропадает даром, что все варианты историй самодостатчны, заслуживают уважения и сострадания... но мы-то знаем, какая ветка дает ачивку за "настоящее" прохождение. Так что тут мы чуть-чуть потеряли.[/spoiler]
   Но это был чудесный опыт. Три сумасшедших вечера, три восьмичасовых марафона (с погрешностями) и исписанный кодами и схемами блокнот под рукой. Вин.

24143011.review:
Well...that was a huge disappointment.

Quick disclaimer: I've been a fan of Uchikoshi's work ever since Ever17. I loved 999. I didn't really like VLR because it rehashed a lot of things from the Infinity series and expanded the story to what I believe was a very forced conclusion (so suddenly the entire world perished due to a never before mentioned deadly virus, huh? Okay...)

But I still believed in this third installment and honestly thought something amazing like Ever17 or 999 could come of it.
It didn't.

I'm sure you're now wondering "wait, why is his review positive then?"

Truth be told, as a puzzle game, ZTD is very solid. Some ideas for puzzles were overused, but outside of that it's pretty good.
As a story-driven game, I was actually rather pleased with it until it's later parts. It had a generally strong narrative that kept you interested and many nice ideas: the fragment system is confusing at first, but a very nice system because it allows for the player to experience the story in different ways and slowly fit up the pieces him/herself. The idea of hopping through timelines with codes and passwords also comes back, though as with VLR it could've been implemented better, I think. The Decision Game was also quite interesting with all the dilemmas piling up.

So, why did I say I was disappointed? Well, the central twist over Zero's identity and the ending.

I'm sorry to say, but that was just completely stupid. It was a twist so absurd that any sort of sense of desbelief is thrown away through the window. You have to experience it to believe it. That one single thing brought the entire game crashing down for me. And the ending that followed was alright, but weak and full of plotholes. Ever since VLR, the Zero Escape series is full of plotholes, but ZTD promised to adress those. Not only did it not offer any satisfying explanations, it created even bigger holes that I believe will never be adressed. The mechanics on how the science works in the story just make no sense at all and are inconsistent from game to game. There is one particular ending (you'll know which one) where one of the characters could've actually resolved the whole problem, but that character is so incredibly dumb that he doesn't. Trust me, you'll know what I mean.

With that said, this is a positive review. I had a consistently good time with ZTD until the final twist showed it's ugly head and there was actually one particular ending that was emotional and engaging.

I wouldn't say it's not worth to pick up ZTD at all due to all those factors, but unless you're a blind fanboy I don't see how this couldn't come up as anything but a disappointment story-wise.

I'll just have to pretend none of the sequels for 999 ever happened. I guess I can do that. I did it with FF X-2.

24134783.review:
After being stuck for a long time because I was stupid, I finished the game, got all the endings, even some bad ones.

Here's my impressions (some spoilers):

The good:

- The new puzzles made my brain go insane sometimes, but some that were really difficult for some people were easy to me, and others were near impossible.
- The story itself is really good, can't say the same about the timeline fragments thought. I mean, I liked it all the mystery and suspense in some points. [spoiler]And at D-Team End 2, I legit cried.[/spoiler]
- IQ is good, even with some lowres textures here and there. Got no crashes, only a minor sound bug.
- [spoiler]The ward twist was really well played, I didn't make the connection until the game told me so, because I thought it was the same case with VLR, 2 floors. Well played, game.[/spoiler]
- Diana is the best character on this game IMO, [spoiler]having to see her breakdown on the path to end D-2 was really hard on me.[/spoiler]
- This game is so gory, like, holy crap. They weren't kidding when they said wanted a higher rating. The pictures in the screenshots don't do justice to the game proper.
- English voices are top notch. [spoiler]DC Douglas (Wesker in RE5) as Zero? Yes please.[/spoiler] Haven't played in Japanese, so I won't comment on that.
- [spoiler]The ending was definitely... something. I have to say I wasn't expecting it but at least it worked and made tons of sense. I'm more surprised than anything.[/spoiler]

The bad:
- The fragments system. I missed one scene and for God knows how long, I was stuck on the game, unable to progress further. A large punishment for a single mistake.
- The stiff animations and horrible lipsyncing do not improve as the game progresses, some scenes are so awkward because of them. It is a port of a handheld game, but still.
- [spoiler]The 'Who is Zero II?' twist was so awkward, I mean, you can make a deduction way before he appears, and know his identity, like in half game, even before that.[/spoiler]
- [spoiler]It was very hard to me to like Eric (I guess that is the same to anyone), a guy that panics over every single damn thing. I mean, he is supposed a 'regular' guy, but in the last quarter of game, he goes on carrying a shotgun, falsely accusing people and shooting them.[/spoiler]
- [spoiler]Mira being 'that' is so much an untwist it hurts. Also she is undirectly responsible for everything that happens, in all games. Way to go.[/spoiler]
- [spoiler]At the same time I was surprised about the ending, it's so damn open, I really doubt that this is the end of the series.[/spoiler]
- [spoiler]The game is quite "short", if you know what you're doing.[/spoiler]

Overall, a good game, but it suffers (IMO) from the 'middle child syndrome', strangely, more plots are opened instead of closed because of this game. I'd say that VLR is the better game in terms of puzzles, but ZTD has a better story and tries to keep the suspense up all times, while VLR drops it right at the middle. I haven't played 999 yet, as I await for the Steam port of it.

I'd rate ZTD an 8, an solid game experience, full of deaths and nice stories branches. And complex motives.

Also, the Decision Game. [spoiler]2 in binary is 10. Once you played it, you'll understand. Very well played.[/spoiler]

24130942.review:
Spoilers Ahead.
Only read this review if you have already beaten the game, or if you don't care about spoiling it for yourself.

Zero Time Dilemma is easily, for me, the weakest game in the Zero Escape series. It's still a good game, with a variety of interesting twists and mind boggling time line bending, but at the end of the day it fails to pull it's own weight. 

First thing's first: The Cast.
ZTD is played through three groups of characters, Q team, D team and C team. Sadly, C team, containing Sigma, Phi and Luna, character's we know and love, play a surprisingly small part in the game. Phi is a grave casualty in this situation, receiving far too little screen time for such an important character, and while Sigma and Diana have reasonable time, their existence is more about establishing their relationship than strengthening their characters.  Carlos, leader of team C is a new character introduced, who is a perfect flawless John Doe fireman, but still manages to come out as one of the better characters if you can ignore his backstory being ripped out of a Disney film. Junpei and Akane are back and better than ever as the co-members of C team and they hate each other... For roughly five minutes. After that Junpei is hunting for that poon once more and Akane is talking about how she could never live without him, even though he's become a wildly cynical dick.  Then, there's Eric, a ceaselessly whiny, trigger happy fellow who spends almost all of his time on camera screeching about this or that. Mira, a girl who loves from the heart for the heart, and manages to scratch that 'angsty, just not quite realistic murderess' that everybody knows and loves. Last but not least, your friendly robotic child and a dog that everyone has an absurd affinity for.

The Animation!
If you're looking for some constant uncomfortable uncanny valley in your life, look no further. Joking aside, the animation is a nice detour from the previous game's Visual Novel style, as it allows for a little bit more freedom in camera angles, but I do think it ruined the immersion a great deal at some times with the jerky, jaunty movements and sometimes unsynced voice/lip movements.

Plot:
The plot of ZTD was good. Kind of. It was good as a stand alone game. However, if you're expecting Akane to talk about her brother who loves her dearly, that's not going to happen. If you're expecting to ever hear about K, tough. The previous games are mentioned in such small amounts that, while it would be nice for new players, it is incredibly disconcerting for someone who wants to know more about the mysteries left over from previous games. Still, there were good twists sprinkled about, and while it did dip into the melodramatic from time to time (see; Maniacal laughing, unnecessary murder, WHO KILLED MIRA?!), over all it managed to handle the situations portrayed well.

Ending: (This is where the spoilers really really start, so turn back now.)
This is where the game fell off the most. The ending for ZTD was a huge disappointment. Once again, everybody was trapped in this facility because Zero had the good of mankind in mind. Well, more exactly he had 'Complex Motives', and needed to bring himself into existence even though that creates a paradox of it's own. Then, there's the fact that, assuming as the implication has been that this is the last game in the series, we don't even know who our villain is. It's just some terrorist who we know nothing about. Free the Soul, Brother, Left, Crash Keys, Cradle, throw them all in the same pot cause they're all good guys at the end of the day and you're never going to know who the real bad guy is. 

VLR's ending left a huge promise for what ZTD was going to be about; Sigma and Phi trying to stop the outbreak of Radical 6, with the help of some other company from that timeline who never appear in this game. Instead we got a soft boiled, poorly connected rehash of past Zero Escape games where Sigma and Phi played a surprisingly small part.

Overall:
Overall this game is a good game, contrary to what everything in my review says. If you liked the other Zero Escape games, you kind of have to play it to experience the ending, but know that it won't live up to it's predessesors in anything other than psychobabble. If you just want a different, story based game with puzzle elements, go for it. You'll definitely find yourself missing something, but it's something unique, and that much is nice. Preferably play the other games first though. More or less just buy the trilogy and be disappointed but not entirely crushed by this one. 
Enjoy!

24127954.review:
Featuring full voice acting, multiple levels of depth and complexity, and and intriguing storyline, Zero Time Dilemma is a fantastic inclusion into the psychological thriller Genre and one that I have no reservations recommending to anyone who might be interested in a narrative based story with puzzles and intrigue.

Review Excerpt:
"Each scene has a series of events or choices in it that allow your team members to either live or die. Any time there is a choice.. or what Zero calls the ‘Decision Game” the team leader has to choose between options A,B, or sometimes C and D. Each choice has the potential for dire consequences for either one or more people. In addition to that, the scenes are all out of order. That’s done seemingly intentionally as so many aspects of this game are. This is rationalized by the devices the captives wear on their wrists. They inject them with a sedative and a compound that makes them forget every 90 minutes. This means you have to try and figure out and piece together the true sequence of events and also which events you need to try and avoid as they may cause the deaths of multiple people.
The complexity of the game continues on further with at least one of the captives may not be all they seem to be, adding in even more intensity and general mistrust. Also there are even puzzles that can only be figured out if you pay attention to the dialogue and clues that you pick up from the character’s interactions."

See my full Critique here:
https://youtu.be/TvuGrEloo5c

24124328.review:
The game the Fans wanted bu not the game the fans deserved.

This is a game that by all means should not exist...but thanks to the love of the developers and the passion of the fans this game is finally here !!!

By all means this game is by and for the fans if you haven't played the other games ( 999 and Virtue Last reward ) you should not play this game, wait for a few months because 999 and virtues last reward are coming out for PC !!!!

The major diference from the other games is that it gets rid of the Visual novel style to a more cinematic aproach probably to appeal to the West.. unfortunatly it ends up feeling cheap and with such a low budget it really was a bad idea.

The game itself is about solving puzzle rooms and watching cutscenes and also making choices..

The main attracion here is the story and the characters.

Unfortunatly as I stated at the beginning the games ending is a huge let down, and is not at all as tight and epic and emotional as 999 and Virtues Last reward.

The twist are decent but not impressive and the ending is a horrible to say the least, you can see how they were constricted by budget and time.

The worst offended will be the people that come from Virtues Last reward and 999 fresh and start up immediatly Zero time dilemma they will see how low quality everything is, from the story to the characters.

The game was supposed to answer all the questions fans have in a big epic conclusion to a beloved series, but ends up feeling cheap and lazy.

in the game we play as 3 players divided in 3 teams.

Team D which was written by the creator,

Team C and Q which was written by some other people and it shows so so so much how bad the other teams are in comparision, Team Q especially suffers from 2 horrible characters and only 1 good one.

Returning characters are just not doing much at all, it feels like they are just there because they have too..

I think a big issue is the and it shows in VLR  in which ushikoshi spend 3 years planning and wirting hyping the 3rd part up so much that when the 3rd part was not greenlit he dropped it and when it was greenlit he rushed it too much.

The music as well is a huge let down compraed to the other 2 games...

with the epic songs being remakes from the last one...

In the end I enjoyed the game I wont lie, the puzzles are nice and fun and the beginning and mid story are great.

But the characters, the ending, the overall feeling of cheap budget and rushed story really left a sour taste in my mouth.

Buy this game if you are a fan and have played the other 2, if you havent played those DO NOT play this one as it spoils major plot points and great twist right at the start of the game.

It is still a good game but it is a mediocre zero escape game.

Score 7.5/10

Achievement Difficulty: 2/10 it's mostly story based and finding all files in every room which really isn't a huge challenge.

24116744.review:
Upon reaching the credits, a message saying that this game was meant for the fans, and without them, the project wouldn't have even existed. After experiencing this, it definitely and genuinely felt that way, and mastermind Uchikoshi did a wonderful job in wrapping the Zero Escape trilogy up.

I felt like this game had a constrained budget and had to do what it could given the dramatic direction that they wanted to pull for this. The TellTale-like, full cinema narrative ended up as quite engrossing, but still rough around the edges. When models are a bit constrained to samey lip-syncing and paired up with all-too convenient camera obscuring angles, it sometimes comes off as a bit cheesy. In the end it still was pretty awesome though.

However, that narrative style really shows how much the game, and even the entire trilogy, just loves committing information dumps, as tiring as it can get. Due to the new structure, this game refrains from doing it as much, but it's almost to a very, very draining point.

From a personal perspective, I keep finding that Uchikoshi relies on the same tropes and concepts throughout all his writing, so it kind of leaves me less excited or even easily predictable. However, I still enjoyed the ride, and his perspective to address the visual novel or choose-your-adventure medium is fascinating. I do enjoy how much this game builds up on both of the previous installments' points and moments, which makes it even more essential to read 999 and VLR.

But fans coming into this, and it's important since it really MAKES the experience to have read 999 and VLR --- if you're a fan, this conclusion to the trilogy is going to be very satisfying. With references to Back to the Future, Doctor Who, all the fanservice plug-ins, and tying the most vexing cliffhangers from before up, you'll be happier than one snug, Funyarinpa in a rug.

24115935.review:
Dernier épisode de la trilogie Zero Escape, ZTD est tout simplement incontournable afin de connaitre la raison des évènements survenus pendant Virtue's Last Reward. En plus de VLR, il est également conseillé de d'abord jouer à 999 sur Nintendo DS ou iOS afin de pouvoir comprendre toute l'histoire de l'équipe C. Bonne nouvelle, les deux jeux devraient être publiés sur Steam prochainement !

Concernant le jeu en lui même, il abandonne un peu le format Visual Novel pour un mode cut-scene / cinématique qui n'est pas sans rappeler les jeux Telltale. Ces scènes sont entrecoupées de puzzles, marque de fabrique de la série, qu'il faudra résoudre afin de s'échapper des diverses salles et récolter des indices qui feront progresser l'histoire. Les puzzles en eux-même sont en demie teinte par rapport à VLR: beaucoup plus faciles et malheureusement répétitifs. 

Se reposant sur le concept des mondes parallèles introduit dans VLR, il est possible de faire dans n'importe quel ordre les différentes scènes disponibles pour chaque équipe (visualisées sur un grand flowchart). L'histoire principale prend forme au fur et à mesure et les informations récoltées dans une histoire pourront être utilisées afin de débloquer la situation dans une autre réalité. J'ai fini le jeu à 100% en 20h quasi tout rond.

En conclusion, à conseiller les yeux fermés pour tous ceux qui ont fait 999 et VLR et meurent d'envie de connaitre le fin mot de cette trilogie ! Pour les autres je conseillerai d'attendre leur sortie sur Steam afin de ne pas se spoiler l'histoire inutilement.

24115685.review:
Great way to end the trilogy while not entirely ruling out a 4th game.
 
Just a few issues with it:

-The facial expressions and animations are pretty bad. You can tell they tried to fix it by using camera angles that point towards the ceiling during some dialogue, but it doesnt mask the fact that the animations were very subpar. This gets a bit of a pass from me since aksys was trying to do something different on a fairly low budget. The game would have been better as more of a VN with some 3D animations like VLR was, but props for trying something new.

-The dub is worse than VLR. In VLR there was only one voice I didnt like (clover). Whereas ZTD has several bad choices. Akane and Eric are pretty Bad. Junpei and Diana have their moments where they fit perfectly, but other times they sound very out of place. Props to Matt Mercer and Karen Strassman for their performances as sigma and phi, as well as D.C. Douglas' outstanding performance as zero, which were head and shoulders above everyone else.

-The story was great as a self contained narrative, but in doing so they clearly retconned a bunch of stuff from VLR. I wont tell you which, but I will advise you to try not to be too disappointed if you don't have all your questions answered. On the bright side ZTD asks a bunch of new questions and answers them beautifully. So please go in with an open mind, and get ready to have it blown the fuck away.

PS: Play 999 and VLR first, its not mandatory to understand ZTD but they're great games and this game will spoil the fuck out of them in the first 2 hours.

[spoiler] 新人物里如果说zero有毒,E和M就是有病。万恶之源Mira以一个令人说不出话的理由导致这一连串悲剧的发生,zero不断强调女人和蜗牛的那个故事让人错认为他希望复仇,在游戏过程中M也各种痛下杀手，真结局里大家却手拉手迈向美好明天,说好的血仇呢？M情商低,E则是智商低...轻信,懦弱,只会一味把过错推给他人,可沾上血迹最多的不是冷血女杀手而是软饭男,一言不合就拿枪杀队友不加考虑,玩家还不得不与其周旋...是的,两位都被安排有自己的苦衷，可这不是人物如此有病的理由...顺带一提C是亮点，hero得恰到好处，都是新人差距怎么这么大呢？	[/spoiler]
[spoiler] SHIFT作为核心内容各人理解不同,不方便评论...有一点是肯定的,意识穿越代表坑了另一个历史的自己..所谓好结局建立在多少牺牲之上？有点嘲讽	[/spoiler]

说到底还是强行的锅,强行走完每一条线,强行让玩家做违心的抉择,,强行引入不明所以的概念,强行人物关系和动机合理化,强行给事件找理由,又在剧情发展不下去的时候强行摆出剧情锁或是冷酷的game over.好比RPG中无理取闹的空气墙,别无选择的剧情杀。可因为你是玩家,你要对一切负责,你忍受一切玩下去才能了解真相....游戏体验实在是糟糕至极点。所以打完这个游戏也是强撑着的,从开始的满怀期待到只想全成就走人...媒体反响倒是不错,或许是因为没打完吧

对慕名而来的新人热情推荐[极限脱出 9时间9人9门]

PS:思索许久这一作令我如此反感的point在哪里,不只是各方评测过多的吹捧导致预期过美好...
一款好游戏可以是轻松愉快的，引人深思的，可以是令人恐惧困惑，甚至弥漫绝望氛围的。但前提是玩家愿意玩下去,愿意接受这一切走向结局——抱歉，ZTD的表现更像是劝退，对玩家太不友好了.个人感情，仅供参考

24108344.review:
I'm just gonna add my own points and thoughts about the game.
Great Story, perhaps not quite as good as the first 2 installments but still amazing.
Great characters, each has a distinct personality and are memorable, especially if you were invested in the characters from the previous instalments.
The puzzles were interesting to varying degrees. You can tell some puzzle rooms are much more well thought out than others. Difficulty also varies from easy to challenging. 

One of the things I love about this series is the way they smoothly mesh actual science, theoretical science/ pseudo-science and science fiction. This game does not dissapoint there. It made me search stuff up so thats a plus (?).
Also, this series is the only game I play with a pen and paper to write notes down. There is an in-game memo pad, but writing in that is like trying to write with a wet bar of soap especially if you're using controller.

Instead of the 'smack in the face' mind blowing plot twists that I experience playing the first 2 games, this game had me realise where the story was going as clues were fed to me. Although there were a few surprises. [spoiler] Although I sortof felt that some of the twists had been done by the previous 2 games. [/spoiler]

[strike] The ending was alright, but it left me slightly hanging about the details of what happens to characters. [spoiler] One thing that nags at me is Mira. What happens to her? Does she just get away? She is a psychopathic serial killer and many of the characters at the end knew she was a psychopathic serial killer :/ [/spoiler] [/strike]
Edit: Turns out there were additional notes added after you complete the game talking about the details of what happens to characters :D

I agree that the animations are clunky and it seems the devs realised this so they try their best to minimise animations with cinematography tricks that obscures parts of the model or do stuff off screen. The character models are good though. I would've been happy with still images so I don't really have much complaints and the rest of the game is good enough to make this the worst complaint I have.
This game did make me think a full professionally animated visual novel would be amazing though. Sortof like an interactive anime.

All in all, Great game, great story, good twists, stuff makes sense, great characters, japanese voice acting was great (I didn't play it with english voices) and decent/ great puzzles. Apparently, they're planning on releasing the first 2 games on PC as well, which makes me really happy because this will allow others to play and experience the wonders of Zero Escape.

24102422.review:
Zero Escape: Zero Time Dilemma is the conclusion to the Zero Escape series (the other games in the series include "Nine Hours, Nine Persons, Nine Doors" and "Virtue's Last Reward". This game consists of cut-scenes/visual novel parts, and puzzle solving components, and is generally about nine people and a dog trying to find a way out of an underground shelter, with escape rooms, that they are trapped in. Playing the previous games of the Zero Escape series is highly recommended since there are many recurring characters from previous games, and many references to the previous games.

Story: The story is laid out so that you watch/play fragments of the story from the perspective of different characters/teams at different points in time, similar to puzzle pieces, and you piece the fragments together to get the whole story. I found this way of presenting the story to be effective since it makes it easier to connect with the characters since their memory is usually erased in every fragment. I liked how may loose ends in this story and the story of the previous games were connected and explained but I feel there are still a lot of loose ends and too many Deus Ex Machinas were used; it seemed really random how special super-advanced technology that no one in that universe has heard of/knows about would randomly be found, and how the antagonist would just happen to have a special ability. Compared to the plot of the rest of the games in the series, I would say this game has the weakest plot. Although there were some components of the plot that were based on facts and pseudo-science, I felt disappointed since there were a lot fewer components compared to the other games in the series. Overall, I would rate the story 7.5/10 since there's a plot twist I did not really notice until a bonus ending was revealed, otherwise 6.5/10 without that plot twist.

Characters: The characters were great. Each had their own detailed backstory and each character was unique in their own way.  The personality of each character really reflected the past experiences mentioned in their backstory and matched the plots of the previous games in the series for returning characters. Overall, I would rate the characters 9/10.

Artwork/Graphics: The artwork was great. Most rooms in the game were pretty detailed. For a VN/puzzle game, the graphics are great. Nothing to complain about, except, maybe, use different models for the characters that are forced to live on minimal food for 10 months. Great artwork/graphics overall, 8.5/10.

Music/Sound: Music and sound effects were excellent. I liked how they reused the soundtrack from the previous games for emotional scenes relating to the returning characters. Really catchy music and nothing to complain about the sound effects. The voice actors were also great, nothing to complain about, except I would prefer having al lthe same voice actors from VLR for the returning characters. 9/10.

Puzzles: The puzzles were too easy compared to the other games in the series. I was rarely stumped for any of the puzzles and there were fewer puzzles in this game compared to the other games in the serious. I would rate the puzzles 7/10.

Overall: I would rate this game 8/10. Good story, excellent characters, graphics and music. I’m glad they made the last game of the trilogy but I feel there are too many Deus Ex Machinas used. There's an amazing plot twist though.

24100843.review:
The game itself, for what it is, is fine. It's a more poorly executed 999/VLR. 

The animations are clunky, almost to the point that they shouldn't have included them and just went back to the VN style of 999. Most of the "action" happens off-screen, not for the Tarantino-effect, but becuase the animators were doing such a terrible job that they just removed all complex animations from the game by moving the camera away. 

All of the story "mechanics" of 999/VLR (read: [spoiler]Morphogenetic fields, multiple timelines, etc.[/spoiler]) are used here to the point of losing their "wow" factor and as a "basic" game mechanic rather than a narrative strength. 

The puzzle mechanics range from "yeah that makes sense" to "panty-twistingly obnoxious developer-mind-reading nonsense." Some puzzles you will see how to solve them and go "ugh, I don't have time for that," and just look up the solution. 

The new characters are basically pointless except for one, and even that one is kind of a letdown in the end. 

The only good thing about this game are the "moments" in some of the scenarios, and if you look at this game as its "vignette"-style single story nuggets, they're not "bad" per say, but put them all together and you may find yourself annoyed by the time you're done. 

::WARNING: SPOILERS FOR 999/VLR/ZTD AHEAD::

If you have played 999/VLR and was hoping this game would give you answers on/dive deeper into:
[spoiler]
Free the Soul
The Moon
K/?

Radical-6

[/spoiler]

Then sorry... you won't get much clarity, and what's given will just upset you and get you mad at the game.  

The game's ending itself [spoiler]basically wipes out the existence[/spoiler] of one game and [spoiler]completely ignores[/spoiler] the other. 

If you've played the other two games in the series, then you'll probably get this, you might even like it... I didn't... not really. It wasn't the worst... but ultimately disappointing... which makes me sad.  I LOVED the first two.

24100458.review:
Wow... Just, wow.

This was a game. I have been with this series since just before VLR came out and to see it finally reach its conclusion was an extremely satisfying experience. 

I was suprised when I first heard this was coming to Steam but was extremly excited to finally play Zero Escape in HD. But enough about that, onto the game itself. 

The first thing I should stress (although I feel like its pointless to say since everyone else is saying it but oh well) is that people should probably play 999 and VLR (virtue's last reward) before jumping in here. Zero Escape focus has always been on its narrative, and although the developers do their best to not put in spoilers, inevitibly plot points from both previous games (999 to a lesser extent but VLR extensivly) are revealed and the player risks missing context or spoiling the major twists of those games if they play this first. The most major of these being the lack of connection to the already established characters and thus not being able to experience the story to a full extent. Luckily for those who don't own a 3ds (999 was exclusivly on ds, VLR on 3ds and Vita) remasters have been announced for steam so soon enough players should have easy access to all 3 games.

I suppose I should mention my problems with the game since it is not perfect, Unfourtunetly we have to once again sit through clunky and strange animations, but honestly compared to VLR this game is nothing and after playing through that this really didn't bug me at all. Also, I understand story was the main focus of this game but the lack of "escape" sections in this game is very noticible, especially compared to VLR which had numerous "escape" sections while still keeping its complex and compelling narrative. It seems their awnser to this was to make the sections in this game very unclear as to what the player had to do at some points, and this would have been fine if they hadn't removed the hint system from VLR which could help people figure out the solutions themselves without spoiling themselves to the whole escape section and runing the only gameplay sections this game has. 

Despite this I can honestly not reccomend this game enough. Like VLR the clunky animations are more then made up for by the steller voice acting that was on point the entire game. The story is immersive enough to warrent a pass on the lack of balence with gamplay. The "Decision Game" was a nice change from the usual Zero Escape formula of 9 ruling everything, and it was nice that your decisions actually had a major impact on the overall story, an improvment over the last game's attempt. I was unsure of the 3-team formula (for lack of character interaction) and fragment style storytelling (lack of chronology) but they both ended up working out quite well, the former providing comepelling tight knit inclusive stories that made me care about each character, the later allowing for me to learn things out of order and context and simply fueled my interest further into how some of the things that I saw happened, only for me to have plenty of "OHHHH, SO THAT'S WHAT THAT WAS ABOUT" moments throughout the game.

I have one major complaint to vent about, it does not even pretain to the game or gameplay, but rather what happens after you complete both of these things. Warning: I don't devulge any details here but some might consider this spoilers so I am moving my point to another paragraph so people can skip over if they don't want to be spoiled.

After you complete the game, the creators were nice enough to enclude little "epilouge" stories in the form of files that provide aftermaths for each of the characters..... with the exception of 3 members, all from the same team. This frusturated me especially because this was my favourite team to follow throughout the whole game and to not see an ending for them is dissapointing to say the least considering the author has already stated this is the last game in the series. However, the writer of the story always does an extensive Q and A in the months following the release of these games in order to awnser any questions people might have (as the games can be quite confusing) and this is sure to be brought up so I am looking forward to his response.

Overall, this was a really good game. It served its purpose of tying up the loose ends of the previous two games while simoultainiously remaining its own game and having an interesting and compelling self-contained story. Although there were some problems, honestly the are negligible in the grand scheme of things and easy enough to look past as the rest of game more than makes up for it. For anyone who has never played the prevous games or games like this before know this, its like SAW, but with a good story, and if you appeciate story in games, you will enjoy this series.

9/10
+Good story that tidies up loose ends from previous games while still having its own self-contained narrative
+HD graphics, a first for the series
+Voice-acting and writing as high of quality as they have always been (pretty damn high)
+Decisions you make in this game WILL matter
+Puzzles require you to actually think
-Clunky animations (better than VLR's though)
-Although still present, gameplay is clearly put to the side to focus on story, something the previous games seemed to have no problems balencing very well
-"Escape" segments sometimes unclear what they want you to do or figure out
-Some problems with the epilouges (personal nitpick honestly, some might not care but it really bugs me)

24099082.review:
As a huge fan of the past 2 Zero Escape games, I was thrilled to hear that the supposed last game in the series was finally being made. It's out and all I can say is, Spike Chunsoft, Aksys Games, and Kotaro Uchikoshi have made one of the best endings to a trilogy of games, movies, books, or anything in the history of media. 

The story is complex, characters are filled with development, the puzzle rooms are gloriously challenging, and writing is superb throughout. It's a game that will interest you from the moment and starts and may even make you a little misty eyed by the time the game shows you it's true ending.

The layout of the game is wholey unique and done expertly. Jumping between different storylines back and forth can be jarring at first but, it all fits together in a way towards the end that no other game ever has done before. All questions that you wanted answered from the past 2 games will be answered. Only major problem is the presentation of the game. The animations look pretty cheap which could be blamed on a small budget and the facial animations almost never match up with what emotion is supposedly being portrayed. 

Overall: An incredible and flawed masterpiece that needs to be experienced. Pick it up NOW! 10/10

24094254.review:
My friends were on about this series a couple of months before the release of this game, so I sat down and played through 999. And as someone who's enjoyed Danganronpa and other visual novels of this style I was pleasantly surprised, so without hesitation I got Virtue's Last Reward and of course enjoyed that.

 What I'm trying to say is, if you want to pick up this series. Play the other games first beforehand: Not only to understand what the hell is happening in this game but to also see if you enjoy the series first, since a lot of reading isn't everyone's cup of tea.

A friend of mine compared it to Telltale's kind of games, it's not so much Telltale as a choose your own adventure type of game, which goes for all the games in the series. The game splits choices into a handy flowchart so you can "SHIFT" between them with puzzle elements which are a bit dumbed compared to the other games but don't hinder the story at all. It's a very story rich game and I'd recommend picking up the other games beforehand, which are coming on PC too soon. If you can't wait pick up the first two.

As a guy who's recently gotten into this series I've really enjoyed it and say if you like Danganronpa, Phoenix Wright and other visual novels you'll enjoy this, just prepare for a lot of sci-fi mumbo-jumbo and a lot of confusion.

24092774.review:
9 Hours, 9 Persons, 9 Doors (il capitolo 1) è il mio videogioco nonché romanzo preferito, parto con questa premessa. Zero Time Dilemma conclude la serie, quindi vi consiglio caldamente a giocare i primi due capitoli prima di cimentarvi in questo (pare che presto usciranno su Steam).

Che dire, che dire... dei tre è probabilmente il capitolo che mi è piaciuto meno, ma comunque un buon 7-7,5 su 10 se lo porta a casa. Gli enigmi continuano ad essere interessanti e mai frustranti, un buon contorno per la storia che la fa da padrona in questa esperienza. Il gioco si completa in circa 20-25 ore. L'inizio mi è parso molto dispersivo, si continua a passare da una scena all'altra, da un gruppetto di persone all'altro forsennatamente e con alcuni pattern che si ripetono... superato questo scoglio iniziale, però, inizia la parte succosa vera e propria che, come tradizione della serie, è appassionante e ricca di spunti di filosofia, scienze (fisica, statistica, psicologia, neuroscienze, intelligenza artificiale, ...) ben inseriti.

Ho apprezzato l'avere le animazioni in 3D e tutto doppiato, in stile Telltale o Life is Strange (più simile ai primi la qualità della grafica, nulla di eccezionale insomma, ma godibile). Le animazioni purtroppo spesso sono carenti.

Il livello di mindfuck ovviamente è elevato come al solito :P purtroppo avendo giocato i primi due ci sono molte cose che si possono intuire con largo anticipo.

Insomma complessivamente è un gioco che ha tanti tentennamenti ma che racconta una bellissima storia che appassionerà chiunque apprezzi un certo insieme di cose (paradossi temporali, filosofia, intelligenza artificiale, meccanica quantistica e via dicendo).

Ah, ho pianto solo una volta, a differenza delle copiose lacrime riversate in più occasioni nel 2, e in meno occasioni ma molto sentite nell'1 :S

24091691.review:
First of all, if you are even remotely interested in this game and you have not played 9 Hours, 9 Persons, 9 Doors and Virtue's Last Reward, please play those first to understand the plot and learn about the returning characters.

So for those who have played 999 and VLR, getting this game is a no brainer, but I'll try to explain what's new and what to expect without revealing spoilers.

The technology is evolved compared to VLR which only had a few pre-rendered animated cutscenes, and the realtime 3D character models were only used for speech. In ZTD all characters are rendered realtime for cutscenes and regular speech. This means they realistically walk, gesture, and interact with the environment at all times. All characters are voiced everywhere except during room escapes.

The downside, however, is that despite the technology improvements, it still pales in comparison to similar PC games. The texture resolutions are low, the quality of sound effects is poor, and the English voice acting is awkward in some places. I especially didn't like Zero's voice, as the distortion applied to it made it very hard to hear against the music.

On the plus sides, the music is still good, and let's face it, we're playing this for the awesome plot! So what can you expect from the plot compared to 999 and VLR?

Since you may have read that the premise involves characters dying in order to escape, this game discards the hand-holding of rules penalties and launches right into making you make harsh decisions that swiftly and callously kill people, before you even encounter a single escape room.

When you do begin encountering the escape rooms, you'll find the challenge to be pretty steady, with a few head scratchers that call for some deep logic and note taking. No disappointments here.

And of course the last thing is how the characters fight back. With 999 gently introducing the concept of alternate realities and VLR developing it into a decision tree, ZTD takes the concept to extremes with lots of reality-altering shenanigans. In VLR you made decisions and followed the tree as far down as you could go, where in ZTD it is more episodic. You make one set of decisions, and then that fragment of story reaches a conclusion or cliffhanger, and you are invited to continue that branch later on with a different group. This is a bit jarring in the beginning since it's hard to keep track of when you are in the story, and what decisions were already made. The characters, however, are equally disoriented, so you will get used to it.

Overall great game to conclude the Zero Escape series.

24089633.review:

24081054.review:
After finally finishing this, I can say, as a person who has 100% completed the previous two games, this is the perfect game to end it all.

[b]TL;DR[/b]: If you have played the previous games, this is unquestionably a must-play.

[h1]Introduction[/h1]

Zero Escape is a Japanese Escape Room Puzzle game series, which includes Choose-Your-Adventure Visual Novel type of story telling. While the puzzles will take the majority of your play time (unless you're a super genius), the main meat of the game is definitely the story and the characters. [spoiler]The story itself is a form of puzzle as well.[/spoiler] Zero Time Dilemma is the last of the trilogy, and while it can be played as a standalone, It WILL leave you with questions. It will also lessen the impact of the story of previous games, so please play them in the "correct" order.

[h1]The Good[/h1]

While there weren't as many puzzle rooms as VLR or 999, they were still as complex, if not more complex than previously, and as varied as ever. I'd say that each puzzle room took me from 15 minutes for the more straightforward ones, and up to 1 hour for the really weird ones. They were all REALLY fun. Even if I got frustrated, I always ended up enjoying the puzzles after finally solving them. I did not need walkthroughs for these, but a pen and paper were a must.

Lots of paradoxical and philosophical thinking, VERY out-of-the-world mysteries[spoiler]out-of-the-dimension mysteries[/spoiler], and overall great story and characters. This is also true for the new characters, even if Eric is annoying almost all of the time. They all get great backgrounds, and they are very well included into the story of the returning cast.

[h1]The Bad[/h1]

One thing that didn't come up, was alternate solutions to puzzles[spoiler](For Golden Files in VLR, and True Ending in 999)[/spoiler]. And there were few moments when I didn't even see what I was clicking for progression, and a very few moments where I even started randomly clicking things.

While the visual quality and style is amazing (in fact, I like it more than the beautiful 2d of 999), the 3d animation is lacking. The same animations get reused constantly, lipsync is almost non-existent and those few unique animations you see sometimes, are a bit lacking. Still miles better than VLR.

The ending is a very slight cliffhanger. I say that it's that kind of a cliffhanger as to be even good, but I know some who would hate it.

[h1]The End[/h1]

After this splendid finale, I can whole-heartedly say: [b]This is my #1 videogame series of all time![/b] Every loose end got cut, and all the questions (that I had) got answered, and the puzzles were mostly amped up in difficulty. As a sequel and a finale, it fills all the check marks and then some, and that's all I could ever ask for.

24076633.review:
The long awaited ending to the Zero Escape trilogy arrives, and it's damn good. It's highly recommended to additionally play 999 and Virtue's Last Reward, though it is possible to enjoy Zero Escape: Zero Time Dilemma (ZTD) as a standalone story, then play the other two games as sort of a "backstory" later. If you read nothing else in this review, just know that.

Zero Escape, as a series, is a prime example of how to write a true mystery thriller story. It keeps the reader guessing and doubting to ridiculous degrees with all the twists, but in the end every major plot point has its place in an overarching storyline and every character plays their part. It's notable that the writer (Kotaro Uchikoshi) sticks to the established rules of his world and story; a keen observer will see painstaking attention to consistency.
Reiterating, the similar and popular Danganronpa, a title which left a sour taste and huge disappointment for me, had big issues with contrivances and downright [i]random[/i] things that were introduced as simple one-time plot devices, as well as how disjointed the story felt from one chapter to the next. This is not the case with ZTD, where each plot element is important and is resolved. Things don't randomly happen; everything has relevance. A player finds themself constantly contemplating each new revelation, no matter how innocuous, because nothing is throwaway. Considering ZTD builds upon two preceding games, what we have is simply masterful writing. Additionally, it is worth noting that the characters are all quite fleshed out and well-written. The player will be spending a lot of time learning more about them as the story progresses, and there is much to learn.

As for the gameplay, it's simple. You are given a menu to view various segments of the story. The structure of these segments comprise of a cutscene, then a decision (that has a real impact on plot) and/or an "escape room" (a series of puzzles to find an exit), then another cutscene. Progression happens when the player has enough knowledge from various segments to overcome a dilemma which previously posed as an obstacle.
Due to the nature of the narrative, it can become difficult to follow the plot sequentially, but ZTD provides a handy in-game flowchart to help the player understand the chronology of events. Speaking of which, I did find the introductory segment of the game a bit repetitive, as I needed to view a scenario many times from different perspectives, but it's ultimately a necessary foundation for everything that ensues; an investment which paid dividends.
A weak point of ZTD, however, is a somewhat poor presentation, most notably stemming from relatively janky animation quality in the cutscenes; this is most noticeable in scenes with heavy action. A large part of one's enjoyment of ZTD is the ability to accept this. I, personally, was able to get past this, as the animations worked well enough to convey the events as they occured.

In summary, Zero Escape: Zero Time Dilemma, despite a rough presentation, achieves excellence in storytelling. It has a lofty ambition to intrigue the player to learn the truth behind the mysteries, and it undeniably succeeds. Whenever the player thinks "I figured it out!", a plot twist occurs and dashes those expectations again and again until the player is confused and mentally exhausted, and it is at this point ZTD lays everything out. It is at this point everything comes together, everything makes sense, for a satisfying conclusion.

24070876.review:
The finale is here, and it did not disappoint. Not often do I come across a game that makes me say "holy shit" out loud, multiple times.

Mr. Kotaro Uchikoshi continues to impress and delight/horrify with more engaging puzzles, convoluted plot, mindbending conspiracies, and unfortunate death and dismemberment with his final entry to the Zero Escape series. While similar to the others in style and concept, Zero Time Dilemma still carries enough uniqueness to make it as enjoyable as the others. Overall, I feel that ZTD is an improvement over the previous title, VLR, with better animations, better character designs and dialogue, better audio/soundtracks, and a true ending that isn't full of plot holes.

I have a couple minor complaints. ZTD felt like it was a tiny bit shorter then the previous titles, with 7 endings instead of 9, and fewer, easier puzzles, lacking a challenging endgame puzzle. I'm also a bit sad that the gripping, vivid descriptions of 999 were replaced with cheesy 3D animation in VLR and ZTD. For that reason, 999, the first game, will always be my favorite in the series. But these small issues are overshadowed by greatness in other fields.

I also want to say that Spike Chunsoft porting their games to PC has been the greatest thing since, well, ever. And now I get to play one of my favorite series without having to resort to shitty handhelds or obtuse emulators.

24066783.review:
My feelings about this game are very complex. On one hand, I enjoyed it very much and found that its flaws didn't really dampen the experience as a whole for me. On the other, I can't really give it an unconditional recommendation.

Let me start off by saying that if you are already a fan of the Zero Escape series, you've already played and finished this game - so really, what are you looking in the reviews for now? If you are considering whether to get into the series, the answer is that of course you should - go play 999 and VLR right now!

As for ZTD itself, it is not without its issues. The good, however, is very good - (mostly) good characters with complex motivations, an interesting plot full of timey wimey and quantum theory bull shit. The story is not perfect by any means; some plot elements are wavering near asspull territory, and some characters lack sufficient characterization, development or a reason to be in the story. The way the story is framed and presented is on the whole very innovative, as the story is told in independent fragments that can (and often must) be played out of order, taking advantage of the medium to tell a story that wouldn't have necessarily worked as a film or book. At some points, you need to do some unintuitive stuff in order to progress the plot, which you wouldn't necessarily know unless someone else told you, and there's a few moments of tedium through the course of the game, but on the whole, the writing and presentation are pretty good - I wish there was bit more banter and fleshing out, and that the story was a bit more meaty on the whole, but on the whole I would say that it's a good and fitting conclusion to the trilogy that I enjoyed greatly.

Now, I have two big qualms with the game. The first is mostly technical - I've had to deal with constant bugs and crashes throughout the whole thing. The interface is clearly designed with a controller in mind and few concessions towards M/KB input - it does work and I played through the whole game in this fashion, but you still can't rebind keys, input text through your keyboard (you instead use your mouse to press keys on your screen), or even get M/KB button prompts - it's all Xbox controller stuff, and you don't even have a helpful guide as to which key does what besides trial and error. While not really a technical issue, it must be said that the animations are just plain awful. It's not really a deal breaker, but everything looks cheap at best and comical at worst (or is it the other way around?) The models themselves are rather pretty and well made, a few low-res textures aside, and the environments are completely acceptable (with the same caveat). Unlike others, I haven't had any framerate issues, but given the bugs and crashes, I don't know if that's enough to recommend this version of the game over the 3DS or Vita versions (which I have not played.)

My second big issue is that Carlos will never be real.

Altogether, I give this game a solid 8.5/10.

24065528.review:
This game is like Mass Effect 3. It's an amazing game, but its prequels were so good that they make this game almost disappointing. Nevertheless, it's worth your money.

Zero Escape 1, AKA 999: 9 Hours 9 Persons 9 Doors, was a masterpiece. Its story is one of the best in video gaming history. It was clever, suspenseful, and full of mysteries and twists. If you like mysteries, you gotta get 999 if you can. It's available on DS right now (iOS too, but we don't talk about the iOS version. Don't get the iOS version), and it should be coming to Steam soon. Zero Escape 2, AKA Virtue's Last Reward, was also a masterpiece. It gave us another equally brilliant plot on top of good quality of life changes like a flowchart that you can use to jump to any part of the story you've seen, skipping the stuff you've already read. It's available on 3DS and Vita, and should be coming to Steam after 999 does.

These two games set a very high standard for Zero Escape 3, Zero Time Dilemma, to uphold. And just like Mass Effect 3, it was doing very good at first. I was almost ready to call it my favorite Zero Escape game. Its story was great so far and it held my attention. Its puzzles were already much better than those of the previous Zero Escape games, being more creative and challenging. But then it Mass Effect 3ed.

For those who don't remember, Mass Effect 3's ending was atrocious. Zero Time Dilemma's final act was silimar. The ending itself was good, but it left many unanswered questions. Many of them were from 999 and Virtue's Last Reward, and I guess I'm OK with them not elaborating on details of previous Zero Escape games to avoid confusing newcomers, but some of them came from Zero Time Dilemma itself. My guess is that they ran out of money; it's pretty obvious they were short on money given the poor graphics/animations. I suppose we'll have to wait for a Q&A to hear the answer to our questions.

Ultimately, Zero Time Dilemma's incomplete ending prevented it from being as great as 999 and Virtue's Last Reward. As they say though, it's the journey that matters and not the end, and Zero Time Dilemma had an amazing "journey" just like Mass Effect 3. For this reason, I still loved Zero Time Dilemma. If you're a Zero Escape fan, I think you'll end up loving it too. If you're not a Zero Escape fan, you should pick up 999 on the DS if you have one or on Steam when it comes out. You could jump straight into Zero Time Dilemma, but a lot of the game's twists are better if you've played 999 and Virtue's Last Reward. Once you've played through 999 and Virtue's Last Reward, I would say that this game is definitely worth playing.

TL;DR: 8.5/10

When, what feels like an eternity ago, I was introduced to the, at the time, nearly unknown to the world game of 999, it was nothing short of a revelation. Having just opened my eyes to the existence of platforms other than PC, I did have certain expectations of there being some great games I would never play otherwise. And yet, how could I expect them to be fulfilled so thoroughly?

Suffice it to say, Morphogenetic Sorrow filled my days. It might've been slightly harder than what I was used to, in both the puzzles and interface, but... On some level, 999 did something scarcely any other medium has ever managed to accomplish with me.

It actually brought an emotion to my eye. With every second of a story unraveling in front of my eyes, I was reminded of those days I thought long forgotten, of that sacred moment when I launched that very first game of Broken Sword for the first time and had my perception of the medium forever changed.

But I digress.

When Virtue's Last Reward came about, t'was the purest of sufferings, for another console was needed. It took me a year.

Worth every day and penny.

And now, game three is afoot.

You know, I happen to have a friend on Steam. He never heard anything about 999 or Virtue's Last Reward and haven't even pressed on this game's name on Steam. He had absolutely no reason to be interested, much less buy it. And yet he did buy it, and merely two days after my own purchase, to boot.

Do you want to know why?

Because for the past two days, he has been seeing me playing this game without rest.

And I don't think I wasted a single second.

24062737.review:
Zero Time Dilemma takes you on a wild ride that takes more or less 15 to 20 hours to complete. 

The overall structure of the game can be a bit disorienting at first but once you fully grasp how it works it makes for a very interesting narrative. The plot has some really strong and emotional moments. The twists felt less crazy compared to the last game but they are still pretty effective, though one in particular won't be liked by everyone.

I played the game with the Japanese voice acting and I felt it was good, even if there was some overacting in some parts.

The music as always are really good, going from really soft and emotional melodies to the more somber and goosebumbs inducing tunes. A lot of them are remixes from the past games, but the new ones are as great as the old.

The art style is okay, it's nothing special and looking at the promotional artworks it's pretty generic, but it's good enough for the budget the game had, the problem resides more in the animations. Well, more like the lack of animation in certain scenes. Again it's okay for the budget it had but it's a bit of a shame considering the game went in a more "cinematic" direction.

The Escape Rooms are really fun overall. It's maybe just a feeling but I felt there was more than in the previous games, which is nice. Don't expect to be always playing in this game though, there will be a lot of time where you're basically just watching a movie.

ZTD will probably disappoint some of the most hardcore fans of the series, but despite the flaws it has in different aspects, it's still a great experience and I'm eager to see what Uchikoshi will come up with next.

24052974.review:
A very powerfully wrotten and designed adventure game, this is an excellent example of how thrillers with sci-fi elements can make their mark. Zero Time Dilemma is actually the third and last installment in the Zero Escape series, following Nine Hours, Nine Persons, Nine Doors and Virtue's Last Reward (both are currently unavailable on Steam, and were originally released for the Nintendo DS and 3DS respectively). These visual novels or adventure games involve people getting abducted by a mysterious masked entity calling themselves Zero, and then being forced to participate in deadly games that put their lives on the line. 

Determining how and why this is happening is the key objective of all these games, with replayability in fact being a critical way of getting all the answers. This does have the downside of basically exhausting all the game's content by the time you're fully satisfied with it, as aside from the jigsaw puzzle narrative, the only other major component of Zero Time Dilemma is its elaborate "escape the room" puzzles that, despite some hiccups here and there, provide an excellent challenge and reward patience and critical thinking. Nonetheless, it is a very engaging and compelling experience while it lasts.

The developers clearly made a conscious effort to ensure that Zero Time Dilemma could be enjoyed as a standalone experience, as all the basic plot points connecting the series together are explicitly laid out, and you shouldn't be too confused about the basic plot by the time it's all over. As a result, a lot of the characters and plot threads from prior games are either marginalized or dropped entirely. This, in addition to the drastic changes in character designs and presentation (not all of them for the better) could make this a somewhat jarring experience for people familiar with the earlier games. However, I'd still strongly recommend playing or looking up the prior Zero Escape games in order to gain a deeper understanding of the series universe (or shall I say, multiverse, *wink* *wink*) as well as the backstories of several key characters that will help you understand them a lot better. I myself watched Let's Plays and read wiki entries on Zero Escape before buying this game, and they played a huge role in shaping the way I experienced it.

All in all, this is a fundamentally sound and entertaining thriller that will keep you thinking long after you're done with it, and though it's far from a perfect game, I highly recommend it if there's room in your budget for the price tag.

24052437.review:
*黑色部分可能含有1、2、3代剧透，慎点！*
Zero：我们来玩一个Decision Game吧，以下有两个按钮，“推荐”和“不推荐”，你会选择哪个呢？

按照我攻略的习惯，我会从我感觉会指向Bad End的选项开始，所以第一次我选择了“不推荐”。
选好了以后，小伙伴们都惊讶地问我：“你为什么做出这么蠢的决定？作为一个春社（Spike Chunsoft）粉，你哪根筋抽了要选择不推荐，而且ZE3这个游戏的谜题、配音、剧情都很优秀，和前作有密切的联系，密室也很好玩，为什么会有不推荐的情况发生？”我支支吾吾地说着：“我…我不知道……”但其实坐在电脑前的我，只是好奇想看看这个结局会发生什么而已。
结局就是，我被其他极限脱出系列的粉丝以及围观群众殴打致死，屏幕上显示出Bad End字样。

然后我[spoiler]使用了SHIFT能力回到了过去，[/spoiler]改成了推荐，这下大多数小伙伴露出了满意的表情，但是少数粉丝仍然不满意：“你为什么不说这个游戏的建模和画面不尽人意、[spoiler]前作某些“特别受关注”的坑竟然不填、[/spoiler]有的时候有BGM掉线的Bug？”然后一枪崩了我。我万万没想到[spoiler]这个游戏对方出牌竟然总和我是反着的[/spoiler]又得到一个Bad End。
于是我看见有一个新选项解锁了，我点了推荐然后小心翼翼地写了些理客中的评价，[spoiler]并且给群众解释我已经看到其他结局了你们不要再和我反着选了，你们是不是也能穿越啊？[/spoiler]终于解锁了一个结局。
于是我通关了游戏：Steam脱出3：评测困境。
---------------------------------------------------
小剧场结束了，我个人当然极力推荐，因为瑕不掩瑜！再说考虑到这一作差点就没办法呈现在我们面前，所以大家还是对于画面和建模之类的东西降低一点标准，剧情和密室都很好玩的！
最后我看各种评论里都提到了建议通关前作，我也同意，因为如果你通关了这一作觉得非常好玩（我相信这发生的概率很大），再回去玩前作的时候就少了很多乐趣，等于少了两部精彩的作品可以玩！另外按照顺序通关极限脱出系列有助于理解系列剧情[spoiler]以及打越套路[/spoiler]。

Zero：你再以这样的风格写评测，吃枣药丸

24040729.review:
Before playing this game, It is advisable to play or watch both previous Zero Escape titles.

I thought that ZTD was a great game. Not perfect, but certainly better than average and worth playing. The best way I can rate it is by comparing it to its prequel, Virtue's Last Reward.

On the plus side, ZTD completely drops text narration. In my opinion, this is better than being half of a Visual Novel like VLR, because once you voice the dialogue you are left with perfunctory narration that simply describes routine actions. Seeing those actions animated gives you more time to see the story and character development and less time reading about someone reaching into their pocket or furrowing their brow. ZTD only reverts to text conversations during puzzle rooms, where you wouldn't want to wait for the VO lines anyway. Also [i]blessedly[/i] absent are VLR's constant shoehorned bad attempts at wordplay ("jellyfast", "hoption"). Characters joke with each other occasionally but the jokes are never really awkward.

It's also nice to have static teams who have a general interest in working together. VLR's characters felt unrealistic because of how willing they were to directly cause the deaths of most or all the other players. This is a big step up from that. There's also a lot more violent imagery and on-screen deaths which allows the characters to show how devastated they are by the consequences of their actions.

Puzzles are logical and satisfying to solve, for the most part. There's good variety between math, object hunting, and experimentation. Rather than having an explicit "Easy" setting, characters will gradually comment on the puzzle if you continue to exit the puzzle and re-enter; you can click through these conversations without reading if you adamantly do not want hints. There were no puzzles where the English localization caused problems.

On the flip side, the story—while it has twists that I REALLY enjoyed—doesn't end on a perfect note. A few things set up in this game and in VLR are left unresolved; I had hoped for a fantastic ending and got one that was merely good.

The character models and animations are not that great. Diana's skirt in particular looks bad whenever she's not standing up. Some of the running animations look like a first-year student's homework. The mouth animations aren't detailed enough to accurately match their speech. It looks like it was rushed, but it's probably also the result of the game needing to run on two handheld consoles. A PC game that is basically nothing but cutscenes (not that I'm calling that a bad concept for a game, obviously) ought to at least look comparable to other PC games at the same price point. It goes without saying that ZTD does not.

But in the end, it doesn't have to look amazing to do what it is trying to do: bring you back to the Zero Escape world to let you solve the puzzles and see the story. If you want to unravel a crazy plot of crisscrossing timelines while occasionally stopping for a clever puzzle, you are not likely to be disappointed.

24039438.review:
First and foremost let's get this out of the way:  I would first only play this game if you have played 999 and VLR.  Once and only after you've done that play this game.  Even then I would replay both games and read up as much as you can on it as the story in both games, and the philosophy, is super deep and tense.  To put it as short as possible this game is a hallmark in story telling, it has incredible voice acting and the are enough shocking story moments to keep you spinning in your chair or on your couch.

My only gripe is that coming from VLR the almost non-linear pathing can get pretty confusing sometimes.  I appreciate what the game is doing by introducing 3 main protagonists of sorts, or 3 main story groups, but it's very hard to keep track of the time lines that youre in when you choose them.  In VLR everything was linear in a sense where you followed a natural progression til you hit a dead end or a make a decision.  Here at anytime you can be kicked out of what the game calls a fragment and you need to either join another fragment or another character teams fragment - again this just causes a very disjointed story at times.  In the end after 100% the game it is understood more or less but it be confusing at the beginning - whether this was intentional is debateable as your characters in game are given a drug that causes them to forget usually after ever fragment.

Overall though, I completed 100% as mentioned in under 20 hours.  I will admit that I did use a guide once or two on a few puzzles, some of them are savage such as the one where you need to translate an alien language, think hiroglypics, into a tridecimal number system.  There are also some clues that even after the solution is known are very vague or poorly explained but thats only a small handful.

Overall I will be giving this game a perfect 5 out of 5.  It's a must buy/play but again if you havent played 999 or VLR I would avoid for now, if you insist on playing it I can only assume you wont get the full benefit of it yet - it may only be a 3 or 4 out of 5 for you now.

24038811.review: Zero Escape 3 is bittersweet. On one hand, you could argue the storyline and cinematic presentation is the best in the series. The puzzles aren't the strongest the series has seen, but the consequences of the decisions made within the game have a much more immediate effect on the story. The graphics are genuinely not very good, even on PC they look poorly animated even for a handheld game. Many things that were supposedly to be resolved from 999 and Virtue's Last Reward are not actually very clearly addressed (for the sake of spoilers I will leave it at that). There are a lot of great ideas in the narrative and design of the game that take place here, some of which are so over the top I might think they actually destroy any chance the narrative has of making sense. At the very least, I will say I had a lot of fun solving the puzzles, had many laughs and occasionally emotional moments watching the various ways people died and overall hope that if there is a Zero Escape 4, it takes less than four years to come out! 8.8/10, here's to hoping Uchikoshi has a bigger budget to work with next time around.

24038780.review:
As many before me have said: Please, first play 'Zero Escape: 999' and 'Zero Escape 2: Virtue’s Last Reward' respectively, before playing 'Zero Escape 3: Zero Time Dilemma'. 

The series as a whole is incredible. I dare to say the best I’ve ever played. I thoroughly enjoyed Zero Time Dilemma. The puzzles were fun, and I loved the silly little interactions like in the previous two games. The soundtrack is wonderful. I loved the gameplay and, in this aspect, think it’s the best out the series. I especially loved D-team: Their voice actors were on point. I loved their story, interactions and endings. They were what made Zero Time Dilemma for me.

The main story started off fantastically and promising. I was completely hooked throughout most of the game. However, when nearing the end, I got a bit let down.

The revelation and the true ending were underwhelming. I don’t think they were necessarily bad ideas, however badly executed. Questions from the previous games that the makers promised would be answered and explained, were left unanswered and unexplained. Even more questions were raised. The game by itself is great, but I can’t say that it's a good and proper conclusion to the series. 

I'm convinced that I wouldn’t have been let down if they had extended the ending, given certain characters more screen time and backstory, and spent time answering and addressing things from both this game and the previous games. I truly hope that this will be corrected and that we can be given closure. Not necessarily with an expansion or a fourth game, perhaps with a short novel.

The underwhelming ending doesn’t take away the fantastic moments in the game. Some were my favourites out of the entire series. Despite leaving us with many questions, there were things that did get answered and were given closure. I know that Uchikoshi and co. have done the best they could with a limited budget, and I’m very grateful for this game existing in the first place. I thoroughly enjoyed and loved Zero Time Dilemma, despite its flaws.
