23939641.review:
I am currently playing through the 3DS copy of Zero Time Dilemma.

999 and Virtue's Last Reward are some of the greatest pure experiences I've ever had in any medium (book, video game, movie, anime, whatever).    Zero Time Dilemma is shaping up to be the same way.     If you're looking for an open-world experience, this is not it.  If you're looking for tight gameplay mechanics ala Super Meat Boy or Mario, this is not it.

What you get from the Zero Escape series is an incredible journey, a series of interactive novels with room-escape puzzle segments.    The games take full advantage of the interactive nature of video games to tell stories that are both fantastical and intimate.    You will wonder just what in the world is going on at times, but bit by bit, piece by piece, the story of each individual title comes together.

And then the games take everything you've learned and proceed blow your mind with it.

These games are experiences I will cherish for the rest of my life.   If you take this journey yourself, you absolutely must do everything in your power to play them in order:  999, then VLR, then ZTD.     You absolutely must do everything in your power to NOT read spoilers about the characters or plot points - this includes looking up  random wiki profiles on the characters, since you may accidentally stumble across spoilers in a page title or hyperlink.

999 is available for the Nintendo DS and makes full usage of the device.  A stripped down version of 999 which removes the puzzle sequences from the game, as well as the Nintendo DS elements is available on IOS.   Virtue's Last Reward is available on the 3DS and Playstation Vita -   both versions are the same, although the 3DS version contains a save-corrupting bug which can be avoided as long as you save only during the story sequences (not the puzzle sequences).  

Both titles are reportedly going to be coming to Steam, so for those of you who  haven't been exposed to this series yet, if you wait a while, you should be able to experience the complete series on your PCs.  Trust me when I say you don't want to play the games out of order.   Because once you do,  you've had earlier titles spoiled for you, and there's no turning back from that.   You will have missed out on the once-in-a-lifetime experiences of the earlier title(s).

Enjoy the music.    Connect with the characters.    Take in the stories.   Scratch your head on the puzzles.   It's one hell of a journey.

Now, if you'll excuse me, I have to go back to playing this game.

23938667.review:
Since it came out today i obviously didnt have time to complete the game and i will probably update when i do
but this is just 'first impressions' review to not only share my thoughts so far but also try to convince people to buy this game.
First of all the game is very text heavy, the story is presented in cutscenes rather literal chuncks of text to read
i still say it's text heavy because even thought it lacks the 'novel' part and replaces it with cinematics it is still a visual novel so be prepared for a game that expects you to sit back and pay attention to the story.
If you're the kind of gamer who skips text or story to quickly to move on to the next bit of gameplay
This is probably not the game for you

As far as the cutscenes themselves go you have to keep in mind that they were primarily intended to run on portable hardware so they wont look as good as other pc releases today
That said i found them very enjoyable to look at just because of the art direction alone, character models are very well done and even though there might be a low res texture here and there overall the graphics are certainly not a let down and i'm happy they managed to transition well from the 2d/3d sprites to fully animated 3d models.
If we're are talking about animation however i do have to mention that it isnt the smoothest
Character animation can be rough and robotic at times but i didnt find it too distracting since every animation is unique unlike in previous where they would have generic poses.
Because of this rough animation, the lip-sync isnt perfect either though i didnt find it breaking immersion at all this is mostly because of the excellent writing, the localization team behind this has done a great a job, and the well done performances by the various voice actors
I've only played with the English dub so far and everyone fits their role and delivers their lines just fine.

Now let's talk about gameplay, trough various moments in the game you are trapped in a certain location and have to get out in order to move on to the next bit of story. These escape segments have no time limit and thank god for that because even though the puzzles are very well done they are also certainly challenging
However by no means unfair
You are always given enough hints to find the solution and the puzzles themselves are unique and fun to solve each time
Even if you're not a fan of point and click or puzzle games
You will not have trouble solving any of these if you are patient and willing to search for clues. These escape rooms can be done in any order and which one you are trapped in depends on which team you've chosen. Team C, Team Q or team D. All of these teams consist of 3 persons each and you will play as either Carlos(c), Q(q) or Diana (d) each being the leader of their team.
You can freely switch between teams at any time as well.

Another big part of the game is decisionmaking you are given a flow-char where you can see the different outcomes for every decision you make and believe me, there are a lot.
While games like 'the walking dead' bu telltale games offer you the illusion of free choice
Here your choice has a drastic consequence each time
You might die in the middle of the game when there is still so much more to discover, you might even die in your very first escape room
The best thing about this is that the choices you have to make are never black and white
There's always that "but what if..."
There is no right or wrong decision. It really makes you think and thats what this game is all about. To make you think.
I don't really want to talk more about these decisions just because i wsnt to avoid spoiling but there will be deaths and the possibillity of you doing at every moment is very real.
This makes it even more tough for when you have to choose 1 person to save and one person to let die for example
You really feel connected to these characters.

As far as playing other games in the series go i definitely recommend you check them out 999 and Virtue's last reward.
These came out before Zero Time Dilemma but the timeline goes like this:
999 --> Zero Time Dilemma --> VLR
So while not necessary i do recommend playing the other games before or after this one
You're given enough info and explanation during this game to get a general understading of what happened during the other games but you'll feel so much more connected to the story and characters when you played the other games

In the end is Zero Time Dilemma worth buying? Yes. Oh god yes. It's a great example of great story telling along with a killer set of puzzles, escape scenarios and one of if not the most hardest decisions you will ever make in video games and possibly your life.
Get this if you're a fan of VN/puzzle/escape/point and click/choice-based games
Or you know, if you're into saw
If not then i still recommend you at least give it a try
Chances are it will be become one of your favorite games of all time

23932391.review:
As a preface, I'd HIGHLY recommend you play the first two games in the series before giving this a try. While ZTD can be played as a standalone title, you'll be missing out on a lot of crucial information and you won't enjoy it to its maximum potential.

Another hit in the Zero Escape series which has yet to have a bad (or even mediocre) title. The overall premise is similar to the two previous games: 9 people are stuck in an underground bunker, where they are forced by the antagonist (a peculiar geezer named Zero) to play a game ('the nonary game' in the previous titles, 'the decision game' in ZTD). For each person that dies, a password will be obtained for the X Door, which when provided with 6 passwords, will open and result in freedom for whoever opened it (and whoever passes through in the ten seconds after). This is the basic premise, but the story goes MUCH deeper than this and anyone who has played a Zero Escape title beforehand will understand what I'm saying.

I've personally already completed the 3DS version of ZTD, so I can say with absolute certainty that the story is great. My only criticism comes in the form of the games ending. Without spoiling anything, I believe that if this was meant to be the conclusion to the series, they have left the ending a little open ended (I'm hesitant to call sequel-bait, but it's a distinct possibility). This may result in another game in the series being released (which I'd love), but based on the wait many fans have had to endure for ZTD, it's a distinct possibility that another may not be made. Don't let this put you off, however - the journey through the entire game itself is incredible and it's on par with the previous titles (which are also held in a very high regard by most people who have played them). Some of the plot twists will blow your mind!

In terms of gameplay, there's not really a lot I can say. The game consists of a mixture of visual novel elements along with 'escape the room' style puzzles, with a large flowchart full of branching decisions. The game handles this in a very unique and interesting way, however, allowing you to jump between fragments of the timeline, not actually knowing where they place until they're completed. This allows you to jump right into whichever fragment you desire, and play the game in whatever order you choose.

The PC port is absolutely fantastic, and I have been getting consistent 60FPS at 1080p with full antialiasing with an antique GTX 650 and AMD-4170fx rig. The animations may be a little jarring occasionally, but the voice acting more than makes up for this.

Overall, Zero Time Dilemma is a fantastic entry into the series and I'd highly recommend buying it ASAP. Do yourself a favour, and play the first two though. You'll never regret it.

23931473.review:
Before you read my review, there are a few things you should note:
- This game is very text-heavy and you will be doing a lot of reading and listening.
- This game is rated 18 for a reason; topics and imagery that could make people feel uneasy will appear in this game.
- You're probably going to need a notepad and pen
            
If all of the above things bother you, you probably won't like this game. If you're alright with these, then continue to read!
            
[b]Zero Escape: Zero Time Dilemma - Overview[/b]
9 people wake up to find themselves trapped in an underground facility. They're told the only way they can escape is for six of them to die. In addition to this, they'll be put to sleep and lose their memories every 90 minutes. You're also told a story about a woman going for a run. She comes to a fork in the path, however this time she takes the left path rather than the right path like she usually does, because there was a snail. Two hours later, she's murdered. In ZTD, [b]you become the snail[/b]. (Metaphorically of course, but that would be pretty cool.)
            
Zero Time Dilemma is the third (and final) game in the Zero Escape series, straight out of the mind of the wonderful Kotaro Uchikoshi. The game features a non-linear narrative (meaning you don't have to play the game in a set order), and depends on your choices and their consequences to advance.
            
There are essentially three parts to ZTD: cutscenes/story, Escape Rooms, and player's decision. Like I stated above, there is a lot of reading to do as the cutscenes feature heavily between different segments of the game, and (depending on how adept you are at puzzles) you're probably going to spend most of your time watching these cutscenes. The escape rooms are the majority of the gameplay - you'll be placed in a variety of different rooms, and must use your own knowledge and the items and clues provided for you to make your escape. Players decision is exactly what it sounds like, similar to the choice aspect of [i]Life Is Strange[/i], but with a bit more of a twist - the choices you make are weighted on a percentage chance, so they may end well or they may end [b]horrifically[/b].

[b]Zero Escape: Zero Time Dilemma - My Thoughts[/b]
I have played the entire Zero Escape series (albeit in the wrong order - oops), and I love them. As a puzzle fan and an avid reader, the series is perfect for me. However, you do not need to have played the previous two games to enjoy Zero Time Dilemma, but it is recommended. I repeat: [b]you do not need to have played the previous two games to enjoy Zero Time Dilemma[/b].

[u]Story:[/u]            
The story behind ZTD is phenomenal. Every twist and turn poses more questions, and you feel as though you can't stop playing until you've found all the answers. There are many different endings to explore, both good and bad, and you won't feel like you've truly completed the game until you've seen them all. As previously stated, it follows a non-linear story and you can play it in any order - which works extremely well due to the participants losing their memories every 90 minutes. They don't know what order things are happening in, and neither do you. However, as endings are unlocked, you'll be able to see the game's story flowchart, and this will allow you to pinpoint things you've missed. 

[u]Gameplay:[/u]            
I love the gameplay within ZTD. I've managed to escape all of the rooms without help, but I did struggle and become frustrated at points. Escaping from a room off of your own back is extremely rewarding though, so try not to use guides unless you're 100% stuck! (See my tips for escaping below.) The only thing that bothers me, is lack of gameplay during the first hour or so. The introduction is quite heavy, and you'll find yourself waiting a while to get into things.

[u]Characters:[/u]            
The characters are very interesting too. There are 4 returning characters from the older games, and 5 totally new characters - and they've all got their own story to tell. You start off by only knowing their names, but after playing through their teams fragments, you'll slowly learn how they came to end up in this messed up game of murder. Whilst I'm on the subject, the 9 people are split into 3 teams, each with a team leader (and that's who you'll control). But I honestly loved getting to know them all, some of their backstories really took a turn for the worse.

[u]Visuals:[/u]            
The art and animation is average honestly. Now, this does not mean bad, it just means compared to the rest of the game, I don't favour it as much. If you love the artstyle from the Telltale games such as [i]The Wolf Among Us[/i] and [i]Telltales The Walking Dead[/i], you'll probably like the art in ZTD. However, the animations are quite clunky, and the mouth movements can be quite bizarre at time. That being said, the team making the game was small and they had limited time and resources so they did a great job considering that!


[b]Zero Escape: Zero Time Dilemma - Pros and Cons[/b]
Pros:
- Compelling and interesting story
- Amazingly written characters and backstories
- No puzzle room is the same, and they will all make you think
- The addition of the skip text button!
- Flawless PC port
- Estimated 20 hours playtime without skipping/using guides
- Gab
            
Cons:
- Janky animations
- The memopad (partially because it has a limit, partially because no one likes writing with a mouse or controller)
- Lack of gameplay during the intro
- No 'rotate' prompt on Xbox Controller (it's RB)
- I pressed [i]the[/i] button
- Snails
            
Do I recommend the game? [b][u]100% yes[/u][/b]. I'm honoured that Spike Chunsoft provided me with a review copy, ZTD is currently my favourite game of the year. If you love mysteries and puzzles, get this game! Fantastic.

23929847.review:
[b] Target Audience: [/b] [I] Those who want to think. [/i]

[b] Summary: [/b] 
Ready to get your mind blown, because Spike Chunsoft is ready to poke around inside your head again with the third in the Zero Time Dilemma series. And while it's not as good as Danganronpa 2, it's still worth its weight in gold in terms of this writing. Drama's the name of the game here. The game may seemingly start slow in building its set pieces from the beginning, but the game gets into a good pace of intrigue and shock factor when you have to make hard decisions about the well being of the teams with Zero's game. And the third act is an onslaught of set piece after set piece, as you just sorta stand there in awe while it keeps on blowing you away with the next reveal. And puzzle wise, the game does a great job of mixing things up as well, being able to keep things reasonably fresh as you try to break out of the latest room that you've been trapped in. Where the game falters a bit is in its characters: as a couple of them just don't have the charisma to stand out. And some of the presentation elements really missed the mark, in particular with the animations. The animations are just plain bad. But the game focuses on the story, and that's where it truly shines. It's a memorable third game that gives several answers, but asks new questions in the process. Another great game in the Aksys and Spike Chunsoft library.

[b]Video Review: [/b] https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=mo4zIjU4Iyw

[u] Lists: [/u]
[b]Positives:[/b]
[list]
[*] The drama created. It's never cheap, and it's always able to pull on strings, even if the character has had questionable decision making up to that point. The game does well in making you feel for these characters.
[*] The entire ramp up to the climax and the finale. It's just jaw dropping with everything that goes on. You'll not only be at the edge of your seat, you'll be glued to the screen, not wanting to leave. 
[*] The writing duality in terms of the choices that are presented to you. Each choice doesn't seem like a no brainer (although you will choose both eventually to see all the plot), and makes you truly wonder what you'd do in the same situation.
[*] The piece meal story progression in terms of the overall timeline flowchart is fun. Forcing the player to play the story out of order, to the point where they have to figure out where exactly they are in the timeline: yeah, that works rather well here.
[*] The science/math theory elements are always appreciate from a player who has a CS background. Yay Quantum Theory!
[*] The plot does a great job of not spoiling itself, but giving hints about what's to come in the future. I noticed that when I went back to rerecord sections that some of the language and symbolism used connected directly to the end of the game, and I was just in awe at how woven it was. I like to call that the Edgar Wright effect, and ZTD has it in spades.
[*] 20+ Hours of content here. While it's a 40 dollar game, you do get your money's worth in the genre.
[*] In 99% of the cases, the game does a good job of hinting when you get stuck, in particular when you're stuck within a room and can't figure out what you need to do next.
[*] Q team in particular has some really interesting characters within it. Their personalities help really create an interesting dynamic, and was probably my favorite team to follow.
[*] Puzzle design has a good variety to it, and hits the sweet spot of reasonably challenging, without making you throw your keyboard at the wall.
[*] The game does a reasonable job of making you ignore plot holes, just by its immersion factor alone. And I'm not talking about those perceived plot holes that aren't actually there because it hasn't shown what it truly is yet, I'm talking about the actual plot holes.
[*] Game includes the japanese voice acting as an option. Good to see.
[*] Just on a personal note, it's nice to see the PC port of the game come out at the same time as the 3DS and Vita. It's nice to see that the PC platform is being taken more seriously, and that is being opened to a whole new audience. Now get on porting 999 and VLR, please.
[/list]

[b]Negatives:[/b]
[list]
[*] Oh geez, the animations. Some of the worst animations I've seen in a game in a long while. Not only are they unnatural, they are comically bad at some points, giving the game a B horror movie feel at times. Which could have worked if the other parts of the games tone didn't go completely against it.
[*] There's some missing sound elements in cutscenes that work against the games immersion. If blood is draining into a drain, I expect to hear something along the lines of drainage. 
[*] The little details of this PC port are annoying. There's things like the labels for keys that aren't included at the top level (you have to go to a help menu to find them), and even then, they can be wrong. For those who play: W is your quick item switch. You're welcome.
[*] The characters that have come over from VLR really need you to have played VLR in order to truly enjoy them. Otherwise, it feels like there's segments missing.
[*] Once in a while, the english voice acting...can be a little cringy. 
[*] Actually, a couple of these characters just don't have the charisma to keep you interested in them specifically. Q team being the exception.
[*] Keyboard functionality within the sections where you have to type in words, would have been appreciated.
[*] Attempting to write on the in game notepad is like buttering up your hands and trying to play Wii Bowling. It just, no. 
[/list]

39469900.review: A game for Phi Brain Kids :b
